Blog-Posts/Keyboards/Dactyl-Manuform-R-T.title: Dactyl Manuform R-Track
Blog-Posts/Keyboards/Dactyl-Manuform-R-T.content:
Dactyl Manuform R-Track
Preface: This design is entirely made by QQurn, and details can be found at gitlab.com/keyboards1/dm_r_track.
After building my first ergonomic keyboard a few months prior, I wanted to do more electronics. I started toying with the idea of having a pointing device (something to move the mouse) integrated into the keyboard. In researching that idea, I stumbled upon an amazing design. Here are some of the key features:

Split Keyboard, 5x6 layout for 62 keys
PMW3360 Motion Sensor Integrated under the right thumb for Trackball
I^2C Communciation Between the Halves over RJ9
Arduino Micro on the Right, Pro Micro on the Left
Fully programmable with 32kB of flash

I was enthralled, but the only way to make one was with a 3D Printer. So I purchased a 3D Printer over the holidays, and got to work setting it up. After honing in the printer, I fired it up to create the case. But that was just the beginning of the work. The shape is molded to the human hand to minimize movement and maximize comfort, which requires a 3D “keywell,” curving the keys to the fingers. This shape prevents standard printed circuit boards, which are rigid and planar.
So, QQurn’s design resorts to “handwiring,” where the switches are connected by dozens of individual short wires soldered in air. To make matters worse, switch matrices require a diode on each key (see here for why). You have to solder each wire in air, totaling over 200 connections. It is very tedious.
So, painfully, over about 20 hours, I wired all the switches, along with an I^2C bus to communicate between the two microcontrollers, and the trackball sensor. A few hours of troubleshooting and a lot of firmware tweaking later, and I have an absolutely amazing keyboard. You really can’t understand how comfortable it is until you use it for a full work day, but it was definitely worth the time, money, and effort. Now for the fun part: Photos!


What Did I Learn?
While I didn’t create this design myself, there was still a lot of work involved in manufacturing and wiring it. I learned a ton about 3D printing, soldering, and also the QMK firmware framework which enables the keyboard to work.

Blog-Posts/Keyboards/ErgoTravel.title: ErgoTravel
Blog-Posts/Keyboards/ErgoTravel.content:
The ErgoTravel was my first foray into the world of Ergonomic Keyboards. For this first build, I stuck with something tried and true. I purchased a kit from an online retailer, and built it according to the instructions. While the components were all included, I had to solder everything by hand, my first major experience with soldering. It was a lot of fun.
Once I had everything soldered and assembled, the next step was firmware. The keyboard runs QMK, a C-based firmware framework that runs on hundreds of keyboard designs, including the ErgoTravel. The main config, describing the electrical design, was already complete, but I had to create and tweak my own keymap. The keymap determines what pressing a given key actually does. I decided to get ambitious and try out as many of QMKs features as possible, including tap dances, layers, layer-taps, and leader key. It was great to explore the firmware and learn a bit of C.
Once I had built the keyboard and been using it for a few weeks, a small problem became apparent: the kit didn’t come with a full case, so the PCB was partially exposed. I was slowly noticing dust and gunk accumulating, which I thought could become an issue long term. So I wanted to create a more full enclosure. Luckily, my father is a hobbyist wood-worker, so we worked together create a case of walnut. It’s beautiful, I think.

Blog-Posts/Keyboards/Icarus.title: Icarus
Blog-Posts/Keyboards/Icarus.content:
Icarus
Introduction
I had just finished a written math assignment when I thought to myself: why should I have to compute something on my calculator, then enter it into the computer? Why isn’t the calculator directly connected to my computer? So I decided to try and solve that problem by making a numpad and calculator in one. You activate calculate mode, input your calculation, and it writes out the answer. Here’s a quick feature overview:

Fully Programmable with QMK firmware
Custom PCB with onboard Cortex M4 Microprocessor
Integrated 128x32 OLED
USB-C Connection
4x5 Mechanical Key Matrix for 20 Keys

The project has two main parts: Hardware (PCB and case) and software (actual functionality).
Hardware Development
Circuitry
The microprocessor (i.e. the brain) is integrated directly into a custom PCB, along with USB circuitry, the key matrix, and a voltage regulator. The MCU runs on an external 16MHz crystal. I designed the PCB using KiCad, a free and open source CAD suite for electrical engineering. PCB development is one of my favorite parts of these keyboard projects, because its the right mix of creativity, problem solving, and research. For this board in particular I spent a lot of time reading about the STM32F4xx series and the best design practices for PCBs. Here’s the final schematic:

And the PCB Layout:

I had the PCB manufactured and some of the surface mount soldering done by JLCPCB.
Case Design
Once I had a designed the PCB, I needed somewhere to put it. A few months prior I had purchased a 3D printer, so I decided to design and 3D print a case. I created the enclosure in AutoDesk Fusion 360. I tried my hand at creating a screw-less design. The stackup involves three parts:

The main plate
The PCB
The bottom plate

The PCB is attached to the main plate by the tension between the mechanical switches (which snap into the plate) and the holes in the PCB. The bottom plate then has a “snap-fit” to attach to the main plate, fulling enclosing the PCB. Overall, I think it was pretty successful.
Software Development
This ended up being where the bulk of my time on this project went. It turns out that programming a calculator isn’t as easy as I thought! It turned out to be a great learning experience. At the start of this project I didn’t really have much experience with C programming, but I developed a lot of skills by programming Icarus. The base for the firmware is the wonderful Quantum Mechanical Keyboard Firmware, or QMK. It has a lot of abstraction that makes it easy to get started with your own firmware. Each keyboard has a config that defines its electrical configuration and layout, and then each user can create their own keymaps, with a specific layout to fit them. I assumed that setting up the initial config would be the easy part (as it had been with my previous boards), but I was quickly proved wrong. The first time I plugged in the PCB and flashed it with firmware that I thought was correct, the entire thing hung and became non-responsive. I spent hours debugging before eventually discovering that the quartz clock that I had chosen for the microcontroller was not the same speed as the QMK default. Once I fixed that, it was on to programming the calculator functionality.
While most normal inputs are easy to setup in QMK, I had to program the calculator functionality mostly from scratch. The way I tackled this was to create a togglable layer with custom defined keycodes corresponding to each matrix position. In other words, I defined functions for each key. Most of these functions write to a char array representing the current equation. The ”=” button then calls a function from the TinyExpr library to interpret that buffer into a numeric result, if possible. Pressing enter then sends it to the computer using the qmk “send_string()” function.
To make this all more user-friendly, I added a little 128x32 OLED that displays the current expression buffer and expected result as you enter in characters. On the default layer, where you just enter numbers like a numpad, it displays the layout because my keycaps are blank.
Final Product

Blog-Posts/Keyboards/Silvis.title: Silvis
Blog-Posts/Keyboards/Silvis.content:
Introduction
After building Tantalus and another Dactyl Manuform 5x6, I still wasn’t fully satisfied with my secondary keyboard. My Dactyl Manuform R-Track is perfect for my primary setup, but I have been moving around more and doing school work on a laptop. Unfortunately the Dactyl is quite bulky and a little finicky (owing to my amateur soldering job), so it isn’t very mobile.
I began toying around with ideas for a while. I finally settled on creating another flat keyboard. There would be no mousing device, no curved keywells. I wanted to prioritize the typing experience, above other luxuries. I figure it is better to make the best portable keyboard possible than a mediocre mouse and mediocre keyboard. So from that came Silvis.
Feature List

Custom PCB with On-board STM32F411 microcontroller
3D Printed Case designed in Fusion 360
Programmable with QMK
Addressable Per-Key RGB
USB-C
Hotswappable Cherry MX keys

Hardware Development
PCB
I designed the Silvis PCB using the KiCad suite, which I’m now pretty adept with. The PCB features an STM32F411 microcontroller, which has 512 Kb of flash and 128 Kb of ram, plenty for a keyboard. The schematic is overall similar to one of my previous projects, Icarus, because I chose the same MCU for both. The biggest difference is that Silvis features per-key SK6812 Mini-E LEDs, which are reversed mounted. This means that you solder them on the back, but they point up through a hole illuminating the keys from below.
Laying out the components for this PCB proved far more challenging then any of my previous designs. I wanted the design to be symmetric but unibody, with a couple of different angles between columns to match the splay of my hand. Additionally, each and every one of the 58 keys has both an LED and a diode (see here for why) attached to it. Placing that all by hand was… daunting. I knew I would make a mistake. So I started looking into ways to do it programmatically instead.
ErgoGen
Ergogen, short for ergonomic keyboard generator, is a Javascript project that allows you to describe a 2D keyboard layout using a YAML config, and then generate design files, including plate SVGs, PCBs, and even cases, from there. This allows for a much faster workflow, by tweaking code instead of manually shifting keys in KiCad. I used ErgoGen to place the switches, diodes, and LEDs for the Silvis matrix. I’m a huge fan of this project, and strongly suggest it to anyone looking to make their own ergonomic keyboard.
Case Design
I wanted Silvis to be able to hold up to abuse. I wanted a rigid case with a durable design. Of course, for those purposes, a 3D printed case probably wasn’t my best choice, but its what I had to work with.
The overall design is pretty simple. I have a 3d-printed shell that the PCB drops down into, then a FR4 plate goes over that, with 10 M3 screws holding everything together. I designed all of this in Fusion360.
Software Development
Software for this project was really easy. Over my past keyboard projects I have developed a strong understanding of QMK, so that is what I chose to use again. The only tricky part was configuring the LEDs to work properly.
Usage
I’ve now been using Silvis as my daily driver for about 6 months, and it is wonderful. All of my tedious design work really did pay off.

Blog-Posts/Keyboards/Tantalus.title: Tantalus
Blog-Posts/Keyboards/Tantalus.content:
Tantalus
Introduction
This is my 3rd ergonomic keyboard, and my first completely custom design. My previous build, the Dactyl Manuform R-Track, was almost perfect. However I needed another board for my second setup, and really didn’t want to handwire again. So, I set about learning how to design my own 3d models and create my own PCBs. I had a couple goals in mind:

Fully Programmable with QMK
38 Choc Keys with a layout optimized for prose
Custom PCB with integrated MCU
USB-C Connection
Trackball on a daughterboard

I achieved most of these goals, but in practice it isn’t perfect.
Hardware Development
This project was a great learning experience for a number of reasons, but the big one is that I got very acquainted with KiCad, an open source PCB design tool. From scratch, I learned how to create schematics, modify and design footprints, layout a PCB, route a PCB, and read datasheets. Since this was my first design, I kept it somewhat simple. No LEDs, no OLED, no split board, none of the other possible bells and whistles for QMK boards.
Instead of using a separate daughterboard for the microcontroller as I had on my previous two builds, Tantalus has an ATMEGA32U4 directly on the PCB, along with all of the clock and voltage regulating circuity that entails. This enables me to have a USB-C connection anywhere else on the PCB.
And the PCB Layout:

Once I finished the PCB, I set to work learning another tool from the ground up: AutoDesk Fusion 360. I needed to create a 3d printable enclosure for the PCB, with a spot for the trackball. I severely underestimated how hard it’d be. After many, many iterations, here is a render of the final design:

Assembly
I had the PCB manufactured and partially soldered by JLCPCB. Once I had soldered the rest of the components and printed the case, it came time to assemble everything. Unfortunately, everything didn’t go to plan. Some of the tolerances on the case were bad, the wiring was tight, and the trackball sensor interefered with the case closing. Additionally, I made a couple small mistakes on the PCB that rendered two keys non-functional, until I ran jumper wires to fix it. However, with a bit of gumption and a dremel, I was eventually able to get everything fitting and the case to close.
Final Product
Without further adue, here is how it turned out:

And the internals:

Is it janky? Yes. Did I make mistakes? Yes. Am I happy with the final product? Not really. Am I glad I did it? Absolutely. This was a great learning experience.

Blog-Posts/Posts/BWSI.title: Beaver Works Summer Institute
Blog-Posts/Posts/BWSI.content:
Beaver Works Summer Institute
Introduction
In the summer of 2023, I had the pleasure of attending the Beaver Works Summer Institute, a program for rising high school seniors run by MIT. It offers the brightest students in the nation the chance to work on fascinating engineering projects with courses taught by MIT faculty.
I chose to take the Autonomous Underwater Vehicle Challenge, where we learned to take a remotely operated underwater robot and transform it into something fully autonomous using sensor data, computer vision, and motor control. Here is what our robot looked like:

Physics
The first step on our journey to autonomy was understanding how the robot moves in the water. It has a 6 thruster configuration, with 4 on the xy plane and 2 for vertical movement. This allows us full control in all 3 dimensions. You can turn the robot (yaw) by turning on opposing horizontal thrusters. We didn’t really bother with pitch and roll, but you should be able to control those to. In order to understand how the robot actually moves, you have to do just a little bit of linear algebra. Thinking only in the 2D plane, you can find the horizontal and vertical components of each thruster using basic trigonometry. You can do the same to calculate torque, assuming you know the dimensions of the robot. Once you have the components relative to the AUV, you can translate them into the global plane using a rotation matrix. Now that calculation only gives us the acceleration of the AUV. You really want the expected position, so you have to integrate twice. This math formed the basis of our first week of study.
Motor Control
Now that we had an idea as to how the robot would respond, it was time to learn how to actually control it. We did so using the PID control model, which relies on an error and the change in that error over time in order to calculate how much to change by. Essentially, the speed of the motors depends on how far away from your target you are, and how quickly that distance is changing. This prevents you from overshooting. The code for this is actually exceedingly simple, but the bulk of the work came from testing it on our actual robots and honing in on the gain values.
Computer Vision
Okay, so we can control our robot and make it go where we want to now. How do we know, autonomously, where to go? The same way you do: with vision! Our robot is equipped with a high resolution, high refresh rate camera. You can process that image to gather data about the surroundings, and then decide where to go accordingly. For us, we had to main modes of travel: following April Tags (basically QR codes for robots), or following the lane of a pool. April tags stand out quite a bit an image, so they are pretty easy to find and follow. They give a lot of information based on their size in the image, so you can actually follow them pretty accurately. Pool lanes are a lot harder. They are just dark edges at the bottom of the pool, and there is often times multiple of them in the image, so it can be very difficult to detect them all and pick the right one. I would say that this problem is where the bulk of my development work went throughout the 4 week program.

Blog-Posts/Posts/Biking.title: Biking
Blog-Posts/Posts/Biking.content:
Biking
Research
As winter settled in and I began to spend more time inside, I was looking to get into a new excerise hobby. I spent a while thinking about it, and eventually decided that I wanted to start biking. I’ve known how to ride a bike for a long time, but I’ve never really had a good one, and never really gone on wrong rides. But after discovering the world of bikepacking and seeing all kinds of adventures documented on YouTube, I decided I was going to get into it. So, I spent about a month looking into all kinds of bikes, from sleek and modern road bikes to full-suspension mountain bikes. I learned a lot from that research. For one, bikes are expensive. There are also a lot of options. There’s suspension, drive trains, rim versus disc brakes, dropbar versus flatbar, and countless other of decisions to make before purchasing a bike. But, eventually, I started to develop an idea of what I wanted.
The Poseidon X
The bike I settled on, and purchased in December 2022, is the Poseidon X. It is a gravel bike, built for rougher terrain (like on gravel roads!) but not neccarisly bumpy and steep trails like you might tackle on a mountain bike. This seems like a good compromise for me, because I will be doing likely 80-90% of my riding on roads, even if I am excited to get on trails come summer. It is a rigid bike, meaning no front or rear suspension. This makes it easier to maintain and cheaper to purchase. It has a 1x10 cassette, which still offers plenty of range for tackling hills or going downhill.
As of January, I haven’t been able to go on any long rides yet due to cold weather. But, from the ~10 mile days I have done, the bike is excellent! Its a blast to ride, with smooth gear shifting, lots of braking power, and good ergonomics. I’m really happy with it!

Blog-Posts/Posts/Obsidian.title: Obsidian Notes
Blog-Posts/Posts/Obsidian.content:
Obsidian Notes
What is Obsidian?
In late 2022, I was lucky enough to stumble onto a wonderful project called Obsidian Notes. The principle is simple: a note-taking software composed of plain markdown files with a focus on interconnection and extensibility. You create a folder of markdown files, and use local links, tags, and canvases to connect everything. This allows you to move from file to file as you would thought to thought. It sounds simple, but is extremely powerful in practice.
But… why?
I was skeptical at first too. People online speak of note software like Obsidian as if they will completly change your life, and I didn’t believe them. But, now that I have been using Obsidian for about 3 months, it really does have a big impact on my workflow and thought proccesses. Essentially, whenever I learn a new concept or have an interesting thought I expect to revisit, I write it down in my Obsidian vault, often in shorthand at first. Then, when I have time later, I can expand it fully. Next time I think about that thing, I can just look at my note to refresh my memory. This can also serve as a to-do list; when you think of something you need to do, just write it down. Maybe tag it. Then you come back later. It has a huge impact on my ability to get things done. Fleeting thoughts become reality a lot more now that I use Obsidian.
Daily Notes
The very first place I write down most of these notes and thoughts is my daily note. A daily note is simply a file that you create each day with the date. From my daily notes I can get to everything I worked or thought about that day. In Obsidian, if you want to create a new file, you just write [[$file_name$]], and then hit Ctrl+Enter. This file will then have a “backlink” to your daily note, which can later be viewed graphically. This allows you to visualize ideas and thoughts on a graph, and follow your train of thoughts. This is especially powerful when you return to a project or idea after a long time.
Tags
Another hugely important feature of Obsidian is tags. I use tags just as topics. So if I make a file about a physics topic, I just tag it with physics. This can be done in two ways:

Inline tags
YAML Frontmatter

Inline tags are just written like#topic directly in your markdown. These are fast to make, but produce visual clutter. YAML Frontmatter tags are written at the very top of the file, like this:
---
tags: [xxxxx, yyyyy]
---

Both methods work with the other, so you can use whatever you want depending on the note. I tend to use inline tags in my daily notes, but YAML frontmatter for when I extract something to its own file.
Graph View
I mentioned the graph view, but I just wanted to give you a visual of what that looks like:

That is a screenshot of my main Obsidian vault, with over 500 notes. It gives a clear visual of how ideas and tags are related. Most of the grouping comes from tags, but those can be disabled to get a direct view of file-to-file connections, if that is what you are looking for. Its really interesting to visualize what you have learned and thought about for the past months.
Syncing
A conventional note-taking approach would involve a notebook, that you can take around with you and write things down in. Obsidian is digital, and not even natively in the cloud. So what do I do if I’m out and about and want to write something down? Well, the way I see it, there are two options:

Sync your vault across devices
Take intermediary notes on another device

I use a mix of both. Sometimes I will write things down on scraps of paper and fold them up in my pocket. Other times, I will write them using Obsidian for my phone (yes, its cross platform!).
There are a couple ways to sync a vault from your phone to laptop or similar. Obsidian themselves offer a service called Obsidian Sync, which is $10 a month for cross-platform cloud syncing with version history. A free approach is to setup a Git/GitHub repository, using the obsidian-git plugin.
Conclusion
So, I implore you: take a look at Obsidian. It might not be for you, and that’s fine, but if you have ever wanted to try out a note taking software, I truly believe that Obsidian is the best option available.

Concepts/Concepts.title: Concepts
Concepts/Concepts.content:
Concepts
Concepts are ideas, rules, or mental groupings of similar objects, events, people, and activities. You have a concept of a ball that includes footballs, rubber balls, soccer balls, and cannon balls, for example. Concepts are typically based on prototypes.
Concepts can be loosely defined, such as a bird; this is a superordinate concept. They could also be very specific, which is called a subordinate concept, for example a Orange-breasted bunting.
This folder includes notes on a variety of concepts from a range of fields and across the subordinate to superordinate spectrum.

References
Myers Psychology for the AP Course; Module 34

Concepts/Math/Algebra/Algebra.title: Algebra
Concepts/Math/Algebra/Algebra.content:
Algebra
Algebra is the branch of mathematics that studies structure and manipulation. We are introduced to elementary algebra in middle or high school, but the field is much deeper and more beautiful.
Subtopics

Concepts/Math/Algebra/Average-Rate-of-Ch.title: Average Rate of Change

Concepts/Math/Algebra/Completing-the-Squ.title: Completing the Square
Concepts/Math/Algebra/Completing-the-Squ.content:
Completing the Square
This is a technique for Solving Quadratic Equations.
We first are given a quadratic ax^2 + bx + c = 0. We subtract c from both sides to get
ax^2 + bx = -c. Then we add \left(\frac{b}{2}\right)^2 to both sides.
The whole equation can thus be rewritten as \left(x + \frac{b}{2}\right)^2 = -c + \left(\frac{b}{2}\right)^{2}.
Then we can square root both sides and isolate x to find the solutions.

Concepts/Math/Algebra/Long-Division-of-P.title: Long Division of Polynomials
Concepts/Math/Algebra/Long-Division-of-P.content:
Long Division of Polynomials
Notation
When using long division, you can set up your problem like this:
\frac{x}{y}
\to
y\overline{)x}
It is helpful to write out all terms of the numerator in the form ax^{n}+bx^{n-1}+ \dots + c. For example, if you had an expression 8x^3, you would write it under the line as 8x^{3}+0x^{2}+0x+0.
Division
The first step is the divide the highest powered term in the divisor and we divide it into the highest powered term in the dividend. You write the result above the line. Next, you multiply the result by the whole divisor, and subtract the result of this multiplication. You continue until you have gone through all the terms. Here is an example:
4x^{2}+2x+1+\frac{1}{2x-1}\over
2x - 1 \overline{)8x^{3}+0x^{2}+0x+0}
You divide 8x^{3} by 2x, yielding 4x^{2}, which you multiply by 2x - 1 to get 8x^{3}-4x^{2}. Subtracting that from the original yields
4x^{2}+0x+0. You then divide 4x^{2} by 2x, yielding 2x. You multiply 2x by 2x-1, subtract the result, and continue…

Concepts/Math/Algebra/Power-Set.title: Power Set
Concepts/Math/Algebra/Power-Set.content:
Power Set
Topic: Algebra
The power set of a Set A is all of the Subsets of A. It is denoted by \mathcal{P}(A).
If A is a finite set with n elements, then \mathcal{P}(A) has 2^{n} elements. That is,
\boxed{|\mathcal{P}(A)| = 2^{|A|}}
Rationale
For each element in A, we can either choose to include it or not include it in any given subset. There is thus 2 options for each of n elements, so there are therefore 2^{n} total subsets.

References

Concepts/Math/Algebra/Proper-Subsets.title: Proper Subsets
Concepts/Math/Algebra/Proper-Subsets.content:
Proper Subsets
Topic: Algebra
A Set A is a proper subset of a set B if A \subseteq B but A \neq B. In this case, we can omit the line: A \subset B. This is alternately written as A \subsetneq B.

References

Concepts/Math/Algebra/Quadratic-Equation.title: Quadratic Equations
Concepts/Math/Algebra/Quadratic-Equation.content:
Quadratic Equations
Topic: Algebra
A quadratic equation is of the form
ax^{2} + bx + c
These equations appear throughout the natural world and the study of mathematics. It is critical to be able to be comfortable Solving Quadratic Equations.

Concepts/Math/Algebra/Quadratic-Formula.title: Quadratic Formula
Concepts/Math/Algebra/Quadratic-Formula.content:
Quadratic Formula
The quadratic formula is
x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^{2} - 4 ac}}{2a}.
$$ It is used in [[Solving Quadratic Equations]].

Concepts/Math/Algebra/Set-Cardinality.title: Set Cardinality
Concepts/Math/Algebra/Set-Cardinality.content:
Set Cardinality
Topic: Algebra
The cardinal number or cardinality of a Set is the length of the set. It is notated by vertical bars, like |S|.
Example
If A = \{1, 2\}, then |A| = 2.
Infinite

Concepts/Math/Algebra/Set-Differences.title: Set Differences
Concepts/Math/Algebra/Set-Differences.content:
Set Differences
Topic: Algebra
The difference A - B of two Sets A and B is defined as A - B = \{x : x \in A \text{ and } x \notin B\}

References

Concepts/Math/Algebra/Set-Equality.title: Set Equality
Concepts/Math/Algebra/Set-Equality.content:
Set Equality
Topic: Algebra
Two Sets are equal, indicated by writing A = B, when they have exactly the same elements. With subset notation, A = B \implies A \subseteq B \text{ and } B \subseteq A.

References

Concepts/Math/Algebra/Set-Intersections.title: Set Intersections
Concepts/Math/Algebra/Set-Intersections.content:
Set Intersections
Topic: Algebra
The intersection of two Sets A and B is all elements belonging to A and B. Symbolically, A \cap B = \{x :  x \in A \text{ and } x \in B \}
If two sets A and B have no intersection (A \cap B = \emptyset), they are said to be disjoint.

References

Concepts/Math/Algebra/Set-Unions.title: Set Unions

Concepts/Math/Algebra/Sets.title: Sets
Concepts/Math/Algebra/Sets.content:
Sets
Topic: Algebra
A set is a unordered collection of different elements. Each thing inside a set is called a element or member of the set.
Elements can be anything: from Presidents of the U.S. to prime numbers. The set is marked by uppercase letters (A, B, C, \dots) and members are marked by lowercase (a, b, c, \dots). A typical set is then written as S = \{a, b, c\} = \{1, 2, 3\}
When it is not convenient to write out all the terms, we can use the \dots notation:
O = \{1, 3, 5, \dots, 49\}
An infinite set may be written, for example, as T = \{2, 4, 6, \dots\}
An alternative is to write using the notation S = \{x : p(x)\} which means all elements x satisfying some condition p(x). For example, S = \{x : |x| = 2\} = \{2, -2\}

Concepts/Math/Algebra/Subsets.title: Subsets
Concepts/Math/Algebra/Subsets.content:
Subsets
Topic: Algebra
A Set A is called a subset of B if every element of A also belongs to B. In this case, we write A \subseteq B.
Every set is a subset of itself: A \subseteq A.
Transclude of Transitivity-of-Subsets
Intervals
The open interval (a, b) is the set
(a, b) = \{x \in \mathbb{R} : a < x < b\}
which is a subset of \mathbb{R}.
The closed interval [a, b] is the set
[a, b] = \{x \in \mathbb{R} : a \leq x \leq b \}
which is, again, a subset of \mathbb{R}.
Transclude of Proper-Subsets
References

Concepts/Math/Algebra/Transitivity-of-Su.title: Transitivity of Subsets
Concepts/Math/Algebra/Transitivity-of-Su.content:
Transitivity of Subsets
Topic: Algebra
Let A, B, C be Sets. If A \subseteq B and B \subseteq C, then A \subseteq C. See Subsets.
Rationale
Think about a element x \in A . Since A \subseteq B, the element x \in B. But B \subseteq C, which implies that x \in C. Therefore, every element that belongs to A also belongs to C and so A \subseteq C.

Concepts/Math/Algebra/Venn-Diagrams.title: Venn Diagrams
Concepts/Math/Algebra/Venn-Diagrams.content:
Venn Diagrams
Topic: Algebra
Venn diagrams are a way to visually represent Sets.

References

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Calculus.title: Calculus
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Calculus.content:
Calculus
The study of the infinitesimal.

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Derivatives/Criti.title: Critical Point
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Derivatives/Criti.content:
Critical Point
If f is defined at c, a critical point is any point where f'(c) = 0 OR f'(c) = DNE (that is, not differentiable at c). The nature of a critical point is determined by the Second Derivative Test. This tells us whether the point is a minimum, maximum, or in multivariate a saddle.


                  
                  Multivariable Calculus 
                  
                

A critical point of a Multivariable Function exists where all of the Partial Derivatives are equal to 0.

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Derivatives/Diffe.title: Differentiability
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Derivatives/Diffe.content:
Differentiability
If a function f has a derivative (is differentiable) at x=c, then f is continuous at x=c. This tells us the that:

\lim_{x \to c^-}f(x) = \lim_{x \to c^+}f(x)
f(a) = \lim_{x \to c}f(x), where f(a) exists

Conversely, a discontinuous function at x = c is not differentiable at that point. However, a function can be continuous and not differentiable at x=c. This occurs when there are corners, cusps, or vertical tangents at x = c

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Derivatives/First.title: First Derivative Test
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Derivatives/First.content:
First Derivative Test
The first Derivative of a function reveals information about the function’s behavior, including critical points and Extrema. The information from the first derivative is summarized by the following list:

If f'(c)=0, then x=c is a [critical point](Critical Point) of f(x).
If f'(x)>0 for all x in interval (a, b), then f(x) is increasing on [a, b].
If f'(x) < 0 for all x in interval (a, b), then f(x) is decreasing on [a, b].
If f'(x) > 0 for x < c and f'(x) < 0 for x > c, then f(c) is a maximum.
If f'(x) < 0 for x < c and f'(x) > 0 for x > c, then f(c) is a minimum.

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Derivatives/Impli.title: Implicit Differentiation
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Derivatives/Impli.content:
Implicit Differentiation
Implicit differentiation is the process used to find the derivative of variables expressed in a more complex relationship than simply y = f(x). For example, you would could you implicit differentiation to find the slope of a circle, expressed as x^{2} + y^{2}= r^{2}, at a certain (x, y) point.
Implicit Differentiation Steps

Differentiate both sides of the equation with respect to the independent variable
Make sure to apply the Chain Rule to expression(s) involving the dependent variable
Relocate all terms involving differentiation of the dependent variable (\frac{dy}{dx}, y’, etc.) to one side of the equation, and everything else to the other side of the equation.
Isolate differentiation of the dependent variable (\frac{dy}{dx}, y’, etc.)
Solve for differentiation of the dependent variable (\frac{dy}{dx}, y’, etc.)



                  
                  Example 1 
                  
                

For example, to find y’ through implicit differentation given 2x^2-3y = \cos(x+y):



































StepJustification2x^2-3y = \cos(x+y)Original equation4x - 3y’ = -\sin(x + y)(1 + y’)Differentiate both sides of the equation4x - 3y’ = -\sin(x + y) -\sin(x + y)y’Distribute -sin(x + y)\sin(x + y)y’ - 3y’ = -\sin(x + y) - 4xRelocate y’ terms to one side(\sin(x + y) - 3)y’ = -\sin(x + y) - 4xIsolate y’y’ = \frac{-\sin(x + y) - 4x}{\sin(x + y) - 3}Solve for y’
Implicit Differentiation Reminders

Before using implicit differentiation, determine if the dependent variable can be isolated and the derivative taken explicitly.
Any derivative involving the dependent variable must use the Chain Rule.
Any derivative involving a product of the independent and dependent variables requires the Product Rule.
Any derivative involving a quotient of the independent and dependent variables requires the Quotient Rule.

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Derivatives/Insta.title: Instantaneous Rate of Change, or the Derivative
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Derivatives/Insta.content:
Instantaneous Rate of Change, or the Derivative
The instantaneous rate of change at a point is equal to the derivative. It can be found by by the difference quotient:
\lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(a+h)-f(a)}{h}
Conceptually, we can think of this as the average rate of change as the distance between the points approaches 0.
Slope of a Tangent Line
The slope of a tangent line is equal to the instantaneous rate of change at that point. A overall curve will have many tangent lines and many different instant rates of change.

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Derivatives/Mean-.title: The Mean Value Theorem
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Derivatives/Mean-.content:
The Mean Value Theorem


                  
                  The Mean Value Theorem 
                  
                

Let f be continuous on the interval [a, b] and differentiable on the interval (a, b). If two points at x = a and x = b are joined by a secant line, then there must exist at least one point, c, in between them, such that the tangent line at c has the same slope as the secant line.
f'(c)= \frac{f(b) - f(a)}{b - a}



In other words, if a function is both continuous and differentiable, then at some moment the instantaneous rate of change must equal the average rate of change.
Another way to think of this is that there is at least one point where the tangent line is parallel to the secant line.
Transclude of Rolle's-Theorem


                  
                  AP Test Tip 
                  
                

In order to earn full points on the FRQ, you must check these conditions to use the MVT:

Confirm that the function is continuous and differentiable on the interval
Find the average rate of change on [a, b]
Make a conclusion stating the name “MVT” in your reasoning




Examples


                  
                  Sample Problem 
                  
                

Let g(x) be a twice differentiable function such that g(3)=6 and g(6)=3. Show that there must be a value c for 3 < c < 6 such that g'(c) = -1.
The function is differentiable, so it is continuous. The average rate of change is \frac{g(6) - g(3)}{6 - 3}=\frac{3-6}{6-3}=\frac{-3}{3}=-1
By the MVT, there must be a value c where g'(c) = -1.

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Derivatives/Optim.title: Optimization Problems
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Derivatives/Optim.content:
Optimization Problems
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
Optimization problems are attempts to find the Extrema of various functions described in terms of one or more variables. I will focus on multivariable ones.
Multivariable Optimization Problems
The first step is to find the critical points, which is described below:


                  
                  Critical Points 
                  
                

When the Partial Derivatives are all 0
f_{x} = 0, f_{y} = 0, \dots
a point (x_{0}, y_{0}) is a critical point of z = f(x,y).
In space, this means that the Tangent Plane to the graph z = f(x,y) is horizontal.


The difficulty is that critical points don’t always have to be minimums or maximums, as they would have to be in single variable functions. This is because they can be Saddle Points. Therefore, the possibilities for critical points are

local minimums
local maximums
Saddle Points

In lower dimensions, extrema can be conceptualized as occurring at the very peak of a hill or mountain where it levels out.

References
ocw.mit.edu/courses/18-02sc-multivariable-calculus-fall-2010/resources/clip-optimization-problem/

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Derivatives/Rolle.title: Rolle's Theorem
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Derivatives/Rolle.content:
Rolle’s Theorem


                  
                  Rolle's Theorem 
                  
                

Let f be continuous on the interval [a, b] and differentiable on the interval (a, b). If f(a) = f(b), then there is a number, c, between a and b such that f'(c) = 0.




                  
                  Warning
                  
                

Note: This is a specific case of the MVT.

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Derivatives/Rules.title: Chain Rule
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Derivatives/Rules.content:
Chain Rule
The Chain Rule is applied to find the derivative of a composite function y = f(g(x)).
Chain Rule using Newton’s Notation


                  
                  Chain Rule 
                  
                

If a function g is differentiable at x, and a function f is differentiable at g(x), the the composite function f(g(x)) is differentiable at x and f(g(x))' = f'(g(x) \cdot g'(x) 


In written form, that means the derivative of a composite function is the derivative of the “outside” function, evaluated at the “inside function”, multiplied by the derivative of the “inside function” g’(x).
Chain Rule using Leibnitz’s Notation
For a differentiable function y = f(u) and u = g(x), then \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{dy}{du} \cdot \dfrac{du}{dx}

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Derivatives/Rules.title: Derivative Product Rule
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Derivatives/Rules.content:
Derivative Product Rule
(f \cdot g)' =f \cdot g' + g \cdot f'
Proof
See Proof of the Derivative Product Rule.

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Derivatives/Rules.title: Derivative Quotient Rule
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Derivatives/Rules.content:
Derivative Quotient Rule
Topic: Derivative Rules
For derivatives:
\left(\frac{f}{g}\right)'=\frac{g \cdot f' - f \cdot g'}{g^2}

This is often expressed as “low d high - high d low all over low squared.”
Proof
See Proof of the Derivative Quotient Rule.

Flashcards
What is the derivative of \frac{f}{g}? :?: (\frac{f}{g})'=\frac{g \cdot f' - f \cdot g'}{g^2}

References

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Derivatives/Rules.title: Derivative Rules
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Derivatives/Rules.content:
Derivative Rules
Constant Rule
\frac{d}{dx}(c) = 0
when c is a constant
The Power Rule

\frac{d}{dx}(x^n)=nx^{n-1}

Constant Multiple Rule

\frac{d}{dx}(cf(x)) = c\frac{d}{dx}f(x)

Sum and Difference of Two Functions Rule

\frac{d}{dx}(f(x) \pm g(x)) = \frac{d}{dx}f(x) \pm \frac{d}{dx}g(x)

Product Rule

(f \cdot g)' =f \cdot g' + g \cdot f'

Transclude of Derivative-Quotient-Rule#^6b7beb

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Derivatives/Secon.title: Second Derivative Test
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Derivatives/Secon.content:
Second Derivative Test
The second derivative test is a method for determining whether a Critical Point is a maximum or minimum.
Single-Variable

If f'(c) = 0 and f''(c) < 0, then f has a local maximum at x = c.
If f'(c) = 0 and f''(c) > 0, then f has a local minimum at x = c.

Put in words instead of math,

If f is concave down around a critical point, then that critical point is a maximum.
If f is concave up around a critical point, then that critical point is a maximum.

Multi-variable
In multiple dimensions, the second derivative test becomes more complicated. We will focus on Multivariable Functions with two inputs, x and y. First we find the critical points. Let one such critical point be P=(x_{0}, y_{0}). We then calculate the three second Partial Derivatives and evaluate them P, denoting the resulting values as A, B, \text{ and } C:
A = (f_{xx})_{0}; \quad B = (f_{xy})_{0}; \quad C = (f_{yy})_{0}
Then, we apply the actually test:


                  
                  Second Derivative Test in Three Dimensions 
                  
                































AC - B^{2} is _ConditionMeaning> 0A > 0 or C > 0(x_{0}, y_{0}) is a minimum point> 0A < 0 or C < 0(x_{0}, y_{0}) is a maximum point< 0None(x_{0}, y_{0}) is a saddle point= 0NoneInconclusive




                  
                  Example Application of the Second Derivative Test 
                  
                

Find the critical points of w = 12x^{2} + y^{3} - 12xy and determine their type: minimum, maximum, or saddle.
Solution:
First, we calculate the Partial Derivatives:
w_{x} = 24x - 12y; \quad w_{y} = 3y^{2}-12x; \quad A=w_{xx} = 24; \quad B=w_{xy} = -12; \quad C=w_{yy} = 6y
Then we solve the simultaneous equations w_{x} = 0 and w_{y} = 0: \begin{array}{lcl} w_{x} = 0 \\ w_{y} = 0 \end{array} \Rightarrow \begin{array}{lcl} y = 2x \\ y^{2} = 4x\end{array} \Rightarrow 4x^{2} = 4x \Rightarrow x = 0, 1 \Rightarrow \boxed{\begin{array}{lcl}(x, y) = (0, 0)\\ (x,y) = (1,2)\end{array}}
This gives us our critical points (0,0) and (1, 2). Substituting into AC - B^{2} = 144y - 144 gives us:

(0, 0): AC - B^{2} = -144 < 0, so it is a saddle point
(1, 2): AC - B^{2} = 144 and A > 0, so it is a minimum point



The test is slightly more complicated than the two-dimensional equivalent, but not terribly difficult.

References
1802SC - Multivariable Calculus; Session 30

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Derivatives/Speci.title: Derivatives of Inverse Functions
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Derivatives/Speci.content:
Derivatives of Inverse Functions
First, review the Properties of Inverse Functions:
Transclude of Properties-of-Inverse-Functions
For function f with a point (a, b) on its graph, its inverse f^{-1} has the corresponding point (b, a) on its graph. The ordered pair has been reversed. Additionally, the slope of f^-1 at point (b, a) is the reciprocal of the slope of f at (a, b).


                  
                  The Derivative of an Inverse Function f^{-1'}(b)
                  
                

When f^{-1} is differentiable and f'(f^{-1}(b)) \neq 0, the derivative of f^{-1} is
f^{-1'}(b)= \frac{1}{f'(f^{-1}(b))}
This can also be applied as: f^{-1'}(b)= \frac{1}{f'(a)}


References

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Derivatives/Speci.title: Derivatives of Logarithms and Exponential Functions
Derivatives of Trigonometric Functions
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Derivatives/Speci.content:
Derivatives of Trigonometric Functions
These are the derivatives of common trig functions:

\frac{d}{dx}\sin(x)= \cos(x)
\frac{d}{dx}\cos(x) = -\sin(x)
\frac{d}{dx}\tan(x)=\sec^2(x)
\frac{d}{dx}\csc(x)=-\csc(x)\cot(x)
\frac{d}{dx}\sec(x)=\sec(x)\tan(x)
\frac{d}{dx}\cot(x)=-\csc^2(x)

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Derivatives/Speci.title: Inverse Trigonometric Derivatives

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Integrals/Integra.title: Integral Kernel
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Integrals/Integra.content:
Integral Kernel
Topic: General Transformations
The kernel of a integral transformation is the piece that maps a function from its original function space into another function space via integration.  The function K(s, t) in the following is called the kernel:
T\{ f(t)\} = \int\limits_{t_{1}}^{t_{2}}{K(s, t) f(t)dt}
The most famous example is the Laplace Transform.

References
A First Course in Differential Equations with Modeling Applications; Chapter 7.1

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Integrals/Integra.title: Integral of a Constant
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Integrals/Integra.content:
Integral of a Constant
Topic: Integrals


                  
                  Integral of a Constant 
                  
                

If a function f  is integrable on the closed interval [a, b] and f(x) = c where c is a constant, then \int_{a}^{b}f(x)dx = \int_{a}^{b}cdx = c(b-a)


Graphically this makes sense because the area under a straight line is just a rectangle of width (b - a) and height c.


                  
                  Example of Constant Integral: 
                  
                

Q. Evaluate the integral \int_{-3}^{4}2dx.
A. A. \int_{-3}^{4}2dx=2(4 - (-3)) = 14
A. 
A.


Zero Integral Rule


                  
                  Zero Integral Rule 
                  
                

If a function f is integrable on the closed interval [a, b], then 
\int_{a}^{a}f(x)dx = 0


The zero integral rule also makes sense graphically, because there is no area accumulated when there is only a starting point.
The sum of the integrals \int_{a}^{b}f(x)dx and \int_{b}^{c}f(x)dx is accumulating the area from the a to b and b to c, which is the same as the accumulation from a to c, or \int_{a}^{c}f(x)dx.
Additivity Integral Rule


                  
                  Additivity Integral Rule 
                  
                

If a function f is integrable on the closed interval [a, c] and a < b < c, then \int_{a}^{b}f(x)dx + \int_{b}^{c}f(x)dx = \int_{a}^{c}f(x)dx


Order of Integration Rule
Interchanging the limits of integration reverses the sign of the definite integral.


                  
                  Order of Integration Rule 
                  
                

If a function f is integrable on the closed interval [a, b], then \int_{a}^{b}f(x)dx = -\int_{b}^{a}f(x)dx


Integral Sum and Difference Rule
The integral of a sum/differences equals the sum/difference of the integrals.


                  
                  Integral of the Sum and Difference of Two Functions Rule 
                  
                

If two functions f and g are integrable on the closed interval [a, b], then 
\int_{a}^{b}[f(x) \pm g(x)]dx = \int_{a}^{b}f(x)dx \pm \int_{a}^{b}g(x)dx


Integral Constant Rule
Finally, a constant factor can be factored out of an integral.


                  
                  Constant Multiple Rule 
                  
                

If a function f is integrable on the closed interval [a, b] and k is a constant, then
\int_{a}^{b}kf(x)dx = k\int_{a}^{b}f(x)dx

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Integrals/Integra.title: Integrals
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Integrals/Integra.content:
Integrals
Integrals are a huge part of Calculus, and are generally thought of as finding the area beneath some curve.
Subtopics

where file.name = this.file.name

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Integrals/Integra.title: Integration by Parts
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Integrals/Integra.content:
Integration by Parts
Topic: Integrals
Integration by parts is one of the fundamental techniques for evaluating integrals that have two functions multiplied together.
\int{udv}=uv - \int{vdu}

This could also be written as:
\int\limits_{}^{}{(u(x)v'(x))dx} = u(x)v(x) - \int\limits_{}^{}{(v(x)u'(x))dx}
Guidelines

Assign a u and a dv
du should be a “simpler” function than u
dv should be the “most complicated” function



                  
                  Integration by Parts Example 
                  
                

What is \int\limits_{}^{}{(x \sin{x})dx}?
Let u = x, and dv = \sin{x}dx. Then, du = dx and v = -\cos{x}. Therefore, by integration by parts:
\int\limits_{}^{}{(x \sin{x})dx} = -x \cos{x} - \int\limits_{}^{}{(-\cos{x})dx}= -x \cos{x} + \sin{x} + C



Flashcards
References

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Integrals/Integra.title: Integration by Substitution
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Integrals/Integra.content:
Integration by Substitution
Topic: Integrals
Integration by substitution is a process for evaluating integrals that contain expressions in a form that resembles the chain rule.
I think it is easiest to explain with an example:


                  
                  Find the Indefinite Integral 
                  
                

What is the indefinite integral of (x^{3}+x)^{5}(3x^{2}+1)?


let u = x^{3}+x
then \frac{du}{dx}=3x^{2}+1, so dx=\frac{du}{3x^{2}+1}
therefore
\int{(x^{3}+x)^{5}(3x^{2}+1)} = \int{(u)^{5}(3x^{2}+1) \frac{du}{3x^{2}+1}}=\int{u^{5}du}
The \int{x^{n}}dx = \frac{x^{n+1}}{n+1}, so:
\int{u^{5}du}=\frac{u^{6}}{6}+C
since u = x^{3}+x, \frac{u^{6}}{6}+C=\frac{(x^{3}+x)^{6}}{6}+C
This process is called u-substitution, because you substitute u for a piece of the larger integral. It is very useful.


                  
                  Steps to Integrate by Substitution 
                  
                


Determine a suitable value for u = g(x), or something that’s derivative is present in the integral
Substitute u for the expression and dx=\frac{du}{g'(x)}
Integrate with respect to u
Replace u by g(x)



Proof
The chain rule states that:
\frac{d}{dx}F(g(x))=F'(g(x))*g'(x)
If F is an anti-derivative of f, then F' = f, so:
F'(g(x))*g'(x)=f(g(x))*g'(x)
By The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus,
\int{f'(g(x))*g'(x)}=\int{\frac{d}{dx}F(g(x))}=F(g(x))+C
If we make the substitution that u=g(x), then
F(g(x))=F(u)+C=\int{F'(u)du}=\int{f(u)du}
Special Case
Sometimes, you do a u-substitution but are left with an extra factor of x. In that case, it is sometimes possible to solve the equation u=g(x) for x in terms of u, and then replace the extra factor of x with that expression to get an integral that we can evaluate. Here is an example:


                  
                  Question
                  
                

Evaluate \int{x\sqrt{2x+1}dx}


Let u=2x+1, and dx=\frac{du}{2}, then:
\int{x\sqrt{2x+1}dx}=\frac{1}{2}\int{x\sqrt{u}du}
Which contains an extra factor of x. However, we can solve for x in u = 2x+1 to find that x = \frac{u-1}{2}. Therefore,
\frac{1}{2}\int{x\sqrt{u}du}=\frac{1}{4}\int{u-1\sqrt{u}du}=\frac{1}{4}\int{u^\frac{3}{2}-u^\frac{1}{2}du}
=\frac{1}{4}(\frac{2}{5}u^{\frac{5}{2}}-\frac{2}{3}u^{\frac{3}{2}})+C
Finally, you substitute back u = 2x+1, which I leave as an exercise for the reader.

Flashcards
References

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Integrals/Riemann.title: Riemann Sum
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Integrals/Riemann.content:
Riemann Sum


                  
                  Riemann Sum 
                  
                

A_{n}=f(x_{1}^{\star})\Delta x_{1} + f(x_{2}^{\star}) \Delta x_{2}... f(x_{n}^{\star}) \Delta x_{n}
= \sum_{k=1}^{n}f(x_{k}^{\star})\Delta x_{k}



If we wrap a Riemann sum in the \lim_{\text{ max } \Delta x_k \to 0}, we get the actual area under the curve. The largest rectangle is 0. Because that is ugly to write, we have a simpler notation, the definite integral:
A=\int_{a}^{b}f(x)dx
Writing a Riemann Sum
To approximate an integral with a right Riemann sum use:
\sum_{k=1}^{n} f(a+\Delta x_{i)\Delta}x
$$ where $\Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n}$.

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Integrals/Solids-.title: Arc Length
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Integrals/Solids-.content:
Arc Length
Topic: Integrals
The arc length of a function is the length of the path that the function takes between two points. It can be found using integral calculus.


                  
                  Arc Length Formula 
                  
                

If f' is continuous on [a, b], then the arc length of the curve y = f(x) from the point A = (a, f(a)) to the point B = (b, f(b)) is the value of the integral
L = \int_{a}^{b}{\left(\sqrt{1 + \left(\frac{dy}{dx}\right)^{2}}\right) dx}
Or, for functions defined as x=g(y):
L = \int_{c}^{d}{\left(\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{dx}{dy}\right)^{2}}\right)dy}



This is sometimes also expressed in differential form, where s is the arc length function:
ds = \sqrt{dx^{2} + dy^{2}} = \sqrt{1 + (dy/dx)^{2}}dx
Proof
The distance of a straight line between two points is given by d = \sqrt{(\Delta x)^{2} + (\Delta y)^{2}}. This is a rough starting point for finding the arc length, a basic approximation. Let the two points defining this line be P_{i} and P_{i+1}. A shorthand for the distance formula is then written as L = \left|P_{i-1} \ P_{i}\right|.
If you take a series of points P_{i}=(x_{i}, y_{i}) along the domain (a, b) and sum the distance between each, you get a better approximate. As you take more and more of these points, the approximation gets more accurate.
L \approx \sum\limits_{i={1}}^{n}|P_{i-1} \ P_{i}|
The exact length is:
L = \lim\limits_{n\to\infty}\sum\limits_{i={1}}^{n}|P_{i-1} \ P_{i}|
This is true because as the distance between P_{i-1} and P_{i} approaches 0, the function is more and more accurately represented by a straight line.
Now, as n \to \infty, it can be said that \Delta x = dx and \Delta y = dy, so the function can be rewritten as:

L = \lim\limits_{n \to \infty}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}{\sqrt{(dx)^{2}+(dy)^{2}}}

Under the radical, if you multiply dy by \frac{dx}{dx}, you get:
L &= \lim\limits_{n \to \infty}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}{\sqrt{(dx)^{2}+\left(dy\times \frac{dx}{dx}\right)^{2}}} \\
&= \lim\limits_{n \to \infty}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}{\sqrt{(dx)^{2} \times \left(1 + \left(\frac{dy}{dx}\right)^{2}\right)}} \\
&= \lim\limits_{n \to \infty}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}{\sqrt{\left(1 + \left(\frac{dy}{dx}\right)^{2}\right)}} \times dx
\end{aligned}$$

But that just happens to be the definition of an integral!

$$L = \int\limits_{a}^{b}{\sqrt{1 + \left(\frac{dy}{dx}\right)^{2}}}dx$$
QED.
***

## References
tutorial.math.lamar.edu/classes/calcii/arclength.aspx
Calculus 2: Section 6.2/6.3

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Integrals/Solids-.title: Disk Method
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Integrals/Solids-.content:
Disk Method
Topic: Integrals
The disk method is used to calculate the volume of a Solid of Revolution.


                  
                  Volume by Disks for Rotation about the x-axis 
                  
                

V = \int_{a}^{b}{dV} = \int_{a}^{b}{\pi (f(x))^{2}dx}



Where it comes from
If you have a function f(x) that you are revolving around the x-axis for a \leq x \leq b, you have a solid of revolution.
Consider a thin vertical strip with thickness \Delta x and height y = f(x) and consider revolving this thin strip around the x-axis. This strip generates a thin circular disk or cylinder with radius y = f(x) and thickness \Delta x, which has volume:

\Delta V = \pi y^{2} \Delta x = \pi (f(x))^{2} \Delta x

The full volume of this solid of revolution is given by summing the volumes of these thin circular disks between a and b.
Another way of thinking about it is simply an application of Volume by Slicing where A(x) = \pi[R(x)]^{2}

References

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Integrals/Solids-.title: Feynmann Review - Solid of Revolution
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Integrals/Solids-.content:
Feynmann Review - Solid of Revolution
Transclude of Drawing-2023-08-13-18.17.06.excalidraw
Let’s say that you have an ice-cream cone, and you want to find out how much ice-cream you can fit in it. You don’t quite know the formula for the volume of a cone, so you want to try and figure it out on your own.
Well first, let’s think about what a cone really is. It’s a bunch of circles stacked on top of each other, right? You could split a cone into a series of distinct circles. Of course, if you only had like 2 or 3 circles, it wouldn’t really look much like a cone. But if you had 10 or 20 or 1000, it would look a lot like a cone.
Okay, so we know how to find the volume of a cylinder, right? It’s just the area of the circle times the height, or \pi r^{2} h. So then the volume of the total cone is just all of the cylinders added up one after the other.
But how do you find the radius of each circle? Well if we take the cone and lay it on its side and take a cross-section, what we get is a triangle. If you put the tip of that triangle at the origin of the coordinate plane, then the triangle has three vertices:

0,0
h,0
h,r
where h is the height of the cone and r is the largest radius.
Then, the radius at any point along the cone is just the height of the line between 0,0 and h,r at that point.

The slope of a line, or rise over run, is basically how steep a line is, and you can find it from two different points on the line. In this case, we have one point at (0,0), basically the start, and another one at (h, r), so the rise is h over a distance of r. Thus, the slope of the line is \frac{h}{r}.
Then, the radius at any point x along the cone is just \frac{h}{r} \cdot x. So, the volume of one of those discs we are using to make up our cone has a volume of \pi (\frac{h}{r}x)^{2} \cdot t, where t is the thickness. However, if you were to imagine taking infinitely many discs, then each one would have to be smaller and smaller, so t would get closer and closer to being 0.
But how do you add together all of those infinitely many discs? We have an operation in math called integrating that does exactly that! Basically, you divide up a big problem into a whole bunch of little ones, and then add them together.
In our case, we could write the volume of the cone as V = \int_{0}^{h}{\pi \left(\frac{r}{h}x\right)}{^2}dx 
which basically means all of the circles with a thickness of dx between 0 and h.
See my explanation of integrals here Feynmann Review - Integrals, but essentially doing out the math you get the formula for volume of cone is
\boxed{V = \frac{\pi r^{2}h}{3}}

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Integrals/Solids-.title: Shell Method
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Integrals/Solids-.content:
Shell Method
Topic: Integrals
The shell method is used to calculate the volume of a Solid of Revolution when the Disk Method or Washer Method is not applicable. It considers slices of the object that are parallel to the axis of rotation, rather than perpendicular as is done in the Disk and Washer method.
The technique fundamentally works by decomposing a solid of revolution into cylindrical shells.
The formula is:


                  
                  Shell Method 
                  
                

\begin{aligned} &V = \int_{a}^{b}(2\pi \times x \times f(x))dx \\ \text{ OR } \\ &V = \int_{c}^{d}(2\pi \times y \times f(y))dy \\ \end{aligned}


Where it comes from
Consider a region in the plane that is divided into thin vertical strips or rectangles, much like a Riemann sum. If each vertical strip is revolved about the y-axis, we form a cylindrical shell. It is like an empty tin can with the top and bottom removed. This cylindrical shell has a volume that is approximately equal to a rectangular slab with thickness \Delta x, height equal to the function at \Delta x, and circumference equal to 2\pi r. The volume is therefore:
\Delta V = \text{circumference} \times \text{height} \times \text{thickness} = 2\pi x \cdot f(x) \cdot \Delta x
As \Delta x \to 0 in the limit, the volume becomes more and more accurate.
The full volume is given by:
V = \int\limits_{a}^{b}{dV} = \int\limits_{a}^{b}{2\pi x f(x) dx}

References

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Integrals/Solids-.title: Surface Area of Solid of Revolution
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Integrals/Solids-.content:
Surface Area of Solid of Revolution
Topic: Integrals
The surface area of a solid generated by revolving a function around an axis can be found using a variation of the Arc Length formula.


                  
                  Surface Area of Solid of Revolution Defined by function of x
                  
                

If the function f(x) \geq 0 is continuously differentiable on [a, b], the area of the surface generated by revolving the graph of y = f(x) about the x-axis is
A = \int\limits_{a}^{b}{\left(2\pi f(x)\times\sqrt{1 + (f'(x))^{2}}\right)dx}



One way of thinking about this formula is the circumference of the circle formed by revolution times the length of the circle.


                  
                  Surface Area of Solid of Revolution Defined by function of y
                  
                

A = 2\pi\int\limits_{c}^{d}{\left(g(y)\times\sqrt{1 + (g'(y))^{2}}\right)dy}



References

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Integrals/Solids-.title: Volume by Slicing
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Integrals/Solids-.content:
Volume by Slicing
Topic: Calculus


                  
                  Volume by Slicing 
                  
                

The volume of a solid, integrable cross-sectional area A(x) from x = a to x = b is the integral from a to b, V = \int\limits_{a}^{b}{A(x)dx}



Consider an object with a clearly defined cross-sectional area A(x) perpendicular to the x-axis (or y-axis, A(y)). The volume of this object is the sum of all of the slices from its start, a, to end, b. The object below is an example.


References
Calculus 2, Chapter 6.1

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Integrals/Solids-.title: Washer Method
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Integrals/Solids-.content:
Washer Method
Topic: Integrals
The washer method is very similar to the Disk Method. It is used for finding the volume of more complex bodies of revolution, specifically those in which the body has a hole in it.


                  
                  Volume by Washer for Rotation about the x-axis 
                  
                

V = \pi\int\limits_{a}^{b}{\left([R(x)]^{2} - [r(x)]^{2}\right)dx}



References

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Integrals/Transla.title: Translations on the $S$-axis for Laplace Transforms
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Integrals/Transla.content:
Translations on the S-axis for Laplace Transforms
Topic: General Transformations
The output of a Laplace Transform can be shifted from F(s) \to F(s - a) by multiplying the input function f(t) by e^{at}:


                  
                  Translation Theorem 
                  
                

If \mathscr{L}\{f(t)\} = F(s) and a is any real number, then \mathscr{L}\{e^{at} f(t)\} = F(s-a)




                  
                  Example 1: Translation 
                  
                

The \mathscr{L}\{e^{5t}t^{3}\} is given by the above theorem and this definition: ^f7deec. Together, it yields \mathscr{L}\{e^{5t}t^{3}\} = \mathscr{L}\{t^{3}\}|_{s\to s-5} = \frac{6}{(s-5)^{4}}



References

Topic: General Transformations
Translations on the S-axis for Laplace Transforms
The output of a Laplace Transform can be shifted from F(s) \to F(s - a) by multiplying the input function f(t) by e^{at}:


                  
                  Translation Theorem 
                  
                

If \mathscr{L}\{f(t)\} = F(s) and a is any real number, then \mathscr{L}\{e^{at} f(t)\} = F(s-a)




                  
                  Example 1: Translation 
                  
                

The \mathscr{L}\{e^{5t}t^{3}\} is given by the above theorem and this definition: ^f7deec. Together, it yields \mathscr{L}\{e^{5t}t^{3}\} = \mathscr{L}\{t^{3}\}|_{s\to s-5} = \frac{6}{(s-5)^{4}}

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Jacobian.title: Jacobian
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Jacobian.content:
Jacobian
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
The Jacobian is a scaling factor for a Change of Variables in Double Integrals. It is given by
J = \frac{\partial(u,v)}{\partial(x,y)} = \det \begin{bmatrix} u_{x} & u_{y} \\ v_{x} & v_{y}\end{bmatrix}
Using the Jacobian, we can write a change in area from going from the xy-coordinate system to the uv one as
dudv = |J|dxdy


                  
                  Example 1: Jacobian for Polar Coordinates 
                  
                

In polar coordinates, x = r \cos{(\theta)} and y = r \sin{(\theta)}. The Jacobian for the change of variables from (x, y) to (r, \theta) is found by
\frac{\partial(x, y)}{\partial(r, \theta)} = \begin{vmatrix}x_{r} & x_{\theta} \\ y_{r} & y_{\theta}\end{vmatrix} = \begin{vmatrix}\cos{(\theta)} & -r \sin{(\theta)} \\ \sin{(\theta)} & r \cos{(\theta)}\end{vmatrix} = r So dxdy = |r| dr d \theta.




                  
                  The Jacobian Works Both Ways 
                  
                

Once you’ve calculated the Jacobian, and the corresponding functions, you can go either way using it. Just compute the easiest one!




                  
                  The Jacobian Isn't Constant 
                  
                

The Jacobian is not always a constant. It can be, but most of the time, the scaling factor will depend on the variables. For the example of polar coordinates, the further out you get, the more you scale by.


Tensor Formulation
In Tensor Calculus, the Jacobian is defined as
J_{i}^{i'} = \frac{\partial Z^{i'}}{\partial Z^{i}}
This can be expanded into a matrix representation, such that (for two dimensions) J_{i}^{i'} = \begin{vmatrix}\frac{\partial Z^{1'}}{\partial Z^{1}}  & \frac{\partial Z^{1'}}{\partial Z^{2}} \\ \frac{\partial Z^{2'}}{\partial Z^{1}} & \frac{\partial Z^{2'}}{\partial Z^{2}}\end{vmatrix}
One example is: Transclude of Jacobian-for-Affine-Coordinates#jacobian-for-affine-coordinates

References
1802SC - Multivariable Calculus - Session 54

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Limits/Continuity.title: Continuity
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Limits/Continuity.content:
Continuity 
                  
                

A function f is continuous at c if \lim_{x \to c}f(x) = f(c). To prove continuity, all three of these statements must be true:

f(c) must be defined
\lim_{x \to c}f(x) must exist, and therefore \lim_{x \to c^{-}f(x)}= \lim_{x \to c^+}f(x).
\lim_{x \to c}f(x) must equal f(c)




There are three types of discontinuities:

Removable Discontinuity: appears as holes along the function where the values have been removed
Infinite Discontinuity: the values of the function seem to reach very large numbers due to the presence of an asymptote; appears as a gap between curves
Jump Discontinuity: the function jumps from one value to another, as if the function splits or breaks

Endpoints
Endpoints pose an interesting case. Either the limit from the left or the right will not be possible to determine at an endpoint. In that case, the one-sided limit as the function approaches the endpoint must equal the function value at that endpoint to prove continuity, instead of the overall limit.

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Limits/Function-V.title: Function Value vs Limits
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Limits/Function-V.content:
Function Value vs Limits
An important realization is that f(a) is not the same lim_{x \to a}f(x). For example, if you have a piece-wise function, f(a) could be defined as 10, but as you approach a from either side it would appear to be 3. Make sure to note this difference when working on tests.

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Limits/Intermedia.title: Intermediate Value Theorem
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Limits/Intermedia.content:
One property of continuous functions is the Intermediate Value Theorem or IVT.


                  
                  IVT 
                  
                

If f is continuous on the closed interval [a, b] and k is any value between f(a) and f(b), then there is at least one value c in [a, b] such that f(c) = k.


When using the IVT, remember to always prove Continuity!

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Limits/L'Hopital'.title: L'Hopital's Rule
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Limits/L'Hopital'.content:
L’Hopital’s Rule


                  
                  L'Hopital's Rule 
                  
                

Given functions f and g are differentiable on an interval that contains x = c, but perhaps not differentiable at c. If g' \neq0, L’Hospital’s Rule states:

if lim_{x \to c}f(x) = 0 and lim_{x \to c}g(x) = 0, then lim_{x \to c}\dfrac{f(x)}{g(x)} = lim_{x \to c}\dfrac{f'(x)}{g'(x)}
if lim_{x \to c}f(x) = \pm \infty and lim_{x \to c}g(x) = \pm \infty, then lim_{x \to c}\dfrac{f(x)}{g(x)} = lim_{x \to c}\dfrac{f'(x)}{g'(x)}





Tips


                  
                  Tip
                  
                

If you initially have \infty - \infty , try getting it into a fraction and then see if you get \dfrac{0}{0} or \dfrac{\infty}{\infty} and apply L’Hospital’s rule accordingly.




                  
                  Another Tip 
                  
                

If the original limit is 0^0, \infty^0, or 1^\infty, first set the inside to y and take the ln of both sides. Then compute the same limit, but of ln y this time and afterwards you can go back and figure out y.




                  
                  Product of Functions 
                  
                

\lim_{x\to c}{f \cdot g} = \lim_{x\to c}\left(\frac{f}{\frac{1}{g}}\right) = \lim_{x \to c}\left(\frac{g}{\frac{1}{f}}\right)


Examples


                  
                  Example A 
                  
                

a. Evaluate lim_{x \to 0}\dfrac{sin(x)}{x}:
lim_{x \to 0}\dfrac{sin(x)}{x} = \dfrac{0}{0}
lim_{x \to 0}\dfrac{sin(x)}{x} = lim_{x \to 0}\dfrac{sin(x)'}{x'}=lim_{x \to 0}\dfrac{cos(x)}{1} = cos(0) = 1


                  
                  Example B 
                  
                

b. Show that lim_{x \to 0}(1+x)^{1/x} = e
let y = (1+x)^{1/x}
ln(y) = \frac{1}{x}ln(1+x) = \dfrac{ln(1 + x)}{x}
lim_{x \to 0}ln(y) = lim_{x \to 0}\dfrac{ln(1 + x)}{x} = \dfrac{0}{0}
L’Hospital’s rule applies: lim_{x \to 0}\dfrac{ln(1+x}{x} = lim_{x \to 0}\dfrac{1}{1+x} = 1
lim_{x \to 0} ln(y) = 1, so lim_{x \to 0}y = e

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Limits/Limit-Theo.title: Limit Theorems
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Limits/Limit-Theo.content:
Limit Theorems
Functions are often combined by adding, subtracting, multiplying, dividing, or composing. Each of these operations has a limit theorem related to them for algebraic manipulation. Let f(x) and g(x) be defined for all x \neq a over some open interval containing a. Assume that \lim_{x \to a}f(x) and \lim_{x \to a}g(x) are real numbers.
Limit Rules
Sum Rule
\lim_{x \to a}(f(x)+g(x))=\lim_{x \to a}f(x) + \lim_{x \to a}g(x)
Difference Rule
\lim_{x \to a}(f(x)-g(x))=\lim_{x \to a}f(x)-\lim_{x \to a}g(x)
Product Rule
\lim_{x \to a}f(x)g(x)=\lim_{x \to a}f(x) \cdot \lim_{x \to a}g(x)
Quotient Rule
\lim_{x \to a}\dfrac{f(x)}{g(x)}=\dfrac{\lim_{x \to a}f(x)}{\lim_{x \to a}g(x)}
Composite Functions Rule
\lim_{x \to a}f(g(x))=f(\lim_{x \to a}g(x))

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Limits/Limits-at-.title: Limits at Infinity
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Limits/Limits-at-.content:
Limits at Infinity
When calculating limits, x could approach infinity. This is called examining a function’s end behavior.
When evaluating such a limit, the first step is to take the highest power in the denominator, and divide the numerator and the denominator by that power. Then simplify, and stick in infinity. A whole bunch of pieces will fall away, leaving just a constant.
A faster way is to just take the largest term in the numerator and denominator, and then divide.

Concepts/Math/Calculus/Limits/One-Sided-.title: One-Sided Limits
Concepts/Math/Calculus/Limits/One-Sided-.content:
One-Sided Limits
Sometimes we are unable to determine the overall limit of a function at a specific input valley because the function only exists on one side of that value, like at an endpoint, for example. Or perhaps the limit exists and equals a different value on the right side. In cases like these, one-sided limits are used to describe the behavior of the graph.


                  
                  Left-Sided Limit: 
                  
                

If f(x) becomes arbitraily close to a single number, L, as x approaches c from the left side, the limit of f(x) as x approaches c from the left equals L. Mathematically, this limit is written as If $f(x)$ becomes arbitraily close to a single number, $L$, as $x$ approaches $c$ from the left side, the limit of $f(x)$ as $x$ approaches $c$ from the left equals $L$. Mathematically, this limit is written as lim_{x \to c^-}f(x) = L
If $f(x)$ becomes arbitraily close to a single number, $L$, as $x$ approaches $c$ from the left side, the limit of $f(x)$ as $x$ approaches $c$ from the left equals $L$. Mathematically, this limit is written as

Similarly, the same can be said about the right:


                  
                  Right-Sided Limit: 
                  
                

If f(x) becomes arbitrarily close to a single number, L, as x approaches c from the right side, the limit of f(x) as x approaches c from the right equals L. This limit is written as If $f(x)$ becomes arbitrarily close to a single number, $L$, as $x$ approaches $c$ from the right side, the limit of $f(x)$ as $x$ approaches $c$ from the right equals $L$. This limit is written as lim_{x \to c^+}f(x) = L
