[[A First Course in Differential Equations with Modeling Applications]]; Chapter 1, section 2

Concepts/Math/Differential-Equations/The.title: Inverse Laplace Transform
Isoclines
Concepts/Math/Differential-Equations/The.content:
Isoclines
Isoclines
Topic: Slope Fields
An isocline is a series of lines of slope, used for slope fields.

Concepts/Math/Differential-Equations/The.title: Laplace Transform of Derivatives
Concepts/Math/Differential-Equations/The.content:
Laplace Transform of Derivatives
The Laplace Transform of a derivative is given by: \mathscr{L}\{f^{(n)}(t)\} = s^{n}\mathscr{L}\{f(t)\} - s^{n-1}f(0) - s^{n-2} f'(0) - \dots - f^{(n-1)}(0)
Common Uses
First, denote that F(s) = \mathscr{L}\{f(t)\}. Then,

\mathscr{L}\{f'(t)\} = sF(s) - f(0)
\mathscr{L}\{f''(t)\} = s^{2}F(s) - sf(0) - f'(0)
\mathscr{L}\{f'''(t)\} = s^{3}F(s) - s^{2}f(0) - sf'(0) - f''(0)


References
A First Course in Differential Equations with Modeling Applications; Chapter 7.2.2

Concepts/Math/Differential-Equations/The.title: Laplace Transform
Concepts/Math/Differential-Equations/The.content:
Laplace Transform
Topic: General Transformations


                  
                  Laplace Transform 
                  
                

Let f be a function defined for t \geq 0. Then the integral \mathscr{L}(f(t)) = \int\limits_{0}^{\infty}{e^{-st}f(t)dt}
is the Laplace transform of f, provided that the integral converges.


The function e^{-st} is the Integral Kernel of the transform.


                  
                  Example 1: Easiest Laplace Transform 
                  
                

Evaluate \mathscr{L}\{1\}.
Solution:
\mathscr{L}\{1\} = \int\limits_{0}^{\infty}{e^{-st}dt} = \lim_{b\to\infty} \int\limits_{0}^{b}{e^{-st}dt} = \lim_{b\to\infty} \frac{-e^{-sb} + 1}{s} = \frac{1}{s}
provided that s > 0.




                  
                  Repeated Integration: e^{t}\sin(t)
                  
                

What is the Laplace Transform of f(t) = e^{t} \sin{(t)}?
Solution:
&= \int\limits_{0}^{\infty}{e^{-(s-1)t} \sin{(t)}dt}; \quad \text{I by P: } u = \sin{(t)}, dv = e^{-(s-1)t}dt\\
&= - \frac{1}{s-1} \sin{(t)}e^{-(s-1)t} |_{0}^{\infty} + \frac{1}{s-1}\int\limits_{0}^{\infty}{\cos{(t)}e^{-(s-1)t}dt}\\
&= 0 + \frac{1}{s-1}(- \frac{1}{s-1} \cos{(t)}e^{-(s-1)t}|_{0}^{\infty}- \frac{1}{s-1} \int\limits_{0}^{\infty}{e^{-(s-1)t} \sin{(t)}dt}) \\
\mathscr{L}\{e^{t} \sin{(t)}\}&= \frac{1}{(s-1)^{2}}- \frac{1}{(s-1)^{2}} \mathscr{L}\{e^{t} \sin{(t)}\}\\
\end{aligned}$$
$$\begin{aligned}\mathscr{L}\{f(t)\} + \frac{1}{(s-1)^{2}} \mathscr{L}\{f(t)\} &= \frac{1}{(s-1)^{2}}\\
\mathscr{L}\{f(t)\}\left(1 + \frac{1}{(s-1)^{2}}\right) &= \frac{1}{(s-1)^{2}}\\
\mathscr{L}\{f(t)\} &= \frac{\frac{1}{(s-1)^{2}}}{\frac{1}{(s-1)^{2}} + 1} \\
&= \frac{1}{(s-1)^{2}} \times \frac{(s-1)^{2}}{(s-1)^{2}+1}\\
&=\boxed{ \frac{1}{(s-1)^{2}+1}} \end{aligned}$$
More generally, we can state that: $$\mathscr{L}\{e^{\alpha t} \sin{(\beta t)}\} = \frac{\beta}{(s-\alpha)^{2} + \beta^{2}}$$


Linearity
The Laplace transform is a linear operator, so \mathscr{L}\{\alpha f(t) + \beta g(t)\} = \alpha \mathscr{L}\{f(t)\} + \beta \mathscr{L}\{g(t)\} = \alpha F(s) + \beta G(s)
Common Laplace Transforms

\mathscr{L}\{1\} = \frac{1}{s}
\mathscr{L}\{t^{n}\} \frac{n!}{s^{n+1}} 
\mathscr{L}\{\sin{(kt)}\} = \frac{k}{s^{2}+k^{2}}
\mathscr{L}\{\sinh{(kt)}\} = \frac{k}{s^{2}-k^{2}}
\mathscr{L}\{e^{at}\}=\frac{1}{s-a}
\mathscr{L}\{\cos{(kt)}\} = \frac{s}{s^{2}+k^{2}}
\mathscr{L}\{\cosh{(kt)}\} = \frac{s}{s^{2}-k^{2}}

Inverse
See Inverse Laplace Transform

References
A First Course in Differential Equations with Modeling Applications; Chapter 7.1

Concepts/Math/Differential-Equations/The.title: Modelling Situations with ODEs
Concepts/Math/Differential-Equations/The.content:
Modelling Situations with ODEs
Topic: ODE
Population Dynamics
The rate at which a population grows is proportional to the total popultion:
\frac{dP}{dt} = kP
Radioactive Decay
Similar to population growth, in radioactive decay, the rate at which the nuclei of a substance decays is proportional to the amount of the substance remaining:
\frac{dA}{dt} = kA
Newton’s Law of Cooling/Warming
According to Newton’s Empirical Law of Cooling/Warming, the rate at which the temperature of a body changes is proportional to the difference between the temperature of the body and the ambient temperature. If T_{m} is the temperature of the medium, then:
\frac{dT}{dt} = k(T - T_{m})
Spread of a Disease
A contagious disease depends on the number of people who have contracted the disease, x(t), and the number who haven’t, y(t).
\frac{dx}{dt}= kxy
Draining a Tank - Torricelli’s Law
Take a tank of water. If A_{w} is the area of the upper surface of a body of water, and A_{h} is the area of a hole at the bottom. Suppose the tank is draining through gravity. In free fall, a body acquires a speed of v = \sqrt{2gh}.
The rate of the volume of water leaving the tank is
\frac{dV}{dt} = - A_{h} \sqrt{2gh}
If we want the height of the water at time t, then_
\frac{dh}{dt} = - \frac{A_{h}}{A_{w}} \sqrt{2gh}
Mixing
If you have a large mixing tank, with an initial amount of some solute, like salt, as A, then the rate at which the amount if changing at any given time is
\frac{dA}{dt} = R_{in} -R_{out}
Where R_{in} is the rate of salt per gallon in, and R_{out} is the rate of salt per gallon out.

References
Chapter 1 section 3

Concepts/Math/Differential-Equations/The.title: Slope Fields
Concepts/Math/Differential-Equations/The.content:
Slope Fields
Topic: Differential Equations
A slope field is a way for us to visualize the solution set to a differential equation. It consists of a series of Isoclines.


                  
                  Example Slope Field: \frac{dy}{dx} = 0.2xy
                  
                





References
A First Course in Differential Equations with Modeling Applications; Chapter 2.1.1

Concepts/Math/Differential-Equations/The.title: Solution Vectors
Concepts/Math/Differential-Equations/The.content:
Solution Vectors


                  
                  Solution Vector 
                  
                

A solution vector to a Systems of Linear Differential Equations on any interval I is any column matrix X = \begin{bmatrix}x_{1}(t)  \\ x_{2}(t) \\ \vdots \\ x_{n}(t)\end{bmatrix}
whose entries are differentiable Functions satisfying the system X' = AX + F.
See Linear Independence of Solution Vectors and Fundamental Set of Solutions. Also General Solution.

References
A First Course in Differential Equations with Modeling Applications; Chapter 8.1

Concepts/Math/Differential-Equations/The.title: Solutions of Systems of Homogeneous Linear ODEs with Constant Coefficients
Concepts/Math/Differential-Equations/The.content:
Solutions of Systems of Homogeneous Linear ODEs with Constant Coefficients
Consider the Homogeneous-Systems of Linear Differential Equations X' = AX
where A is a n \times n matrix of constants. The Solution Vectors to this is of the form X = \begin{bmatrix}k_{1} \\ k_{2} \\ \vdots \\ k_{n}\end{bmatrix}e^{\lambda t} = Ke^{\lambda t}
This implies that X' = K \lambda e^{\lambda t} = A K e^{\lambda t} \to AK = \lambda K \to (A - \lambda I)K = 0
(note that we can’t just “divide out” K, because it is a matrix).
The values of \lambda are found using Eigenvectors and Eigenvalues. Specifically, we must solve \det{(A - \lambda I)} = 0
where A is the coefficient matrix and I is the Identity Matrix, e.g. I_{2} = \begin{bmatrix}1  & 0 \\ 0 & 1\end{bmatrix}
We call A - \lambda I the characteristic equation.
Note that the solutions can have distinct real roots, repeated Eigenvalues, or even complex Eigenvalues.
Distinct Real Roots
If we find \lambda_{1}, \lambda_{2}, \dots, \lambda_{n} as our Eigenvalues from the determinant, where each is real and distinct, then we plug those values back into the characteristic equation to find the Eigenvectors. This is done by finding the Reduced Row Echelon Form (RREF).


                  
                  Distinct Real Eigenvalues 
                  
                

What is the general solution of the following system? \frac{dx}{dt} = 2x + 2y; \quad \frac{dy}{dt} = x + 3y
Solution:
First, we rewrite in matrix notation: \textbf{X} = \begin{pmatrix}2 & 2 \\ 1 & 3\end{pmatrix} \textbf{X}'
We identify the constant matrix to be A, and then find the Eigenvalues by solving for \lambda in \det{A - \lambda I}: \det{A - \lambda I} = \begin{vmatrix}2 - \lambda & 2 \\ 1 & 3- \lambda \end{vmatrix} = (2-\lambda)(3-\lambda)-2 = \lambda^{2} - 5 \lambda + 4 = 0
which has roots \lambda_{1} = 1 and \lambda_{2} = 4. We then use these Eigenvalues to find the Eigenvectors. For \lambda_{1}: A - \lambda I = \begin{pmatrix}2-1 & 2 \\ 1 & 3-1\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix}1 & 2 \\ 1 & 2\end{pmatrix} which implies that k_{1} + 2k_{2} = 0 \Longrightarrow k_{1} = -2 k_{2}. We choose k_{2}=1 to get the Eigenvector \begin{pmatrix}-2 \\ 1\end{pmatrix}
For \lambda_{2} = 4: A - \lambda I = \begin{pmatrix}-2 & 2 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix} \Longrightarrow \begin{pmatrix}1 & -1 \\ 0 & 0\end{pmatrix}
which implies that k_{1} = k_{2} so therefore the Eigenvector is \begin{pmatrix}1 \\ 1\end{pmatrix}. The general solution is thus X = c_{1} \begin{pmatrix}-2 \\ 1\end{pmatrix} e^{t} + c_{2} \begin{pmatrix}1 \\ 1\end{pmatrix} e^{4t}



References
A First Course in Differential Equations with Modeling Applications; Chapter 8.2

Concepts/Math/Differential-Equations/The.title: Superposition Principle for Homogeneous Systems of Linear Differential Equations
Concepts/Math/Differential-Equations/The.content:
Superposition Principle for Homogeneous Systems of Linear Differential Equations
Much like the Superposition Principle for Ordinary Differential Equations, the superposition principle for Homogeneous Systems of Linear Differential Equations is defined as:


                  
                  Superposition Principle 
                  
                

Let X_{1}, X_{2}, \dots, X_{k} be a set of Solution Vectors of the homogeneous system X' = AX on an interval I. Then the linear combination X = c_{1}X_{1} + c_{2}X_{2} + \dots + c_{k}X_{k}, where the c_{i}, i = 1, 2, \dots, k are arbitrary constants, is also a solution of the system on the interval.


See Linear Independence of Solution Vectors.

References
A First Course in Differential Equations with Modeling Applications; Chapter 8.1.2

Concepts/Math/Differential-Equations/The.title: Systems of Linear Differential Equations
Concepts/Math/Differential-Equations/The.content:
Systems of Linear Differential Equations
The intersection of Linear Algebra and Differential Equations is solving systems of differential equations. Introductory differential equations classes consider a first-order system of Linear Ordinary Differential Equations, such as \begin{bmatrix}\frac{dx_{1}}{dt} \\ \frac{dx_{2}}{dt} \\ \vdots  \\ \frac{dx_{n}}{dt} \end{bmatrix}  = \begin{bmatrix}a_{11}(t)x_{1} + a_{12}(t)x_{2} + \dots + a_{1n}(t)x_{n} + f_{1}(t) \\ a_{21}(t)x_{1} + a_{22}(t)x_{2} + \dots + a_{2n}(t)x_{n} + f_{2}(t) \\ \vdots \\ a_{n1}(t)x_{1} + a_{n2}(t)x_{2} + \dots + a_{nn}(t)x_{n} + f_{n}(t) \end{bmatrix}
Which is more conveniently written as X' = AX + F  in Matrix Multiplication shorthand. If the system is Homogeneous, then F = 0 and X' = AX.


                  
                  Matrix Shorthand Example 
                  
                

If X = \begin{bmatrix}x  \\ y\end{bmatrix}, then the matrix form of the Homogeneous linear system given by \frac{dx}{dt} = 3x + 4y; \quad \frac{dy}{dt} = 5x - 7y is X' = \begin{bmatrix}3 & 4 \\ 5 & -7\end{bmatrix}X


Transclude of Solution-Vectors#solution-vectors


                  
                  Verification of Solutions 
                  
                

Is X = \begin{bmatrix}1 \\ -1 \end{bmatrix}e^{-2t} = \begin{bmatrix}e^{-2t}  \\ -e^{-2t}\end{bmatrix} a solution to X' = \begin{bmatrix}1 & 3 \\ 5 & 3\end{bmatrix}X?
Solution:
Taking the Derivative, we find that X' = \begin{bmatrix}-2e^{-2t} \\ 2e^{-2t}\end{bmatrix}. Substituting, we find that AX = \begin{bmatrix}1 & 3 \\ 5 & 3 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix}e^{-2t} \\ -e^{-2t}\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}e^{-2t} -3e^{-2t}  \\ 5e^{-2t} - 3e^{-2t}\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}-2e^{-2t}  \\ 2e^{-2t}\end{bmatrix} = X'
If this operation is unclear, see Matrix-Vector Multiplication and Matrix Multiplication.


Transclude of Superposition-Principle-for-Homogeneous-Systems-of-Linear-Differential-Equations#superposition-principle-for-homogeneous-systems-of-linear-differential-equations
Just like in Undetermined Coefficients for Non-Homogeneous ODEs, we say that the general solution to X' = AX + F is X = X_{C} + X_{P}
where X_{C} is the General Solution to the associated Homogeneous system and X_{P} is a specific solution to the non-homogeneous system.
See Solutions of Systems of Homogeneous Linear ODEs with Constant Coefficients

References
A First Course in Differential Equations with Modeling Applications; Chapter 8.1

Concepts/Math/Differential-Equations/The.title: Wronskian
Concepts/Math/Differential-Equations/The.content:
Wronskian
Topic: Differential Equations
The Wronskian is an operator which takes in a set of functions and can be used to evaluate whether or not they are linearly dependent or independent.


                  
                  The Wronskian 
                  
                

Suppose each of the functions f_{1}(x), f_{2}(x), \dots, f_{n}(x) posseses at least n -1 derivatives. The determinant given by
\begin{vmatrix}
f_{1}  & f_{2} & \dots  & f_{n} \\ 
f'_{1} & f'_{2} & \dots & f'_{n} \\ 
\vdots  & \vdots  & \ddots  & \vdots \\ 
f^{(n-1)}_{1} & f^{(n-1)}_{2} & \dots & f^{(n-1)}_{n}
\end{vmatrix}$$




                  
                  Criterion for Linearly Independent Solutions 
                  
                

Let y_{1},y_{2}\dots,y_{n} be n solutions of the Homogeneous Linear Ordinary Differential Equations of the nth order on an interval I. Then the set of solutions is linearly independent and on I if and only if W(y_{1},y_{2},\dots,y_{n}) \neq 0 for every x in the interval.



References
A First Course in Differential Equations with Modeling Applications; Chapter 4, section 4.2

Concepts/Math/Functions/Alpha-Conversion.title: $\alpha$-Conversion
Concepts/Math/Functions/Alpha-Conversion.content:
\alpha-Conversion
Topic: Functions
If you have a function f(x) \Rightarrow x, then \alpha conversion is the process of changing the variable name; e.g. \begin{aligned}y &\Rightarrow y^{2} \\ x &\Rightarrow x^{2}\end{aligned}
is an \alpha-conversion from y to x. These two functions are said to be \alpha-equivalent.

References

Concepts/Math/Functions/Beta-Reduction.title: Beta Reduction
Concepts/Math/Functions/Beta-Reduction.content:
Beta Reduction
Topic: Functions
When evaluating The Lambda Calculus, we apply \beta reduction. It is the equivalent of inputting a value into a function. Basically, you look for every occurrence of the variable and replace it with the input. This is written with the syntax (\lambda x.M)  N\xRightarrow{\beta} M[N/x]
where M[N/x] means to look through M and replace every x with N (N substituted for x).

References

Concepts/Math/Functions/Error-Function.title: Error Function
Concepts/Math/Functions/Error-Function.content:
Error Function
Topic: Functions
The error function is defined by a non elementary integral:
\DeclareMathOperator\erf{erf}
\erf(x) = \frac{2}{\sqrt{\pi}} \int\limits_{0}^{x}{(e^{-t^{2}})dt}
Is is known that \erf(\infty) = 1.
It has a complementary function, very closely related in definition:
\DeclareMathOperator\erfc{erfc}
\erfc(x) = \frac{2}{\sqrt{\pi}} \int\limits_{x}^{\infty}{(e^{-t^{2}})dt}
such that
\erf{x} + \erfc{x} = 1
It emerges somewhat naturally in differential equations.


                  
                  Example of Error Function 
                  
                

Solve the following initial value problem:
\frac{dy}{dx} - 2xy = 2, \quad y(0) = 1
First, we note that the integrating factor is e^{\int\limits_{}^{}{(-2x)dx}} = e^{-x^{2}}. Then, we multiply both sides by this to get
e^{-x^{2}} \frac{dy}{dx} - 2xe^{-x^{2}} = 2e^{-x^{2}} \to \frac{d}{dx}[e^{-x^{2}}y] = 2e^{-x^{2}}
Since indefinite integration of both sides leads to the nonelementary integral seen above, we identify x_{0} = 0 from the IVP and use definite integration over the interval [0, x]:
\int\limits_{0}^{x}{\frac{d}{dt}(e^{-t^{2}}y(t))dt} = 2 \int\limits_{0}^{x}{(e^{-t^{2}})dt}
Which, using the initial condition, yields the solution
y = e^{x^{2}} + 2e^{x^{2}}  \int\limits_{0}^{x}{(e^{-t^{2}})dt}
This can be rewritten by inserting the factor \frac{\sqrt{\pi}}{\sqrt{\pi}}, yielding the simplified
y = e^{x^{2}}[1 + \sqrt{\pi} \erf(x)]



References
A First Course in Differential Equations with Modeling Applications; Chapter 2, section 3

Concepts/Math/Functions/Exponential-Func.title: Exponential Functions
Concepts/Math/Functions/Exponential-Func.content:
Exponential Functions
Exponentials functions are Functions that increase or decrease at a rate proportional to its size at a given time.
Common examples are:

Population Growth
Half-lives / Radioactive Decay
Temperature Differences

Calculus Definition
The rate of change is proportional to its size, so:
\begin{aligned}
&\frac{dy}{dt}= ky \\
&\frac{dy}{y} = kdt \\
&\int{\frac{1}{y}dy} = \int{kdt} \\
&\ln{|y|} = kt + c \\
&e^{\ln{|y|}} = e^{kt} \times e^{c} \\
& y = \pm e^{c}e^{kt} \\ 
& \boxed{y = Ae^{kt}}
\end{aligned}
The original equation \frac{dy}{dt}=ky could be described as a Separable Differential Equation.

References

Concepts/Math/Functions/Extrema.title: Extrema
Concepts/Math/Functions/Extrema.content:
Extrema
Local Minimums and Maximums
Local (Relative) Maximum—A point, c, is a local (or relative) maximum if f(c) \geq f(x) for all x in a certain interval.
Local (Relative) Minimum—A point, c, is a local (or relative) minimum if f(c) \leq f(x) for all x in a certain interval.
Absolute Minimums and Maximums
Absolute (Global) Maximum—A point, c, is an absolute (or global) maximum if f(c) \geq f(x) for all x in the domain.
Absolute (Global) Minimum—A point, c, is an absolute (or global) minimum if f(c) \leq f(x) for all x in the domain.

Concepts/Math/Functions/Extreme-Value-Th.title: Extreme Value Theorem
Concepts/Math/Functions/Extreme-Value-Th.content:
Extreme Value Theorem


                  
                  Extreme Value Theorem 
                  
                

Let f be continuous on the closed interval [a, b], then f has an absolute minimum and an absolute maximum on [a, b].

Concepts/Math/Functions/Functions.title: Functions
Concepts/Math/Functions/Functions.content:
Functions
A function is a mathematical object which takes in some Set of inputs and returns some output. It can be said to take in a set \mathbf{X} and return a different set \mathbf{Y}, such that each element of \mathbf{X} is assigned to exactly one element of \mathbf{Y}. It is typically denoted by:
y = f(x)
which could be read as “y is equal to a function of x”
A function can be represented graphically by the set of all pairs (x, y=f(x)).
Domain and Range
A function f has some set of values for which it is defined, called the domain. For example, take these two functions:

f(x) = x^{2} has a domain of all real numbers because x^{2} is defined for any input
g(x) = \frac{1}{x} has a domain of all real numbers EXCEPT 0, because division by 0 is undefined

Range is the set of all possible values which y could be in the relation y = f(x). So for example:

h(x) = x has a domain of all real numbers AND a range of all real numbers
\ell(x) = 1 has a range of only (1)

Multivariable Functions
Functions of two or more variables can be written as f(x, y, z, \dots). 1802SC - Multivariable Calculus typically focuses on only two variable functions, f(x,y) for simplicity, although the math can be applied to n dimensions. The basic idea is that f(x, y) gives the altitude z at the point (x, y). This might be useful to represent a plane, saddle, cone, and so on; or the temperature distribution over space.
Transclude of Visualizing-Multivariable-Functions
Examples
f(x) = x^{2} maps each value x to its square. E.g. 2 > 4, 3 > 9.

References
ocw.mit.edu/courses/18-02sc-multivariable-calculus-fall-2010/resources/mit18_02sc_notes_13/
ocw.mit.edu/courses/18-02sc-multivariable-calculus-fall-2010/resources/mit18_02sc_notes_15/

Concepts/Math/Functions/Horizontal-Asymp.title: Horizontal Asymptotes
Concepts/Math/Functions/Horizontal-Asymp.content:
Horizontal Asymptotes

























Horizontal Asymptote RulesExampleLimit GeneralizationIf the numerator has a higher degree than the denominator, then there is no horizontal asymptote.f(x) = \frac{x^{2}+1}{x}For function f(x): lim_{x \to -\infty}f(x) and lim_{x \to \infty}f(x) = \pm \inftyIf the denominator has a higher degree than the numerator, then there is a horizontal asymptote at y = 0.f(x) = \frac{2x}{3x^{2}-12}For function f(x): \lim_{x \to -\infty}f(x)=lim_{x \to \infty}f(x)=0If the numerator and the denominator have the same degree, then the horizontal asymptote is the ratio of the highest power coefficients.f(x)= \frac{x^2-6x+9}{x^{2} -9}For function f(x): limits = a/b

Concepts/Math/Functions/Natural-Log.title: Natural Log
Concepts/Math/Functions/Natural-Log.content:
Natural Log
The natural log is the logarithm with a base of e. It is represented by the symbol \ln.


                  
                  The Natural Log 
                  
                

y = ln(x) = \int\limits_{1}^{x}{\frac{1}{t}dt}



Derivatives
\frac{d}{dx}\ln{x}=\frac{1}{x}
There are two main ways to prove this: using the first principle/limits, and by Implicit Differentiation. I will show the latter, as it is more interesting:
\begin{aligned}
& y = \ln{x} \to e^{y}=x & (1)\\
& \frac{d}{dx}(e^{y}) = \frac{d}{dx}x & \text{ Differentiate Both Sides}\\
& e^{y}\frac{dy}{dx} = 1 & \text{ by Chain Rule} \\
& \frac{dy}{dx}=\frac{1}{e^{y}} & \text{Divide both sides by }e^{y} \\
& \frac{dy}{dx}= \frac{1}{x} & e^{y}=x \text{ by (1)}\\ 
\end{aligned}
Integral
\int{\ln{x}dx}=x\ln{x}-x + C
This comes from an Integration by Parts:
Transclude of Integration-by-Parts#^ae2f1e

















uvu = \ln{x}v = xdu = \frac{1}{x}dxdv = dx
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{}^{}{\ln(x) dx} = \int_{}^{}{u \times dv} \\
& = u \times v - \int_{}^{}{v \times du} \\
& = \ln{x} \times x - \int_{}^{}{x \times \frac{1}{x}dx} \\
& = x\ln{x} - x + C

\end{aligned}

Flashcards
\int{\frac{1}{x}dx=[...]}:?:\ln|x|

References

Concepts/Math/Functions/Properties-of-In.title: Properties of Inverse Functions
Concepts/Math/Functions/Properties-of-In.content:
Properties of Inverse Functions
Invertible functions have the following properties:

One-to-one functions (one input, one output)
Pass the horizontal line test
Are either always increasing or always decreasing on their domains, such as linear functions and cubic functions

The inverse of a function can be found by reflecting the graph over the line y = x.
Finding the inverse of a function algebraically involves reversing the x and y variables. The function can be thought of as f(x) = y, and the inverse as f(y) = x.
The slope of a line tangent to f^{-1} at (y, x) is the reciprocal of the slope of the tangent line to f at (x, y).
If f is differentiable at (x, y), then f^{-1} will be differentiable at (y, x).

Concepts/Math/Functions/Secant.title: Secant
Concepts/Math/Functions/Secant.content:
Secant
Topic: Functions
The secant function is defined as \sec{x} = \frac{1}{\cos{x}}.
Derivative
The derivative of \sec{x} can be found using the Derivative Quotient Rule:
\displaylines{
f(x) = \sec{x} = \frac{1}{\cos{x}} \\
f'(x) = \frac{(\cos{x} \cdot 0) - (1 \cdot -\sin{x})}{\cos^{2}{x}} \\
= \frac{\sin{x}}{\cos{x}}\cdot \frac{1}{\cos{x}} \\
= \tan{x} \cdot \sec{x}
}
Integral
The integral of \sec{x} can be found with clever manipulation and u-sub:
\displaylines{
\int{\sec{x}} \\
=\int{\sec{x}\times \frac{\sec{x} + \tan{x}}{\sec{x} + \tan{x}}} \text{ by multiplicative identity} \\
= \int{\frac{\sec^{2}{x}+\sec{x}\tan{x}}{\sec{x}+\tan{x}}}\\
u=\sec{x} + \tan{x}; \quad \frac{du}{dx}=\sec{x}\tan{x}+\sec^{2}{x}\\
=\int{\frac{1}{u}du}=\ln{|u|}+C\\
=\ln{|\sec{x}+\tan{x}|} + C
}

Flashcards
References
We take the derivative of Tangent and antiderivative of Natural Log.

Concepts/Math/Functions/Simply-Typed-Lam.title: Simply Typed Lambda Calculus
Concepts/Math/Functions/Simply-Typed-Lam.content:
Simply Typed Lambda Calculus
Topic: Functions
The Lambda Calculus is very powerful, but sometimes produces nonsensical results. For example, you might abstract a not function as \text{not} = \lambda b. \text{if } b \text{ then False else True}, but this falls apart as soon as you input a number instead of a Boolean for b. We thus construct a very simple type system to ensure validity. Let, for example, \text{Bool} and \text{Num[ber]} be the types. We then say that each \lambda-abstraction is a mapping as \lambda x . M : A \to B,
where A and B are types. This is alternately (and better) written as \lambda x^{A} . M, \quad M : B
We then state that we can only beta reduce when (\lambda x^{A} . M) N : A.
Our problem with the not function is then resolved simply by stating that b : \text{Bool}: \text{not} = \lambda b^\text{Bool}. \text{if } b \text{ then False else True}

References

Concepts/Math/Functions/Tangent.title: Tangent
Concepts/Math/Functions/Tangent.content:
Tangent
Topic: Common Functions
Tangent is one of the three core trigonometric functions, along with Cosine and Sine.

It can also be defined as \tan{\theta} = \frac{\sin{\theta}}{\cos{\theta}}
Derivative
The derivative of tangent is found using the Quotient Rule
\displaylines{
f(x) = \tan{x} \\
f(x) = \frac{\sin{x}}{\cos{x}} \\
f'(x) = \frac{(\cos{x} \times \cos{x}) - (\sin{x}\times-\sin{x})}{\cos^{2}{x}}\\
=\frac{\cos^{2}{x}+\sin^{2}{x}}{\cos^{2}{x}}=\frac{1}{\cos^{2}{x}}
}
\int{\sec^{2}{x}dx}=[...]:?:\tan{x}

Integral
The integral of tangent is found using u-substitution:
\int{\tan{x}dx}=\int{\frac{\sin{x}}{\cos{x}}} \\
\text{let } u = \cos{x} \\
\frac{du}{dx}=-\sin{x} \to dx = \frac{-du}{\sin{x}} \\
\int{\frac{\sin{x}}{u}\cdot \frac{-du}{\sin{x}}} \\
-\int{\frac{1}{u} \cdot du} \\
=-\ln{\vert u \vert} + C \\
= -\ln{\vert \cos(x) \vert} + c \\
\text{OR } \\\ln{|\sec{x}|} + C
}
\int{\tan{x}dx}=[...]:?:\ln|\sec{x}|

\tan{}^2
Tangent can, of course, be squared. It is sometimes useful to derive or integrate \tan^2.
Derivative
\begin{aligned}
& y = \tan^{2}{x}\\
& \frac{dy}{dx}= 2(\tan(x)) \times \sec^{2}(x)& \text{Chain Rule} \\
& = \boxed{2\tan(x)\sec^{2}(x)}
\end{aligned}
Integral
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{}^{}{ \tan^{2}(x) \times dx} = \int_{}^{}{ \frac{\sin^{2}(x)}{\cos^{2}(x)}\times dx} \\
& \int_{}^{}{\frac{1 - \cos^{2}(x)}{\cos^{2}(x)} dx} = \int_{}^{}{\sec^{2}(x)\times  dx} - \int_{}^{}{1 \times dx} \\
& \boxed{= \tan{x} - x + C}
\end{aligned}
\arctan
\arctan, or \tan^{-1}, is the inverse function of tangent. The arc-tangent of a value x is the angle \theta such that the \tan(\theta) = x.
Derivative
\begin{aligned}
& y = \arctan(x) & (1)\\
& \tan{y} = x & (2)\\
& \frac{d}{dx}(\tan y) = \frac{d}{dx}(x) \\
& \sec^{2}(y) \frac{dy}{dx} = 1 \\
& \frac{dy}{dx}=\frac{1}{\sec^{2}(y)} \\
& 1 + \tan^{2}(y) = \sec^{2}(y) \\
& \frac{dy}{dx}= \frac{1}{1 + \tan^{2}(y)} \\
& \boxed{\frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{1}{1 + x^{2}}} & \text{see } (2)
\end{aligned}
\int{\frac{a}{a^{2}+x^{2}}dx}=[...]:?:\arctan{\frac{x}{a}}


References

Concepts/Math/Functions/The-Lambda-Calcu.title: The Lambda Calculus
Concepts/Math/Functions/The-Lambda-Calcu.content:
The Lambda Calculus
The Lambda Calculus is an incredibly simple system of mathematics that is Turing complete; that is, any program ever written could be abstracted in terms of \lambda-calculus.
Basic Syntax
Lambda calculus is essentially a syntactic sugar for incredibly simple functions. The syntax is:
x \mapsto M \Longleftrightarrow \lambda x.M
(x maps to M becomes \lambda x.M, where \lambda indicates a function, x is the input, and M is the output). Each of these functions are called \lambda-abstractions.
Examples:
f(x) = x + 1 \Longleftrightarrow \lambda x.x+1
Evaluation
See Beta Reduction.
Turing Complete
With just variables, \lambda-abstractions, and \beta-reduction, the language is Turing Complete. The trick is higher-order functions.
Higher-Order Functions
A higher order function: a \lambda-abstraction that returns another \lambda-abstraction. You have to get around having one input somehow.


                  
                  Higher Order Function: Add Two Inputs 
                  
                

f(x, y) = x + y \Longleftrightarrow \lambda x.\lambda y.x+y


In generalized form, this is: (\lambda x .\lambda y . L) M N \xRightarrow{\beta} (\lambda y. L[M/x] )N\xRightarrow{\beta}L[M/x][N/y]
which is called Currying after Haskell Curry.
Simple Type System
Refer to Simply Typed Lambda Calculus.
Abstractions
Booleans
\text{True} = \lambda x . \lambda y.x 
\text{False} = \lambda x . \lambda y.y 
\text{ifthen} = \lambda b^{\text{Bool}}. \lambda x . \lambda y. bxy 
\text{not} = \lambda b^\text{Bool}. \text{if } b \text{ then False else True}
Numbers
3 = \lambda f.\lambda x. f(f(f x)),
or more
generally n = \lambda f . \lambda x.f^{\circ n} x
Recursion
Still don’t understand this one, but:
Y = \lambda f.(\lambda x . f(x x)) (\lambda x . f(x x))
Topics

Alpha Conversion
Beta Reduction
Simply Typed Lambda Calculus


References

Programming with Math

Concepts/Math/Functions/Visualizing-Mult.title: Visualizing Multivariable Functions
Concepts/Math/Functions/Visualizing-Mult.content:
Visualizing Multivariable Functions
Visualizing Multivariable Functions can be difficult on paper/blackboard/screen. One easy way is to draw the shape from one side. An alternative is to use contour plots, which show all the points where f(x, y) = c_{1}, c_{2}, \dots c_{n} where c_{1}, c_{2}, \dots c_{n} are constants chosen at regular intervals. We slice the graph by horizontal planes z = c. Then we draw each level curve on the standard x-y plane. The following figure shows both methods:

The spacing of level curves tells us about the slope.

Concepts/Math/Geometry/Affine-Coordinate.title: Affine Coordinate System
Concepts/Math/Geometry/Affine-Coordinate.content:
Affine Coordinate System
An affine coordinate system is one in which all lines are straight and parallel, and it is linear.
Coordinate systems like the one below is affine, but skewed:

When the axes are instead perpendicular to each other, the coordinate system is orthogonal. Further restrictions may mean that the Coordinate System is Orthonormal Coordinates.
See Conversions between Affine Coordinate Systems and Cartesian Coordinates.
From the work in the Covariant Transformations Between Affine and Cartesian Coordinates, the Covariant Basis Vectors of the affine coordinate system are:
\vec{Z}_{1} = \hat{\textbf{u}} = a \hat{\textbf{x}}, \quad \vec{Z}_{2} = \hat{\textbf{v}} = b \cos{(\alpha)} \hat{\textbf{x}} + b \sin{(\alpha)} \hat{\textbf{y}}
That can be used to find the Covariant Metric of Affine Coordinates.

References
www.youtube.com/watch

Concepts/Math/Geometry/Borsak-Ulam-Theor.title: Borsak-Ulam Theorem
Concepts/Math/Geometry/Borsak-Ulam-Theor.content:
Borsak-Ulam Theorem
When mapping a 3d-sphere onto the 2d plane without any cuts or breaks, you can always find two points that are on the exact opposite sides (Antipedes, e.g. the north and south pole) of the sphere to start but end up mapping to the same location. Mathematically, this means that there must exist a point \vec{p} such that:
f(\vec{p}) = f(-\vec{p})
where f is a function that returns a value for any point on the sphere.
One very famous example is that no matter the weather patterns on Earth (or any other planet), two antipedal points must land on each other and therefore they must have the same temperature and pressure. This relies on the fact that you can map each point on the surface of the earth to a temperature and pressure.
Proof
g(\vec{p}) := f(\vec{p}) - f(-\vec{p})
Looking for \vec{p} where
g(\vec{p}) = \begin{bmatrix}0 \\ 0\end{bmatrix}

References
www.youtube.com/watch

Concepts/Math/Geometry/Circles.title: Circles
Concepts/Math/Geometry/Circles.content:
Circles
A circle is a set of points each uniformly a distance r from a center point P = (h, k).
Circle in the Plane
The equation for a circle in the plane, called the general equation for a circle, is
(x-h)^{2} + (y-k)^{2} = r^{2}
Parametric Equation for Circles
The parametric curve in the plane for a circle is
x(t) = a \cos{(t)}, \quad y(t) = a \sin{(t)}

References
ocw.mit.edu/courses/18-02sc-multivariable-calculus-fall-2010/resources/mit18_02sc_notes_9/

Concepts/Math/Geometry/Conversions-Betwe.title: Converting Polar Coordinates to and from Cartesian Coordinates

Concepts/Math/Geometry/Conversions-betwe.title: Conversions between Skewed Coordinate Systems and Cartesian Coordinates
Concepts/Math/Geometry/Conversions-betwe.content:
Conversions between Skewed Coordinate Systems and Cartesian Coordinates
Consider a coordinate system with axes u and v that are not at a right angle, such that they are skewed (see Affine Coordinate System). Let the angle \alpha be the angle between the two axes. To convert from this skewed coordinate system into traditional Cartesian Coordinates, we use the following equations:
x = au + b \cos{( \alpha )} v, \quad y = b \sin{( \alpha)} v
where a and b are the scaling factors between the two. To go in the opposite direction, we simply use algebra to find:
u = \frac{1}{a} x - a \cot{(\alpha)}y, \quad v = \frac{1}{b \sin{(\alpha)}} y
Also see: Jacobian for Affine Coordinates and Covariant Transformations Between Affine and Cartesian Coordinates.

References

Concepts/Math/Geometry/Conversions-betwe.title: Conversions between Cartesian Coordinates and Spherical Coordinates
Conversions between Cylindrical Coordinates and Cartesian Coordinates
Concepts/Math/Geometry/Conversions-betwe.content:
Conversions between Cylindrical Coordinates and Cartesian Coordinates
The conversion is quite simply; it builds easily upon Conversions Between Polar Coordinates and Cartesian Coordinates: x = \rho \cos{(\theta)}, \quad y = \rho \sin{(\theta)}, \quad z = z
Vice versa:
\rho = \sqrt{x^{2} + y^{2}}, \quad \theta = \arctan{\left(\frac{y}{x}\right)}, \quad z=z

References

Concepts/Math/Geometry/Conversions-betwe.title: Conversions between Cylindrical Coordinates and Spherical Coordinates
Concepts/Math/Geometry/Conversions-betwe.content:
Conversions between Cylindrical Coordinates and Spherical Coordinates
The height is given by z = \rho \cos{(\phi)}, and r = \rho \sin{(\phi)}. \theta is the same.

Concepts/Math/Geometry/Coordinate-System.title: Coordinate System
Concepts/Math/Geometry/Coordinate-System.content:
Coordinate System
Topic: Geometry
A coordinate system uses one or more numbers to determine the position of points on a Manifold.
The most classic example is Euclidean Space, which represents each point in space as a ordered tuple (x, y, z).
Other coordinate systems include:

Cylindrical Coordinates
Polar Coordinates
Orthonormal Coordinates
Spherical Coordinates

Concepts/Math/Geometry/Curvature.title: Curvature
Concepts/Math/Geometry/Curvature.content:
Curvature
Topic: Geometry
Curvature is basically a way of measuring how much something bends from being a straight line or planar.
As with many things in math, curvature is a very simple idea that can be challenging to define precisely. One way to think of it is as the Instantaneous Rate of Change of the Normal Vector to the surface at any given point. In 3D, this is a vector quantity.

References

Concepts/Math/Geometry/Curves-in-Space.title: Curves in Space

Concepts/Math/Geometry/Curvilinear-Coord.title: Curvilinear Coordinates
Concepts/Math/Geometry/Curvilinear-Coord.content:
Curvilinear Coordinates
Curvilinear coordinates are a class of coordinate systems for Euclidean Space in which lines may be curved. Well known examples in \mathbb{R}^{3} are Cylindrical Coordinates and Spherical Coordinates. In \mathbb{R}^{2}, there is Polar Coordinates.

References
www.youtube.com/watch
www.youtube.com/watch

Concepts/Math/Geometry/Cylindrical-Coord.title: Cylindrical Coordinates
Concepts/Math/Geometry/Cylindrical-Coord.content:
Cylindrical Coordinates
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
The cylindrical system specifies each point by a height z and then a Polar Coordinates equivalent r and \theta; in total, each point is (x, y, z) \to (r, \theta, z) where x = r \cos{(\theta)}, y = r \sin{(\theta)}, and z =z.
This can make problems with stacked circles very easy. See Triple Integrals.
The volume element dV = dxdydz = rdrd\theta dz.
Covariant Basis Vectors for Cylindrical Coordinates

\hat{\textbf{r}} = \cos{(\theta)} \hat{\textbf{x}} + \sin{(\theta)} \hat{\textbf{y}}
\hat{\theta} = - r \sin{(\theta)} \hat{\textbf{x}} + r \cos{(\theta)} \hat{\textbf{y}}
\hat{\textbf{z}} = \hat{\textbf{z}}

Transclude of Jacobian-for-Cylindrical-Coordinates#jacobian-for-cylindrical-coordinates

References
1802SC - Multivariable Calculus - Session 75

Concepts/Math/Geometry/Normal-Vector.title: Normal Vector
Concepts/Math/Geometry/Normal-Vector.content:
Normal Vector
Topic: Geometry
The normal vector is a vector perpendicular to a given object. For example, the normal vector to a surface at a point is the vector pointing directly out of that surface - typically made into a unit vector. This is also the normal vector to the Tangent Plane at that point.
The normal vector of a plane is useful for determining the equation of that plane.


                  
                  Aren't there two? 
                  
                

There are two vectors perpendicular to any plane or object. It is important to determine some rule for picking which one to use; typically a right hand rule is employed.



References

Concepts/Math/Geometry/Orthonormal-Coord.title: Orthonormal Coordinates
Concepts/Math/Geometry/Orthonormal-Coord.content:
Orthonormal Coordinates
An orthonormal coordinate system is an Affine Coordinate System in which all axes are mutually orthogonal and all scaling factors are one. Euclidean Space is one example.

References

Concepts/Math/Geometry/Polar-Coordinates.title: Polar Coordinates
Concepts/Math/Geometry/Polar-Coordinates.content:
Polar Coordinates
Polar coordinates, sometimes named planar polar coordinates, are a way of expressing a position in Euclidean Space. In the space \mathbb{R}^{2}, there are two required coordinates to express a position. Polar coordinates do this via the angle from the polar axis, often a horizontal ray, denoted \theta, and the distance along the radial line r. Therefore, the point (x, y) maps to some other point (r, \theta).
Transclude of Conversions-Between-Polar-Coordinates-and-Cartesian-Coordinates#converting-polar-coordinates-to-and-from-cartesian-coordinates
Covariant Basis Vectors
It can be shown that the covariant basis vectors for polar coordinates in terms of Cartesian Coordinates are given as
\hat{\textbf{r}} &= \cos{(\theta)} \hat{\textbf{x}} + \sin{(\theta)} \hat{\textbf{y}} \\
\hat{\theta} &= -r \sin{(\theta)} \hat{\textbf{x}} + r \cos{(\theta)} \hat{\textbf{y}}
\end{align}$$
## References
www.youtube.com/watch

Concepts/Math/Geometry/Spherical-Coordin.title: Spherical Coordinates
Concepts/Math/Geometry/Spherical-Coordin.content:
Spherical Coordinates
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
Spherical coordinates are a way of expressing positions in space. It maps the standard Cartesian Coordinates (x, y, z) to the radius, \rho, angle from the z-axis \phi, and angle in the x\text-y plane \theta. It can be thought of as an extension of Polar Coordinates, much like Cylindrical Coordinates.
A sphere would be made by fixing \rho = a. In this case, \phi is more or less Latitude and \theta is Longitude. \phi ranges from 0 at the North pole to \pi on the South pole. On the other hand, \theta ranges from 0 to 2 \pi.

\rho = distance to origin, \rho \geq 0
\phi = angle to z-axis, 0 \leq \phi \leq \pi
\theta = angle of projection to xy-plane with x-axis, 0 \leq \theta \leq 2\pi

The volume element is dV = \rho^{2} \sin{(\phi)} d\rho d\phi d \theta.
Transclude of Conversions-between-Cylindrical-Coordinates-and-Spherical-Coordinates
Transclude of Conversions-between-Cartesian-Coordinates-and-Spherical-Coordinates
Geometric Examples

If you fix \rho = a, then you get a sphere of radius a at centered at the origin
If you set \phi = \frac{\pi}{4}, you get a cone (this is equal to z = r, or the line y = x rotated around the z-axis)
If you set \phi = \frac{\pi}{2}, you get the xy-plane


References
1802SC - Multivariable Calculus - Session 76

Concepts/Math/Geometry/Volume-of-a-Spher.title: Volume of a Sphere
Concepts/Math/Geometry/Volume-of-a-Spher.content:
Volume of a Sphere
The volume of a sphere is V = \frac{4}{3} \pi r^{3}

References
1802SC - Multivariable Calculus - Session 81

Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/3b1b-Linear.title: Chapter 1 - Vectors
Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/3b1b-Linear.content:
Chapter 1 - Vectors
Vectors
What is a Vector?
Physics Student’s Perspective
A physics student might tell you that what defines a vector is it’s length and direction. You can move it all around, and it is still the same vector.
CS
A computer science might tell you that a vector is just an ordered list of numbers. It can be any dimensional.
Mathematican’s Perspective
A mathematician is somewhere inbetween, with a much more abstract viewpoint. Grant didn’t cover this now.
What should we imagine?
Think of vectors as a arrow pointing somewhere in the coordinate plane, with it’s tail rooted at the origin. Only once you have that visualization should you think of it as a list of numbers.
2D Vectors
In the xy coordinate plane, the point 0, 0 is the origin. The coordinates of a 2d vector, or the values, tell you where it is pointing to. The first value says how far to go parallel to the x-axis, and the second how far to go parallel to the y-axis.
3D Vectors
The same idea applies for 3D vectors. The first number tells you the x-axis, the second y, and the third z.
Vector Operations
Vector Addition
To add two vectors, move the tail of one vector to the head of the other. The vector from the origin to the position that the second vector now points to is the result of the addition.
You can think of this as taking steps along the plane corresponding to the directions of both vectors, and where you end up.
\begin{bmatrix} a \\ b \end{bmatrix}
+
\begin{bmatrix} c \\ d \end{bmatrix} 
= 
\begin{bmatrix} a+c \\ b+d \end{bmatrix} 
Vector Multiplication
If you multiply a vector by a positive constant, you stretch it out by that factor. This can be shrinking or stretching, and is generally called scaling. The constants are called scalars.
If you multiply by a negative scalar, you first flip it, then stretch it.
Numerically, this multiplication is done by multiplying each part of the vector by the scalar value.

Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/3b1b-Linear.title: Chapter 2 - Linear Combinations
Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/3b1b-Linear.content:
Chapter 2 - Linear Combinations
Linear combinations, span, and basis vectors
Basis Vectors
Think of each coordinate in a vector pair as a scalar, multiplying the x unit-vector i and the y unit-vector j. This unlocks something quite important: a 2d vector can be represented as the sum of two 1d vectors, scalars of i and j.
i and j are called basis vectors, because they create the basis of the xy plane. Interestingly, you could use any basis vectors, not necessarily just i and j.
Transclude of Linear-Combinations
Vectors vs Points
It is common to represent a vector as just a dot at the head, or the point where its tip sits. This is just easier for visualizing a collection of vectors.
3D Span
What does the span of two 3D vectors look like? Generally, they will create a plane somewhere in 3D space, unless they are co-linear.
A linear combination of 3 vectors works the same way as it does with 2.
If the third vector is on the plane of the span of the first two, then you are still stuck on that plane. This is similar to co-linear vectors. However, if you pick any other vector, you can access the full 3d space.
Transclude of Linear-Dependence

Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/3b1b-Linear.title: Chapter 3 - Linear Transformations and Matrices
Chapter 4 - Matrix Multiplication
Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/3b1b-Linear.content:
Chapter 4 - Matrix Multiplication
Matrix Multiplication as Composition
Composition
Sometimes, you need to apply multiple linear transformations in sequence. Say a shear and a rotation. You could do this separately, first multiply by the rotation matrix, then the shear matrix, but that is longer than it needs to be. Instead, you find the product of the shear and rotation as a new separate matrix, and just multiply by that.
To do this numerically, we will need to read right to left. Look at i after the first, that is the right, matrix. Multiply it by the second, left matrix, to get the first column of the product. Do the same for j, and you have the product.
\begin{bmatrix}a & b \\ c & d\end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix}e & f \\ g & h\end{bmatrix}
=
\begin{bmatrix}ae + bg & af + bh \\ ce + dg & cf + dh\end{bmatrix}
A simple way to think of this is that the first resulting column is the first column of matrix 1 times matrix 2,  and the second column is the second column of matrix 1 times matrix 2.
Remember that order matters for matrix multiplication.

Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/3b1b-Linear.title: Chapter 5 - Three-dimensional Transformations
Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/3b1b-Linear.content:
Chapter 5 - Three-dimensional Transformations
Three-dimensional Linear Transformations
A linear transformation in 3 dimensions still takes an input vector, and still produces an output vector. The origin must still be preserved, and the grid lines must still remain parallel. A transformation is still described entirely by its basis vectors.

Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Basis-Vecto.title: Basis Vectors
Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Basis-Vecto.content:
Basis Vectors
Basis vectors are a Set of n linearly independent vectors that can be used to write every element in a n dimensional vector space V (or coordinate space \mathbb{R}^{n}). For example, \hat{\textbf{i}}, \hat{\textbf{j}}, \hat{\textbf{k}} form a basis for \mathbb{R}^{3}.

References

Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Bijective-T.title: Bijective Transformation
Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Bijective-T.content:
Bijective Transformation
A bijective transformation is one-to-one: every x in the original coordinate system corresponds to a unique x' in the image coordinate system, and every x' in the image coordinate system corresponds to a unique x in the original coordinate system.

References
www.youtube.com/watch

Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Elimination.title: Elimination with Matrices
Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Elimination.content:
Elimination with Matrices
Elimination with matrices is a technique for solving System of Equations using Matrix Operations. We take a system of 3 linear equations, represent them as a matrix, then reduce to 2 equations with 2 unknowns, then down to a single equation and unknown. We do this using pivot points which are the main left diagonal.

References
1806 - Linear Algebra- Session 1.3

Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/General-Tra.title: General Transformations
Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/General-Tra.content:
General Transformations
A transformation is something that takes in inputs and spits out something else. In linear algebra, we often think of something that takes in a vector and outputs some other vector. The input vector is transformed into the output vector. To visualize this, you can think of all vectors, or their points, as being transformed to produce its output. This could stretch or shape the entire plane.
For some transformation function T, we have
\vec{x'} = T(\vec{x})
\vec{x_{i}'}=T_{i}(x_{1}, x_{2}, \dots, x_{n})
If T is linear, then x_{i}' is called an Affine Coordinate System. If T is nonlinear, then the x_{i}' coordinate system is called a set of curvilinear coordinates.
Transclude of Coordinate-Transformations#coordinate-transformations

Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Linear-Comb.title: Linear Combinations
Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Linear-Comb.content:
Linear Combinations
Any time that you scale and add two vectors, it is called a linear combination of those two vectors.
a\vec{v}+b\vec{w}
One way of thinking about the name is that if you fix one vector and only move the other one, than the resulting vector will draw a straight line.
If you let both scalars range freely, you will normally be able to reach any other vector in that plane. Now, if you happen to have two co-linear vectors, then you are stuck to a line.


                  
                  Span 
                  
                

The span of \vec{v} and \vec{w} is the set of all their linear combinations.
a\vec{v}+b\vec{w}
let a and b vary over all real numbers.


It is often important to determine the Linear Dependence of a linear combination.

Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Linear-Depe.title: Linear Dependence
Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Linear-Depe.content:
Linear Dependence
If one vector can be represented by a scaled version of another or a linear combination of others, then it does not add anything new to the span of the set.
If \vec{u}=a\vec{v} + b\vec{w}, then it is linearly dependent. Conversely, if \vec{w} \neq a\vec{v}, then they are linearly independent.
The Wronskian is a very useful tool for determining linear dependence.

Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Linear-Inde.title: Linear Independence of Solution Vectors
Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Linear-Inde.content:
Linear Independence of Solution Vectors


                  
                  Linear Dependence/Independence of Solution Vectors 
                  
                

Let X_{1}, X_{2}, \dots, X_{k} be a set of Solution Vectors of the Homogeneous Systems of Linear Differential Equations X' = AX on an interval I. We say that the set is linearly dependent on the interval if there exists constants c_{1}, c_{2}, \dots, c_{k}, not all zero, such that c_{1}X_{1} + c_{2}X_{2} + \dots + c_{k}X_{k} = 0
for every t in the interval. If the set of Vectors is not linearly dependent on the interval, it is said to be linearly independent.


This is an identical definition to that explored in 3), but applied to matrices and Vectors.
The Wronskian is very useful for determining the linear dependence.

References
A First Course in Differential Equations with Modeling Applications; Chapter 8.1.2

Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Linear-Syst.title: Linear Systems
Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Linear-Syst.content:
Linear Systems
2x2
A 2x2 system of linear equations is what I learned in Algebra 2:
ax + by = c; \quad mx + ny = o
These types of systems can be solved through:
Substitution
Isolate x or y in one equation, e.g. x = \frac{c-by}{a} and then substitute it into the other.
Elimination
Multiply one equation by a constant and then sum the two equations such that one variable is cancelled out.
Solution Types
A 2x2 system of linear equations can be thought of simply as two lines in the xy plane. The solution is the point where the two lines intersect. There are three distinct solution possibilities:

Infinitely many: the lines are identical
None: The lines are parallel and not contained
One: Everything else

3x3
A 3x3 system of linear equations looks like:
ax + by + cz = d \\
ex + fy + gz = h \\
ix + jy + kz = l \\
\end{cases} \quad \text{ or } \quad  AX = B$$
Which is really three [[Equations of Planes]]. 

#### Solution Types
A 3x3 system like above can have the following solution sets:
- None: Two or more of the planes are parallel, OR the planes are intersecting in a way that does not allow a solution point
- A line: One plane is linearly dependent on the other two
- A plane: One plane is a duplicate
- A point: each plane is linearly independent


***

## References
[[1802SC - Multivariable Calculus]]; Session 13.

Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Linear-Tran.title: Linear Transformation
Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Linear-Tran.content:
Linear Transformation
A linear transformation is specific subset of General Transformations. Geographically, they have the properties that lines remain lines, and the origin remains fixed. It is important to remember that means all lines, not just horizontal or vertical ones.
More mathematically, a transformation L is linear if it satisfies the following two properties:
&L \text{ preserves sums: } &L(\vec{v} + \vec{w}) &= L(\vec{v }) + L (\vec{w})\\
&L \text{ preserves scaling: } &L(s \vec{v})&= sL(\vec{v})
\end{aligned}$$

This is actually very restrictive, because it says that the relationship of a vector to its basis [[vectors]] before transformation will be the same as the transformations relation to the transformed basis [[vectors]]:

$$L(-1 \hat{\textbf{i}} + 2 \hat{\textbf{j}}) = L(-1 \hat{\textbf{i}}) + L(2 \hat{\textbf{j}}) = -1 L(\hat{\textbf{i}}) + 2 L(\hat{\textbf{j}})$$
Therefore, if you know where the [[Basis Vectors]] go through a linear transformation, you can find where everything else goes.

## Mathematical Representation
How is a linear transformation actually done? Say a rotation for graphics. What do you tell the computer to do?

Well, the only information you need is where $\hat{\textbf{i}}$ lands and where $\hat{\textbf{j}}$ lands. In the 2D plane, that is just 4 numbers. These numbers are packaged into a $2 \times 2$ grid of numbers, like this:
$$\begin{bmatrix} a & b \\ c & d\end{bmatrix}$$
Then you need a function that takes in any general vector and applies this transformation to it, using those four numbers. This is done via [[Matrix-Vector Multiplication]]:
![[Matrix-Vector Multiplication]]

## Composition of Transformations
You often need to apply two transformations in sequence. You might shear, and then rotate. To get to any combination of transformations, you could apply them to a vector one by one. For example, you could multiply a vector by a shear matrix, and then multiply the result of that by the rotation matrix. This could, however, be done in a single operation by multiplying the vector by a new matrix, which is the product of the two others.
For a rotation and then shear, this would be:
$$\begin{bmatrix}1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}0 & -1 \\ 1 & 0\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}1 & -1 \\ 1 & 0\end{bmatrix}$$
Note that the transformations are applied right to left. Think of it like function notation: $f(g(\vec{v}))$. We evaluate $g$ first.

Generally, this process is called [[Matrix Multiplication]]:
![[Matrix Multiplication]]

## Three-dimensional Linear Transformations

In three-dimensions, each position is represented by three components. In the standard [[Euclidean Space]], our basis [[vectors]] are typically $\hat{\textbf{i}}$, $\hat{\textbf{j}}$, and $\hat{\textbf{k}}$. A transformation of these basis [[vectors]] can be represented by a 3x3 matrix, detailing where $\hat{\textbf{i}}$ lands, $\hat{\textbf{j}}$ lands, and $\hat{\textbf{k}}$ lands. You then input a vector $\begin{bmatrix}x \\ y \\ z\end{bmatrix}$, like this:

\begin{bmatrix}a & b & c \ d & e & f \ g & h & i\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}x \ y \ z\end{bmatrix} = x \begin{bmatrix}a \ d \ g\end{bmatrix} + y \begin{bmatrix}b \ e \ h\end{bmatrix} + z \begin{bmatrix}c \ f \ i\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}ax + by + c z \ dx + ey + fz \ gx + hy + iz \end{bmatrix}

Or, you can combine multiple transformations like this:

$$\begin{bmatrix}a & b & c \\ d & e & f \\ g & h & i\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}q & r & s \\ t & u & v \\ x & y & z\end{bmatrix} = $$

Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Matrices/Ma.title: Matrices
Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Matrices/Ma.content:
Matrices
A matrix is simply a set of numbers arranged into rows and columns.
For example:
M = \begin{bmatrix} -2 & 5 & 6 \\ 5 & 2 & 7 \end{bmatrix} 
A matrix has a size based on its dimensions. For example, the above matrix has 2 rows and 3 columns, so it is 2x3.
Always write rows x columns.
A matrix element is simply a entry in the matrix. It can be represented by a subscript. For example, the element m_{2,1} = 5, because it is the second row and first column of M.
More generally, the element in row i and column j of a matrix A is denoted as a_{i,j}.

Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Matrices/Ma.title: Matrix Addition
Matrix Equations and Systems
Matrix Multiplication
Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Matrices/Ma.content:
Matrix Multiplication
Topic: Introduction to Linear Algebra
The result of multiplying two 2 \times 2 matrices is shown below:
\begin{bmatrix}a & b \\ c & d\end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix}e & f \\ g & h\end{bmatrix}
=
\begin{bmatrix}ae + bg & af + bh \\ ce + dg & cf + dh\end{bmatrix}
Matrix multiplication only works if the number of columns of the first matrix is equal to the number of rows on the second matrix.
Matrix multiplication can also be thought of as taking the dot product of the rows of the first matrix with the columns of the second.
Order matters when multiplying matrices.
M_{2} \times M_{1} \neq M_{1} \times M_{2}
It helps to think of this in the context of linear transformations. The left column of the resulting matrix represents where \hat{\textbf{i}} goes after the two transformations, and the right column represents where \hat{\textbf{j}} goes.
\hat{\textbf{i}}: \quad \begin{bmatrix}a & b \\ c & d \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}e \\ g\end{bmatrix} = e\begin{bmatrix}a \\ c\end{bmatrix} + g\begin{bmatrix}b \\ d\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}ae + bg \\ ce + dg\end{bmatrix}
\hat{\textbf{j}}: \quad \begin{bmatrix}a & b \\ c & d \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}f \\ h\end{bmatrix} = f\begin{bmatrix}a \\ c\end{bmatrix} + h\begin{bmatrix}b \\ d\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}af + bh \\ cf + dh\end{bmatrix}
Laws and Properties
Associative
Matrix multiplication is associative:
(AB)C = A(BC)
Both are the same as applying transformation C, then B, then A.
Distributive
A(B+C) = AB + BC; \quad (A+B)C = AC + BC
Identity Matrix
Let I_{3} = \begin{bmatrix}1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1  & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1\end{bmatrix}; then AI = A and IA = A for any 3x3 matrix. Similar identity matrices exist for any square matrix.
Determinant Property
\det(AB) = \det(A)\det(B)

References
www.3blue1brown.com/lessons/matrix-multiplication

Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Matrices/Ma.title: Matrix Operations
Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Matrices/Ma.content:
Matrix Operations
The following operations are defined on Matrices:

Matrix Scalar Multiplication
Matrix Addition
Matrix Subtraction
Matrix Multiplication
Matrix-Vector Multiplication

Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Matrices/Ma.title: Matrix Scalar Multiplication
Matrix Subtraction
Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Matrices/Ma.content:
Matrix Subtraction
To subtract two Matrices, simply distribute the scalar -1 first, and then add. Let A and B be matrices:
A - B = A + -1\cdot B

Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Matrices/Ma.title: Matrix-Vector Multiplication

Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Matrix-Dete.title: Matrix Determinant
Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Matrix-Dete.content:
Matrix Determinant
The matrix determinant is only defined for square matrices.
a_{x} & a_{y} & a_{z} \\ 
b_{x} & b_{y} & b_{z}
\end{bmatrix} = \hat{\textbf{i}}(a_{y}b_{z} - a_{z}b_{y}) - \hat{\textbf{j}}(a_{x}b_{z} - a_{z}b_{x}) + \hat{\textbf{k}}(a_{x}b_{y} - a_{y}b_{x})$$
But why?

To find the determinant of a matrix, start with any row or column. You will "expand" this choice. I will typically use the top one. We will expand from left to right.
For each element, cross out everything in that elements row and column. Then, find the determinant of what remains. For example, in that given matrix, you would start with $\hat{\textbf{i}}$, for which you would find the determinant of:
\det\begin{bmatrix}a_{y} & a_{z} \ b_{y} & b_{z} \end{bmatrix}
Two find the determinant of a 2x2, you just use the rule left diagonal - right diagonal. For this 2x2, that is $a_{y}b_{z} - a_{z}b_{y}$. So, the $\hat{\textbf{i}}$ term is $\hat{\textbf{i}}(a_{y}b_{z} - a_{z}b_{y})$.

You then do the same process for $\hat{\textbf{j}}$ and $\hat{\textbf{k}}$. But! You must also remember the sign matrix, multiplying each term by its corresponding sign:
$$\begin{bmatrix}+ & - & + \\ - & + & - \\ + & - &+\end{bmatrix}$$
### Geometric Theorem in Space
Geometrically, the $\det(\vec{A}, \vec{B}, \vec{C}) = \pm \text{volume of parallelepiped formed by those three vectors}$. The parallelepiped is just a fancy word for box with parallelogram sides.

Another way to find the volume of such a space is 
$$\vec{A} \cdot (\vec{B} \times \vec{C})$$
this is known as the [[Triple Scalar Product]].

### Determinant Facts
Let |A| be the determinant of a matrix A.
- |A| is multiplied by -1 if we interchange two rows or columns
- |A| = 0 if one row or column is all zero, or if two rows or two columns are the same
- |A| is multiplied by c if the matrix is piecewise multiplied by c
- |A| is unchanged if we add to one row a constant multiple of another row
### Applications of Determinants in 2D

Consider a triangle. Any triangle you want. Let the adjacent side be formed by $\vec{A}$ and the hypotenuse be $\vec{B}$. Let the sides be separated by angle $\theta$. How would you find the area of this triangle?

Of course, the area of a triangle is $\frac{1}{2} bh$. The base of the triangle is just $|\vec{A}|$. The height $h$ is $\sin{(\theta)} \times |\vec{B}|$. The area is then 
$$\frac{1}{2} |\vec{A}| |\vec{B}| \sin{(\theta)}$$
But, given two [[vectors]], how do you find the angle $\theta$? The easiest way is with [[Vector Dot Products#computing-angles|Computing Angles]]. However, that gives us $\cos{(\theta)}$, so then you have to use the Pythagorean Identity and it gets quite ugly. So instead, we can do some geometry!

We want the value $\sin{(\theta)}$. For any angle $\theta$, there exists a complementary angle $\theta'$ such that $\sin{(\theta)} = \cos{(\theta')}$. In particular, the angle $\theta'$ is formed by rotating $\vec{A}$ by 90 degrees counterclockwise, forming the vector $\vec{A'} = [-a_{2}, a_{1}]$ (this can be seen by geometry, or done using a rotation matrix). The length of A' is equal to the length of A. Therefore, 
$$\cos{(\theta')} = \frac{\vec{A'} \cdot \vec{B}}{|A'||B|}= \sin{(\theta)}$$
Plugging this into our previous formula for area, we have
$$\text{Area} = \frac{1}{2} (\vec{A'} \cdot \vec{B}) = \frac{1}{2}(-a_{2}b_{1} + b_{2}a_{1}) = \frac{1}{2} \det{\begin{bmatrix}a_{1} & a_{2} \\ b_{1} & b_{2}\end{bmatrix}} = \frac{1}{2} \det[\vec{A}, \vec{B}]$$
Note that this area can be $\pm$ depending on the angle $\theta$, so it is more accurate to say that the above is $\pm \text{Area}$.

More generally, this gives us a very elegant geometric representation of the determinant: the absolute value of the determinant of two 2D [[vectors]] is the area of the quadrilateral which they form. This powerful fact can be used to determine the area of much more complex shapes.


***

Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Matrix-Inve.title: Matrix Inverse
Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Matrix-Inve.content:
Matrix Inverse
The inverse of a matrix allows us to “undo” the transformation done by applying matrix A. The fundamental property is that AM = I and MA = I. This requires a square matrix. M = A^{-1} is typical notation.
The primary use is for solving the matrix equation AX = B, such that X = A^{-1}B; that is trying to find the transformation X that brings you from A to B.
Manual Calculation
A^{-1} = \frac{1}{\det{A}} \times \text{adj}(A)
Where \text{adj}(A) is the Adjoint Matrix.
Let A = \begin{bmatrix}a & b & c \\ d & e & f  \\ g & h & i\end{bmatrix}
1)
Find the “minors” of the matrix A:
\begin{bmatrix}
\det{\begin{bmatrix}e  & f \\ h & i \end{bmatrix}} & \det{\begin{bmatrix}d & g \\ f & i\end{bmatrix}} & \det{\begin{bmatrix}d & e \\ g & h\end{bmatrix}} \\ \det{\begin{bmatrix}b & c \\ h & i\end{bmatrix}}&\det{\begin{bmatrix}d & f \\ g & i\end{bmatrix}}&\det{\begin{bmatrix}d & e  \\ g & h\end{bmatrix}} \\ \det{\begin{bmatrix}b & c \\ e & f\end{bmatrix}}&\det{\begin{bmatrix}a & c \\ d & f\end{bmatrix}}&\det{\begin{bmatrix}a & b \\ d & e\end{bmatrix}}
\end{bmatrix}$$

#### 2)
Find the cofactors: do a piecewise matrix multiplication with the sign matrix
$$\begin{bmatrix}+  & - & + \\ - & + & - \\ + & - & +\end{bmatrix}$$
#### 3)
Transpose: switch rows and columns. This is the adjoint matrix.

#### 4)
Divide by the determinant of A.


### Existence
You can not take the inverse of every square matrix. Specifically, if the determinant of a matrix is 0 ($\det{A} = 0$), then you can't take the inverse. 

***
