Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Real-Coordi.title: Real Coordinate Spaces
Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Real-Coordi.content:
Real Coordinate Spaces
\mathbb{R}^2 represents 2-dimensional real coordinate space, or all possible real-valued 2-tuples; vectors of length 2.
There is nothing special about 2. \mathbb{R}^3 means all real valued 3-tuples, \mathbb{R}^4 means 4 dimensional space, etc.

Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Triple-Scal.title: Triple Scalar Product
Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Triple-Scal.content:
Triple Scalar Product
The triple scalar product is a product of three vectors, A, B, and C, given by
\vec{A} \cdot (\vec{B} \times \vec{C})
where the first operation is the Vector Dot Products and the second is the Vector Cross Product. The result of this operation is a scalar, which corresponds to the signed volume of the parallelepiped defined by the three vectors given. This results naturally from the fact that the volume is given by the area of the base times the height.
Proof
The base of a parallelepiped is defined by two vectors, \vec{B} and \vec{C}. The area of this parallelogram is given by the magnitude of the cross product of these two vectors, |\vec{B} \times \vec{C}|. The height is slightly more difficult; it is the amount of the vector \vec{A} pointing in the direction perpendicular to the base. Luckily, the unit vector pointing in said direction can be found using the cross product, and the amount of A along that unit vector is just a dot product:
\text{area(Base)} \times \text{Height} = |\vec{B} \times \vec{C}| \times \vec{A} \cdot \frac{\vec{B}\times\vec{C}}{|\vec{B}\times\vec{C}|} = \vec{A} \cdot (\vec{B} \times \vec{C})

References
ocw.mit.edu/courses/18-02sc-multivariable-calculus-fall-2010/resources/clip-2-more-on-cross-products/
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triple_product
Introduction to Electrodynamics by David J. Griffiths - Chapter 1, p.7

Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Vectors/Ang.title: Angle Between Two Vectors
Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Vectors/Ang.content:
Angle Between Two Vectors
The angle \theta between two vectors \vec{a} and \vec{b} is the same as the angle between the lengths of those triangles, ||\vec{a}|| and ||\vec{b}||. If you construct a triangle by adding the third side, \vec{a} - \vec{b} or ||\vec{a} - \vec{b}||, you can then apply the Law of Cosines.
We are going to solve for the angle in the triangle constructed by the lengths, because this applies to any dimensional vector, not just two or three.
||\vec{a} -\vec{b}||^{2}=||\vec{b}||^{2} + ||\vec{a}||^{2} - 2||\vec{a}|| \text{ }||\vec{b}||\cos(\theta)
||\vec{a}||^{2}-2(\vec{a}\cdot\vec{b}) + ||\vec{b}||^{2}= ||\vec{b}||^{2} + ||\vec{a}||^{2} - 2||\vec{a}|| \text{ }||\vec{b}||\cos(\theta)
(\vec{a}\cdot\vec{b})=||\vec{a}|| ||\vec{b}||\cos(\theta)
Now, if \vec{a} = c\vec{b}, then if c > 0 \theta = 0^{\circ}, and if c < 0, \theta = 180^\circ.
Interestingly, if the two vectors \vec{a} and \vec{b} are perpendicular, than \theta = 90^\circ, and the \cos(90^{\circ}) = 0 , so the entire right hand side is 0. Thus, the dot product of the two vectors must also be 0.

Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Vectors/Uni.title: Unit Vectors
Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Vectors/Uni.content:
Unit Vectors
A vector with magnitude of 1. Typically represented by some letter with a hat, e.g. \hat{x}. The most classical  examples of unit vectors are \hat{i} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}, and \hat{j} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}. These are the Basis Vectors of planar Cartesian Coordinates, and therefore allow us to represent other vectors more concisely. For example,
\vec{v} = \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{bmatrix} = 2\hat{i} + 3\hat{j}
To find the unit vector in the same direction as a vector, we divide it by its magnitude.
Other Examples
While most texts use \hat{\textbf{i}}, \hat{\textbf{j}}, and \hat{\textbf{k}}, others, including an Introduction to Electrodynamics by David J. Griffiths, uses \hat{\textbf{x}}, \hat{\textbf{y}}, and \hat{\textbf{z}}.

Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Vectors/Vec.title: Vector Addition
Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Vectors/Vec.content:
Vector Addition
If you have two vectors:
\vec{a} = \begin{bmatrix} x_{1} \\ y_{1} \end{bmatrix} \quad \vec{b}=\begin{bmatrix} x_{2} \\ y_{2} \end{bmatrix}
Then the sum of the vectors is:
\vec{a} + \vec{b} = \begin{bmatrix} x_{1} + x_{2}\\ y_{1} + y_{2} \end{bmatrix}
Conceptually, this means to place the “tail” of one vector at the “head” of the other. It doesn’t matter what order you chose to do this in; you can put the tail of either at the head of the other.
Even more generally:
\begin{bmatrix} a_{1} \\ a_{2} \\ \vdots \\ a_{n}\end{bmatrix} + \begin{bmatrix} b_{1} \\ b_{2}\\ \vdots \\ b_{n}\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} a_{1}+ b_{1} \\ a_{2}+b_{2} \\ \vdots \\ a_{n}+b_{n}\end{bmatrix}
Properties

Commutative: \vec{\textbf{A}} + \vec{\textbf{B}} = \vec{\textbf{B}} + \vec{\textbf{A}}
Associative: (\vec{\textbf{A}} + \vec{\textbf{B}}) + \vec{\textbf{C}} = \vec{\textbf{A}} + (\vec{\textbf{B}} + \vec{\textbf{C}})
Subtraction: \vec{\textbf{A}} - \vec{\textbf{B}} = \vec{\textbf{A}} + (- \vec{\textbf{B}}) (see Vector Scalar Multiplication)

References
See Introduction to Electrodynamics by David J. Griffiths - Chapter 1, p.2.

Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Vectors/Vec.title: Cross Product
Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Vectors/Vec.content:
Cross Product
The cross product is an operation only defined for vectors in 3-dimensional space, or \vec{a}, \vec{b} \in \mathbb{R}^{3}. The result of a cross-product is another vector orthogonal to the two original.
\vec{A} =
\begin{bmatrix}
a_{1}\\
a_{2}\\
a_{3}\\
\end{bmatrix} 
\: \: 
\vec{B}=
\begin{bmatrix} 
b_{1}\\
b_{2}\\
b_{3}\\
\end{bmatrix} 
\: \: 
a_{1} & a_{2} & a_{3} \\ 
b_{1} & b_{2} & b_{3}
\end{bmatrix} = \hat{\textbf{i}}\det{\begin{bmatrix}a_{2} & a_{3} \\ b_{2} & b_{3}\end{bmatrix}} - \hat{\textbf{j}}\det{\begin{bmatrix}a_{1} & a_{3} \\ b_{1} & b_{3}\end{bmatrix}} + \hat{\textbf{k}}\det{\begin{bmatrix}a_{1} & a_{2} \\ b_{1} & b_{2}\end{bmatrix}}$$

Where $\det$ is the [[Matrix Determinant]] of the given matrix.

The "easier" way to approach cross products is:
$$\vec{A} \times \vec{B} = AB \sin{(\theta)} \hat{\textbf{n}}$$
where $\hat{\textbf{n}}$ is a [[Unit Vectors]] pointing perpendicular to the [[Equations of Planes|plane]] formed by $\vec{A}$ and $\vec{B}$. (the directional ambiguity is resolved by the **right-hand rule**: point your right-hand fingers in the direction of the first vector and curl around toward the second; your thumb points in $\hat{\textbf{n}}$). 
## Details
- $|\vec{A} \times \vec{B}| = \text{area of parallelogram formed by A, B in space}$
- $\text{direction}(\vec{A} \times \vec{B})$ is perpendicular to the plane formed by A and B (with right hand rule)
- **NOT** commutative: $\vec{A} \times \vec{B} = -\vec{B} \times \vec{A}$
- **NOT** associative: $(\vec{A} \times \vec{A}) \times \vec{B} \neq \vec{A} \times (\vec{A} \times \vec{B})$
- Distributive: $\vec{A} \times (\vec{B} + \vec{C}) = (\vec{A} \times \vec{B}) + (\vec{A} \times \vec{C})$
- $\vec{A} \times \vec{A}$ = 0

## References
[[Introduction to Electrodynamics by David J. Griffiths - Chapter 1.pdf#page=3&selection=125,0,126,1|Introduction to Electrodynamics by David J. Griffiths - Chapter 1, p.3]]

***

Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Vectors/Vec.title: Dot Products
Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Vectors/Vec.content:
Dot Products
\begin{bmatrix} a_{1}\\ a_{2}\\ \vdots \\ a_{n}\end{bmatrix} \cdot \begin{bmatrix} b_{1} \\ b_{2} \\ \vdots \\ b_{n}\end{bmatrix} = a_{1}b_{1}+a_{2}b_{2}+\dots a_{n}b_{n} \quad (1)
An alternative definition is given by
\vec{a} \cdot \vec{b} = \lvert\vec{a}\rvert \times \lvert\vec{b}\rvert \times \cos{(\theta)} \quad (2)
where \theta is the angle between the vectors.
Properties


The dot product of two vectors is a scalar


For any vector: \vec{\textbf{A}} \cdot \vec{\textbf{A}} = A^{2}


Commutative: \vec{\textbf{A}} \cdot \vec{\textbf{B}} = \vec{\textbf{B}} \cdot \vec{\textbf{A}}. This can be seen by the definition.


The sign of a dot product is the same as the sign of the cosine of the angle between them. Therefore, the sign of a \cdot b is:



0 = positive if \theta < 90 ^{\circ}



= 0 if \theta = 90 ^{\circ}


< 0 = negative if \theta > 90 ^{\circ}


Therefore, the dot product can be used to give us information about the angle between two vectors. See Computing Angles.




Distributive: A \cdot (\vec{\textbf{B}} + \vec{\textbf{C}}) = \vec{\textbf{A}} \cdot \vec{\textbf{B}} + \vec{\textbf{A}} \cdot \vec{\textbf{C}}


If \vec{\textbf{A}} and \vec{\textbf{B}} are perpendicular, then \vec{\textbf{A}} \cdot \vec{\textbf{B}} = 0 (see Determining Orthogonality)


Computing Angles
Rearranging the second definition above, we find that
\cos{(\theta)} = \frac{\vec{a} \cdot \vec{b}}{\lvert\vec{a}\rvert \lvert\vec{b}\rvert}
This can be used if we are given two vectors and want to know the angle between them; simply calculate the dot product using (1) and divide by the product of the lengths. This method is proven in Angle Between Two Vectors.
Determining Orthogonality
If the dot product of two vectors is 0, they are orthogonal.
Take the equation x + 2y + 3z = 0. Consider a vector pointing to a point in space, \vec{OP} = (x, y, z). In order for the point OP to satisfy the equation it must be true that the dot product of \vec{OP} and \vec{A} = (1, 2, 3) equals 0, because \vec{OP} \cdot \vec{A} = x + 2y + 3z = 0. In this case, that means that \vec{OP} is orthogonal to \vec{A}. The set of points for which this is true defines a plane.
An easier example of this is that the horizontal plane could be defined as the set of points orthogonal to \hat{\textbf{k}}.


                  
                  Determine when points are at right angle 
                  
                

Let P = (a, 1, -1), Q = (0, 1, 1), and R = (a, -1, 3). At what values of a do the three points form a right angle \angle PQR?
Approach: Form vectors and solve for dot product equals 0.
Solution: Let \vec{QP} = (a, 0, -2) and \vec{QR} = (a, -2, 2). When the dot product of these two vectors \vec{QP} \cdot \vec{QR} = 0, the angle between them is 90 degrees.
\vec{QP} \cdot \vec{QR} = a^{2} + 0 - 4 = 0 \to \boxed{a = \pm 2}


Vector Components


                  
                  What is the component of \vec{A} along a unit vector \hat{\textbf{u}}?
                  
                

You can consider the right triangle formed with \vec{A} as hypotenuse, adjacent side in the direction of \hat{\textbf{u}}, and opposite side orthogonal to \hat{\textbf{u}} and connected to the tip of \vec{A}. In this triangle, \vec{A} and \hat{\textbf{u}} form an angle \theta. The length of the adjacent side, or the length along \hat{\textbf{u}}, is given by \cos{(\theta)} \vec{A}. Because \hat{\textbf{u}} is a unit vector, that is just the dot product \vec{A} \cdot \hat{\textbf{u}}.


References
Introduction to Electrodynamics by David J. Griffiths - Chapter 1, p.2
Tensor Dot Product

Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Vectors/Vec.title: Vector Intro
Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Vectors/Vec.content:
Vector Intro
A vector is something with a magnitude and direction.
For example, 5 mph is just a speed or a scalar value, but 5 mph east is velocity, and is a vector.
You can write vectors using \vec in LaTeX, like this: \vec{v}= (5, 0)
You can write vectors, and it is typical to do so, in a columunar manner like this:
\begin{bmatrix} v_{1}\\ \vdots \\ v_{n}\end{bmatrix}
The origin of a vector doesn’t necessarily matter, to measure if they are equivalent.
In a 2 dimensional vector, the first coordinate (top in a column) is typically the x-coordinate, and the second is the y-coordinate.
You can then determine the magnitude of the vector using the Pythagorean theorem.

Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Vectors/Vec.title: Length
Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Vectors/Vec.content:
Length
The length of a vector is denoted by bars, like this: || ||.
||\vec{a}|| = \sqrt{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\dots a_{n}^{2}}
This is just an application of the Pythagorean theorem, except that it extends into any number of dimensions.

Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Vectors/Vec.title: Vector Operations
Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Vectors/Vec.content:
Vector Operations
There are many operations which can be done to and with vectors.
Transclude of Vector-Addition
Transclude of Vector-Scalar-Multiplication
Transclude of Vector-Dot-Products
Transclude of Vector-Length
Transclude of Angle-Between-Two-Vectors
Transclude of Vector-Cross-Product
Transclude of Triple-Scalar-Product#triple-scalar-product

Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Vectors/Vec.title: Scalar Multiplication
Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Vectors/Vec.content:
Scalar Multiplication
\vec{a} \cdot c = \begin{bmatrix} c \cdot a_{1} \\ c \cdot a_{2} \\ \vdots \\ c \cdot a_{n} \end{bmatrix}
Conceptually, you can think of this as putting c copies of \vec{a} in a line. For positive c, the direction is the same, but the magnitude changes. For negative values of c, you go in the opposite direction.
Properties

Distributive: a(\vec{\textbf{A}} + \vec{\textbf{B}}) = a \vec{\textbf{A}} + a \vec{\textbf{B}}

References
Introduction to Electrodynamics by David J. Griffiths - Chapter 1, p.2

Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Vectors/Vec.title: Vectors
Concepts/Math/Linear-Algebra/Vectors/Vec.content:
Vectors
Vectors are the lifeblood of physics and linear algebra.
A physicist would introduce vectors as objects that have a magnitude (how big) and a direction (what way). For example, Velocity is a vector with a speed (a car goes 60 mph) and a direction (due north).
A computer scientist might introduce vectors as ordered lists of numbers. To a CS student, the list (1, 2, 3) is a vector.
Finally, another perspective to view vectors is as arrows on the coordinate plane, with the tail sitting at the origin, pointing towards some position in the plane. The components of the vector inform you how far you must walk along the axis’s, or more generally Unit Vectors, to reach that point.
All Rank 1 Tensors are vectors, but not all vectors are tensors.
We can do a lot of things with vectors. Some of them are described in Vector Operations.
References
www.3blue1brown.com/lessons/vectors

Concepts/Math/Math-Notation.title: Math Notation
Concepts/Math/Math-Notation.content:
\mathbb{R}^{n} means the n-dimensional real coordinate space. It represents all possible real valued n-tuples.
\in means that something is an element or member of something else, e.g:
\vec{x}=\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} \text{, }\vec{x}\in \mathbb{R}^3

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Der.title: Chain Rule for Multivariable Functions
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Der.content:
Chain Rule for Multivariable Functions
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
The Chain Rule for taking the derivatives of Multivariable Functions is


                  
                   Instantaneous Rate of Change of a Multivariable Function
                  
                

\frac{df}{dt} = f_{x} \frac{dx}{dt} + f_{y} \frac{dy}{dt} + f_{z} \frac{dz}{dt}
where x = x(t), y=y(t), z=z(t). See Parametric Equation.




                  
                  Alternative Notation 
                  
                

This can be alternatively written as \frac{dw}{dt} = \nabla w \cdot \frac{d\vec{r}}{dt}
where \nabla w is the Gradient Vector and \frac{d\vec{r}}{dt} represents the Velocity vector.


Justification
From the Total Differential, we can approximate that ![[Total md)#^ab22ed]]
If we look at the change for some time \Delta t, then we get
\frac{\Delta f}{\Delta t} = \frac{f_{x} \Delta x + f_{y} \Delta y + f_{z} \Delta z}{\Delta t}
and in the \lim_{t \to 0}, \frac{\Delta f}{\Delta t} = \frac{df}{dt} (see Derivative), as does \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} \to \frac{dx}{dt}, and so on. Therefore:
\lim_{t\to0} \text{ becomes } \frac{df}{dt} = f_{x} \frac{dx}{dt} + f_{y} \frac{dy}{dt} + f_{z} \frac{dz}{dt}
Examples


                  
                  1 - Chain Rule Example 
                  
                

Suppose that w = x^{3}yz + xy + z+3 and x = 3\cos{(t)}, \quad y= 3 \sin{(t)}, \quad z = 2t
Compute \frac{dw}{dt} and evaluate it at t = \frac{\pi}{2}.
Solution:
The partial derivatives are w_{x} = 3x^{2} yz, \quad w_{y} = x^{3}z + x, \quad w_{z} = x^{3} y + 1


and the derivatives of x, y, z are \frac{dx}{dt} = -3\sin{(t)}, \quad \frac{dy}{dt} = 3\cos{(t)}, \quad \frac{dz}{dt} = 2

Therefore the derivative is \frac{dw}{dt} = (3x^{2}yz + y)(-3\sin{(t)})+(x^{3}z + x)(3 \cos{(t)})+(x^{3}y + 1)(2)
At t = \frac{\pi}{2} we have x = 0, y =3, z= \pi, so
\frac{dw}{dt}|_\frac{\pi}{2} = 3(-3) + 3(0) + 1(2) = -7



                  
                  2 - Rewrite w first
                  
                

Suppose that w = x^{2}y + z, x = t, y = e^{t}, z = \sin{(t)}. Find the derivative \frac{dw}{dt}.
Solution:
First, we rewrite w as w(t) = t^{2}e^{t} + \sin{(t)}
Then we calculate the single-variable derivative of that:
\frac{dw}{dt} = 2te^{t} + t^{2}e^{t} + \cos{(t)}


Sometimes, using the technique shown in Example 2 is more effective than fully doing out the chain rule.
This can be used in the Proof of the Derivative Product Rule and the Proof of the Derivative Quotient Rule.
More Variables
Let w = f(x, y), where x = x(u, v) and y = y(u, v). Maybe these are functions in Polar Coordinates and Real Coordinate Spaces that need to be converted. Then w = f(x(u,v), y(u,v)). The Total Differential of w is
dw = w_{x}dx + w_{y}dy
But here dx is the Total Differential of x, and similarly for dy, so
dw &=  w_{x}(x_{u}du + x_{v}dv) + f_{y}(y_{u}du + y_{v}dv)\\
&= (f_{x}x_{u} + f_{y}y_{u})du + (f_{x}x_{v} + f_{y}y_{v})dv\\
&= f_{u} du + f_{v} dv
\end{aligned}$$
Therefore, $$\frac{\partial f}{\partial u} = \frac{\partial f}{\partial x} \frac{\partial x}{\partial u} + \frac{\partial f}{\partial y} \frac{\partial y}{\partial u}$$
and 
$$\frac{\partial f}{\partial v} = \frac{\partial f}{\partial x} \frac{\partial x}{\partial v} + \frac{\partial f}{\partial y}\frac{\partial y}{\partial v}$$
This is telling us how much the function $f$ changes for a tiny nudge in $u$ or $v$ respectively. 

>[!warning] You can't cancel out the $\partial x$ and $\partial y$, because they are [[Partial Derivatives]]!
> 

#### Example
>[!example] Polar Coordinates
> 
>Let  $\begin{array}{lcl} x = r \cos{(\theta)}\\ y = r \sin{(\theta)} \end{array}$, and $f = f(x, y)$. Then we can find $$\frac{\partial f}{\partial r} = \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}\frac{\partial x}{\partial r} + \frac{\partial f}{\partial y} \frac{\partial y}{\partial r} = f_{x} \cos{(\theta)} + f_{y} \sin{(\theta)}$$

## Formulation using Einstein Notation
Suppose $w = f(u_{1}, u_{2}, \dots, u_{n})$, where $u_{i} = u_{i}(x_{1}, x_{2}, \dots, x_{n})$. $i$ is an integer index from 1 to $n$. In simpler terms, $w$ is a function that depends on $u_{1}, u_{2}, \dots, u_{n}$, where each of those variables $u_{i}$ itself depends on other variables $x_{1}, x_{2}, \dots, x_{n}$. When we take the derivative of this function $w$, we must take into account the rate at which $w$ changes due to a nudge in each of $u_{i}$; but we must also consider the rate at which $u_{i}$ changes due to a nudge in each of $x_{j}$. We succinctly summarize this mathematically, using [[Einstein Notation]], as 

$$\boxed{\frac{\partial w}{\partial x_{j}} = \frac{\partial f}{\partial u_{i}} \frac{\partial u_{i}}{\partial x_{j}}}$$

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Der.title: Constrained Differentials
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Der.content:
Constrained Differentials
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
This is simply the application of Partial Differentiation with Dependent Variables.


                  
                  Constrained Differential 
                  
                

Consider a right triangle with base a, hypotenuse b, and angle between them \theta. The area of the triangle is A = \frac{1}{2}\text{base * height} = \frac{1}{2}ab \sin{(\theta)}, and the sides are constrained by a = b \cos{(\theta)}. What is the rate of change of A with respect to \theta?
Solution:
If we ignore the constraint, then we just need to find \left(\frac{\partial A}{\partial \theta}\right)_{a,b} = \frac{1}{2} ab \cos{(\theta)}. This would lose the right angle though. Instead, we have two options:

Keep a constant:
First, note that if a is constant b must be changing and then b = a/\cos{(\theta)}.
\left(\frac{\partial A}{\partial \theta}\right)_{a} = \frac{\partial}{\partial \theta}\left(\frac{1}{2} a^{2} \tan{(\theta)}\right) = \frac{1}{2} a^{2} \sec^{2}{(\theta)}
Keep b constant:
Same technique yields \frac{1}{2}b^{2}(\cos^{2}{(\theta)} - \sin^{2}{(\theta)})



The technique used in that example is very trivial though, and only works in the easy situations where we can just express one variable in terms of the other. That isn’t always possible. The better method is using Total Differential.
Differentials Method
Continuing with the example from above, we know that \left(\frac{\partial A}{\partial \theta}\right)_{a} means to keep a fixed, so the rate of change of a is 0: da = 0. The constraint is that a = b \cos{(\theta)}, so da = \cos{(\theta)} db - b \sin{(\theta)} d \theta = 0 using the Derivative Product Rule. Solving that,
\cos{(\theta)} db  = b \sin{(\theta)}d \theta \to db = b \tan{(\theta)} d \theta
Our Total Differential of A is
dA &=  \frac{1}{2}b \sin{(\theta)}da + \frac{1}{2} a \sin{(\theta)} db + \frac{1}{2} ab \cos{(\theta)} d \theta\\
&= \frac{1}{2}a \sin{(\theta)} db + \frac{1}{2}ab \cos{(\theta)} d\theta\\
&= \frac{1}{2}a \sin{(\theta)}(b \tan{(\theta)}d \theta) + \frac{1}{2} ab \cos{(\theta)} d \theta\\
&= \frac{1}{2} ab (\sin{\theta}\tan{\theta} + \cos{(\theta)})\\
&= \frac{1}{2}ab \sec{(\theta)}\\
\end{aligned}$$
This is equivalent to our previous answer (using $b = \frac{a}{\cos{\theta}}$), but found in a more general way.

Summary:
- Write one differential (say $dx$) in terms of the others
- Set that differential to 0, $dx = 0$
- Solve for $dy$ in terms of $dz$ using [[Total Differential]].


***

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Der.title: Curl Operator
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Der.content:
Curl Operator
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
For a Vector Field \vec{F} = \langle M, N \rangle, curl is defined as:
\text{curl}(\vec{F}) = N_{x} - M_{y}
For Conservative Forces, \text{curl}(\vec{F}) = 0. This is another way to represent the test for exactness (also see Gradient Field).  
Intuition


Curl is a way of measuring the rotation at a point in a Vector Field representing Velocity

This quantity is also called the vorticity, and is a measure of Angular Velocity



Curl is a function of x, y, which means the amount of curl depends on the location


If you consider the curl of a wind vector field, areas of highest curl are most likely to be storms, hurricanes, etc.


The sign of the curl tells you whether you are going clockwise or counterclockwise.


In a Vector Field representing Force, curl instead measures how much Torque is being exhibited on a point


It still depends on the point (x,y)


In Space
Let \vec{\textbf{F}} = P \hat{\textbf{i}} + Q \hat{\textbf{j}} + R \hat{\textbf{k}} be differentiable. Then, \text{curl}(\vec{\textbf{F}}) = (R_{y} - Q_{z})\hat{\textbf{i}} + (P_{z} - R_{x}) \hat{\textbf{j}} + (Q_{x} - P_{y}) \hat{\textbf{k}}
This is a easy way to write the condition for Gradient Fields in Space: a force is conservative if \text{curl} (\vec{\textbf{F}}) = 0, because in this case P_{y} = Q_{x}, P_{z} = R_{x}, and R_{y}= Q_{z}.
Shorthand
Using the Del Notation, we can define curl in space as a Vector Cross Product:
\text{curl}(\vec{F}) = \nabla \times \vec{F} = \begin{vmatrix} \hat{\textbf{i}} & \hat{\textbf{j}} & \hat{\textbf{k}} \\ \frac{\partial}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial}{\partial y} & \frac{\partial}{\partial z} \\ P & Q & R\end{vmatrix}
if \vec{F} = \langle P, Q, R \rangle.
Properties

If f(x,y,z) has continuous second order partial derivatives, then \text{curl}(\nabla f) = 0
If \vec{F} is a conservative vector field then \text{curl}(\vec{F}) = 0

Usage
Curl is used in Greens Theorem to make line integrals easier to solve.

References

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Der.title: Del Notation
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Der.content:
Del Notation
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
The \nabla character, pronounced del, is used in the shorthand notation for Gradient Vector, Divergence Operator, and the Curl Operator. Specifically, we define \nabla = \left\langle \frac{\partial}{\partial x}, \frac{\partial}{\partial y}, \frac{\partial}{\partial z} \right\rangle
Then, we use this definition to create the:

Gradient Operator
Divergence Operator
Curl Operator


References
1802SC - Multivariable Calculus - Session 85

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Der.title: Directional Derivatives
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Der.content:
Directional Derivatives
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
The Partial Derivatives of a Multivariable Function give the rate of change in the direction of unit vectors. Explicitly, if you consider w = w(x, y), then w_{x} goes in \hat{\textbf{i}} and w_{y} goes in \hat{\textbf{j}}. Directional derivatives tell us the rate of change when we move in the direction of any arbitrary unit vector \hat{\textbf{u}}.


                  
                  Directional Derivative 
                  
                

The derivative along a direction \hat{\textbf{u}} is \frac{dw}{ds|_{\hat{\textbf{u}}}} = \nabla w \cdot \hat{\textbf{u}}
That is the component of the Gradient along the direction \hat{\textbf{u}}.


Proof
See [[18_02SC Note.
Example


                  
                  Finding the direction of maximum speed 
                  
                

By the above definition, the derivative is fastest when \nabla w \cdot \hat{\textbf{u}} = 1, which occurs when \cos{(\theta)} = 1 \to \theta = 0 \to \hat{\textbf{u}} = \text{dir}(\nabla w).


By the inverse of the above, the velocity is slowest when \theta = 180^{\circ}.
There is no movement when \frac{dw}{ds} = 0, which occurs when \theta = 90 ^{\circ}, in which case \hat{\textbf{u}} \perp \nabla w, which means that we are on a level curve (Proof of Gradient Vector Perpendicularity).

References
1802SC - Multivariable Calculus - Session 38
18_02SC Notes- Directional Derivatives

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Der.title: Divergence Operator
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Der.content:
Divergence Operator
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
The divergence (\text{div}) operator of a Vector Field is given by \text{div}\langle P, Q, R\rangle = P_{x} + Q_{y} + R_{z}
The operator is written in Del Notation as \text{div}(\vec{\textbf{F}}) = \nabla \cdot \vec{\textbf{F}}
which is the Vector Dot Products between \vec{\textbf{F}} and the \nabla operator.
Physical Intepretation
Divergence measures how much the flow of a vector field is “expanding.” It could also be said to be the “source rate,” meaning the amount of fluid being added to the system per unit time and per unit area. This makes sense in the Divergence Theorem.
Properties

Distributive: \nabla \cdot (\vec{\textbf{A}} + \vec{\textbf{B}}) = (\nabla \cdot \vec{\textbf{A}}) + (\nabla \cdot \vec{\textbf{B}})
Constants can be pulled out: \nabla \cdot (k \vec{\textbf{A}}) = k(\nabla \cdot \vec{\textbf{A}})
Scalar-Vector Product Rule: \nabla \cdot (f \vec{\textbf{A}}) = f(\nabla \cdot \vec{\textbf{A}}) + \vec{\textbf{A}} \cdot (\nabla f)1
Vector-Vector Product Rule: \nabla \cdot (\vec{\textbf{A}} \times \vec{\textbf{B}}) = \vec{\textbf{B}} \cdot (\nabla \times \vec{\textbf{A}}) - \vec{\textbf{A}} \cdot (\nabla \times \vec{\textbf{B}})2


References

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Der.title: Divergence Theorem
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Der.content:
Divergence Theorem
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
The divergence theorem is the 3D analogue of Green’s Theorem for Flux. Consider a closed surface S enclosing a region D. Let the vector \hat{\textbf{n}} be the normal vector pointing outward at any point. Let a Vector Field \vec{\textbf{F}} be defined and differentiable everywhere in D. Then, the Flux in Three Dimensions is given by the Triple Integrals: $$
\newcommand{\oiint}{{\subset!\supset} \llap{\iint}} \oiint \vec{\textbf{F}} \cdot d \vec{\textbf{S}} = \iiint_{D} \text{div}(\vec{\textbf{F}}) d V
note the [[Surface Integrals|Surface Integral]] and the [[Divergence Operator]].

Because the divergence measures how much material is entering the region or how much it is expanding, it makes sense that the amount that flows (the flux) out is equal to the divergence. Matter has to come from somewhere. This explanation breaks down a little bit for force fields.

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Der.title: Gradient Field
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Der.content:
Gradient Field
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
A gradient field is a special case of the vector field where \vec{\textbf{F}} = \langle M, N \rangle = \nabla f where M and N are some functions of x, y. That means that M = f_{x} and N = f_{y}. If M and N describe a Gradient, then their second Partial Derivatives should be equivalent; or, f_{xy} = f_{yx} \Longrightarrow M_{y} = N_{x}
This is recognizable as the criterion for an Exact Differential Equations.


                  
                  Is a Vector Field a Gradient? 
                  
                

If a vector field \vec{\textbf{F}} = \langle M, N \rangle is defined and differentiable everywhere and M_{y} = N_{x}, then \vec{\textbf{F}} is a gradient field and therefore the Fundamental Theorem of Line Integrals can be applied.


Transclude of Gradient-Fields-in-Space#gradient-fields-in-space

References
1802SC - Multivariable Calculus - Session 63

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Der.title: Gradient Fields in Space
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Der.content:
Gradient Fields in Space
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
Test
In the plane, we have a simple test for whether a Vector Field is a Gradient Field: it must be an exact. In space, if we have a vector field \vec{\textbf{F}} = \langle P, Q, R \rangle, and we want to know if it is the Gradient of some Potential Function \langle f_{x}, f_{y}, f_{z} \rangle, we must perform a more complex test. The conditions are, if the vector field is continuous on a simply connected region:
P_{y} = f_{xy} = f_{yx} = Q_{x}\\
P_{z} = f_{xz} = f_{zx}=R_{x}\\
Q_{z}=f_{yz}=f_{zy}=R_{y}
\end{aligned}$$
Simply put, the mixed partials must be equal. This is just the definition of an [[Differential|exact differential]].


***

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Der.title: Gradient Vector
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Der.content:
Gradient Vector
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
The gradient vector is a succinct notation for representing all of the Partial Derivatives of Multivariable Functions.
\nabla f = \langle f_{x}, f_{y}, f_{z}\rangle
this is read “gradient of f”
It can be evaluated at a point P_{0} = (x_{0}, y_{0}). This is written as
\text{grad }w(x_{0}, y_{0}) = \nabla w|_{P_{0}} = \nabla W|_{0} = \left\langle\frac{\partial w}{\partial x}|_{0}, \frac{\partial w}{\partial y}|_{0}\right\rangle
Properties 1

\nabla(\text{function} f) \to \text{vector(numbers)}
For w = f(x, y), \nabla w \perp f(x, y) = c. That is, the gradient vector is perpendicular to the Level Curves. See Proof of Gradient Vector Perpendicularity
The direction of \nabla w is the direction of fastest increase of w: |\nabla w| = \frac{dw}{ds|_{\hat{\textbf{u}}=\text{dir}(\nabla w)}}. See Directional Derivatives. 2 
The zeroes of the gradient signify stationary points.

That allows us to use it sorta like First Derivative Test, as see in Multivariable Optimization Problems.



Examples
Gradient Operator

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Der.title: Lagrange Multipliers
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Der.content:
Lagrange Multipliers
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
Lagrange Multipliers are a technique for finding constrained optimization problems. Consider a function f(x,y) for which you want to find extrema. But, you are constrained to lie on some curve or surface defined by another function g(x, y) = c. The solution is a point where the gradient vector of f is parallel with the gradient of g; that is a point where \nabla f = \lambda \nabla g
\lambda is called the Lagrange multiplier.
The trick with these problems is that solving the simultaneous equations given is sometimes very challenging.


                  
                  Downfall 
                  
                

Lagrange Multipliers don’t tell us whether the found point is a maximum or minimum! We don’t have second Directional Derivatives, so we can’t use Second Derivative Test. We just use trial and error.


Example


                  
                  Lagrange Multiplier to Minimize 
                  
                

Consider a box made of cardboard with double thottom, single thick front and back, and no top. It’s volume is fixed at 3. What dimensions use the least amount of cardboard?
Solution:
The total amount of cardboard used w = f(x,y,z) = \text{sides} + \text{front/back} + \text{bottom} = 4yz + 2xz + 3xy. The constraint is V = xyz = 3. The Gradients are \nabla f = \langle2z + 3y, 4z + 3x, 4y + 2x\rangle \quad \nabla V = \langle yz, xz, xy\rangle. Therefore we must solve the system of equations \nabla f = \lambda \nabla V, and V = 3 which becomes \frac{2}{y} + \frac{3}{z} = \frac{4}{x} + \frac{3}{z} = \frac{4}{x} + \frac{2}{y}
which yields xyz = 3 \to 3y^{3} = 3 \to y = 1, and then back substitution gives x = 2, z = \frac{3}{2}, and therefore w = 18.


Proof
See [[Pr.

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Der.title: Least Squares Interpolation
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Der.content:
Least Squares Interpolation
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
Linear
There are many possible ways to find the “best” linear equation ax + b to fit a data sit (x_{i}, y_{i}). Least squares is a method to do this by defining “best” as the line that minimizes total square deviation.
Steps
The deviation for each data point is the difference between the actual data point and the predicted, y_{i} - (ax_{i} + b), then our goal is to minimize
D(a, b) = \sum\limits_{i=1}^{n} \left[y_{i} - (ax_{i} + b)\right]^{2}
Then, we can treat this as a optimization problem. First, we try to find the critical points:
\frac{\partial D}{\partial a} = -2x_{i}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}[y_{i} - (ax_{i} + b)] = 0 \longrightarrow \sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}(x_{i}^{2} a + x_{i} + x_{i}y_{i}) = 0
\frac{\partial D}{\partial b} = -2 \sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}[(y_{i} - (ax_{i} + b))] = 0 \longrightarrow \sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}(x_{i}a + b - y_{i}) = 0
Notice that the latter is just a x_{i} multiple of the former. This becomes
\left(\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n} x_{i}^{2}\right)a + \left(\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n} x_{i}\right)b = \sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}x_{i}y_{i}
\left(\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n} x_{i}\right) a + nb = \sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}y_{i}
This is just a 2x2 Linear Systems, so we can solve for (a, b).
Generalization
The steps that can be used to find a linear system can be generalized to other functions, like exponentials or quadratics.

References

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Der.title: Partial Derivatives
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Der.content:
Partial Derivatives
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
Partial derivatives are a way of talking about the rate of change of Multivariable Functions. They are called “partial” because we only care about “part” of the inputs. Partial derivatives are represented by the curly “d” called the “partial symbol” \partial. The alternative notation, often used in applied mathematics, is subscripts, such that \frac{\partial f}{\partial x} = f_{x}
Definition
\frac{\partial f(x_{0},y_{0})}{\partial x} = \lim_{\Delta x \to 0} \frac{f(x_{0} + \Delta x, y_{0}) - f(x_{0}, y_{0})}{\Delta x}
\frac{\partial f(x_{0},y_{0})}{\partial y} = \lim_{\Delta y \to 0} \frac{f(x_{0}, y_{0} + \Delta y) - f(x_{0}, y_{0})}{\Delta y}
Notably, not all functions are differentiable.
Computing Partial Derivatives
To actually take a partial derivative, we almost always do it by simply treating the variables not “active” as constants.


                  
                  Partial Derivative of f(x, y) = x^{2} + y^{2}
                  
                

The partial with respect to x of f is \frac{\partial f}{\partial x} = 2x
This is found by letting y be constant. Obviously, the derivative of a constant is 0, so we just take the derivative of x^{2} to yield 2x.




                  
                  Beware the Curly! 
                  
                

You can’t cancel out partial derivatives in the same way you would “straight” ds. For example, you might have \frac{\partial f}{\partial x} \frac{\partial x}{\partial u}, but you CANNOT simplify to \frac{\partial f}{\partial u}. You can think of it as the partials being complete units that can’t be broken, because they mean nothing without the other part.



References
ocw.mit.edu/courses/18-02sc-multivariable-calculus-fall-2010/resources/clip-partial-derivatives/

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Der.title: Partial Differentiation with Dependent Variables
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Der.content:
Partial Differentiation with Dependent Variables
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
Consider a classic example in thermodynamics where we have a function f(p, v, T) where p is pressure, v is volume, and T is temperature. These three variables are related to each other (non-independent) by the Ideal Gas Law. In these cases, we can quickly get a contradiction or error because \frac{\partial f}{\partial p} is not well defined; you can’t hold v and T constant while changing p because of the constraint. Accordingly, we create a special notation that specifies what is “constant” specifically:
\left(\frac{\partial f}{\partial p}\right)_{T}
would mean the rate of change of f with respect to p when temperature is held constant. Therefore, v must vary.

References

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Der.content:
Saddle Points
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
Saddle points are critical points that are local maximums in one direction and local minimums in another direction.

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Der.title: Smoothness Hypothesis
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Der.content:
Smoothness Hypothesis
Topic: Partial Derivatives
If the graph of a function f(x, y) is a “smooth surface,” it doesn’t have any sharp points, folds, or generally look peculiar. More mathematically, we say that


                  
                  Smoothness Hypothesis 
                  
                

f(x,y) is smooth at (x_{0}, y_{0}) if
f_{x} \text{ and } f_{y} \text{ are continuous in some rectangle centered at } (x_{0}, y_{0})


Generally this just means that the partial derivative(s) fails to exist at a point (x_{0}, y_{0}), e.g. by division by 0.

References
ocw.mit.edu/courses/18-02sc-multivariable-calculus-fall-2010/resources/mit18_02sc_mnotes_ta4/

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Der.title: Tangent Plane
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Der.content:
Tangent Plane
Topic: Partial Derivatives
For a function of one variable, z = f(x), there is a tangent line to its graph at a point (x_{0}, y_{0}) with slope \frac{dy_{0}}{dx_{0}}. The space analogue is the tangent plane at a point (x_{0}, y_{0}, z_{0}), which masses through that point and contains the tangent lines to the graphs of the two partial functions.


                  
                  Equation of a Tangent Plane 
                  
                

The equation of the tangent plane to z = f(x, y) at (x_{0}, y_{0}) is
z - z_{0} = \left(\frac{\partial z}{\partial x}\right)_{0}(x - x_{0}) + \left(\frac{\partial z}{\partial y}\right)_{0}(y - y_{0})
or
\Delta z = \left(\frac{\partial z}{\partial x}\right)_{0}\Delta x + \left(\frac{\partial z}{\partial y}\right)_{0}\Delta y


Approximations using the Tangent Plane
The tangent plane offers a great and intuitive way to approximate the function z = f(x, y) near the point (x_{0}, y_{0}, z_{0}). The idea is simply that if you stay near that point, the graph of the tangent plane will be a good approximation. Therefore,
f(x, y) \approx z_{0} + \left(\frac{\partial z}{\partial x}\right)_{0}(x - x_{0}) + \left(\frac{\partial z}{\partial y}\right)_{0}(y - y_{0})

References
ocw.mit.edu/courses/18-02sc-multivariable-calculus-fall-2010/resources/mit18_02sc_mnotes_ta2_3/

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Der.title: Total Differential
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Der.content:
Total Differential
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
Total Differential
The total differential of a Multivariable Functions is given by its Partial Derivatives along each input times a Differential of that input; e.g. for f(x,y,z):
df = f_{x} dx + f_{y}dy + f_{z}dy


                  
                   df is NOT \Delta f
                  
                

The total differential “encodes” how changes in x, y, z affect f, but it does not tell us how much f will change.


You can think of it as placeholders for small variations, \Delta x, \Delta y, \Delta z to get an Approximation Formula:

\Delta f \approx f_{x} \Delta x + f_{y} \Delta y + f_{z} \Delta z


The real use for this is to “divide” by something like dt to get a rate of change of the function f, that is, the Chain Rule for Multivariable Functions.
Examples


                  
                  Total Differential Example 
                  
                

Find the total differential of w = x^{3} yz + xy + z + 3 at (1,2,3).
Solution:
First, we calculate the partial derivatives and evaluate them at the given point:
w_{x} = 3x^{2}yz + y, \quad w_{y} = x^{3}z + x, \quad w_{z} = x^{3}y + 1
(w_{x})_{0} = 20, \quad (w_{y})_{0} = 4, \quad (w_{z})_{0} = 3
Therefore dw = 20dx + 4dy + 3dz


Relation to the Dot Product
In Introduction to Electrodynamics by David J. Griffiths - Chapter 1, p.14, Griffiths makes the connection that the total differential is really like a dot product between the infinitesimal displacement d \vec{\textbf{l}} and the Gradient Vector. That is,
df = \vec{\nabla} f \cdot d \vec{\textbf{l}} = | \vec{\nabla} T | | d \vec{\textbf{l}} | \cos{(\theta)} 
Since the gradient is so ubiquitous, this is a nice way to remember the total. This also helps with the intuition for this property: ^b73736.

References
1802SC - Multivariable Calculus - Session 32

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Int.title: Applications of Triple Integrals
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Int.content:
Applications of Triple Integrals
Topic: Multivariable Calculus

The mass of an object, given some density \delta = \frac{M}{V}, is \text{Mass} = \iiint_{R}\delta dV
Average value of a function of x, y, z in the region R: \bar{f} = \frac{1}{\text{Vol(r)}}\iiint_{R} f dV
Weighted average: \frac{1}{\text{Mass}(R)}\iiint_{R} f \delta dV
Volumetric
Moment of Inertia

1802SC - Multivariable Calculus - Session 76

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Int.title: Change of Variables in Double Integrals
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Int.content:
Change of Variables in Double Integrals
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
When evaluating Double Integrals, sometimes you need to change the coordinate system. For example, from Cartesian Coordinates to Curvilinear Coordinates.


                  
                  Motivation: Finding the Area of an Ellipse 
                  
                

An ellipse is given by the equation \frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}} + \frac{y^{2}}{b^{2}} = 1. What is the area of the ellipse?
Solution:
Finding the bounds of integration for this is very difficult. What we can do is rescale it into some other coordinate system xy \Rightarrow uv where the ellipse becomes the unit circle. This is done by simp\iinting u = \frac{x}{a}, v = \frac{y}{b}, so du = \frac{1}{a}dx, dv = \frac{1}{b}dy. This yields dudv = \frac{1}{ab}dxdy \Rightarrow dxdy = ab du dv
The area is then given by the double integral ab\iint\limits_{u^{2} + v^{2} \leq 1}  du dv = \pi ab


This is a great way to make ing the bounds of integration findable or the integrand doable.
In General
We find the equations u = u(x, y) and v = v(x, y). Then, we can approximate that \Delta u = u_{x}\Delta x + u_{y} \Delta y and \Delta v = v_{x}\Delta x + v_{y} \Delta y (see Partial Derivatives). This can be written as
\begin{bmatrix}\Delta u \\ \Delta v \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} u_{x} & u_{y} \\ v_{x} & v_{y} \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}\Delta x \\ \Delta y\end{bmatrix}
For linear transformations, the change in area dA \Longrightarrow dA' is scaled by the determinant of the above 2x2 matrix. This scaling factor is called the Jacobian.
Examples


                  
                  Change of Variables 
                  
                

Arbitrary example: compute \int\limits_{0}^{1}\int\limits_{0}^{1}x^{2}ydxdy by changing u=x and v = xy.
Solution:
First, we compute the Jacobian: J = \begin{vmatrix}1 & 0 \\ y & x \end{vmatrix} = x = u. That, by definition, yields dudv = xdxdy. Therefore, our integrand becomes v dudv. Bounds are the confusing part. In the inner integral, we hold v constant, so we hold xy constant. Our lower bound is y = \frac{v}{u} = 1, so u = v, and our upper inner bound is u = 1. For the outer integral, we just want to look at all the hyperbolas from xy = 0 to xy = 1, so v =0 to v = 1. From all that, our integral is \int\limits_{0}^{1} \int\limits_{1}^{v} v du dv



References
1802SC - Multivariable Calculus - Session 53

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Int.title: Double Integrals Applications
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Int.content:
Double Integrals Applications


                  
                  Finding Area of Region 
                  
                

Another great use of double integrals is finding the area of a complex region in the plane. This is simply done by \iint_{R}1 dA




                  
                  Mass of a Flat Object with Density \delta
                  
                

If \delta is the mass per unit area, then the mass of a total object can be found by summing a bunch of small masses dm = \delta dA: \iint_{R}\delta dA
If \delta is constant, then you can just pull this out.




                  
                  Average Value 
                  
                

The average over a continous data set is found by integrating over the entire set and then dividing by the size, which is the area. That is, if the points are all equal weight, \bar{f} = \frac{\iint_{R}{f dA}}{\iint_{R}{dA}}




                  
                  Weighted Average Value 
                  
                

In the same vein as the average value formula above, we can find the weighted average of f. Let \delta(x,y) denote the weights. Then the weighted average of f is then: \frac{1}{\text{Mass}(R)} \iint_{R}{f\delta dA} = \frac{1}{\iint_{R} \delta dA} \iint_{R} f \delta dA
A great use is to find the Center of Mass.




                  
                  Moment of Inertia 
                  
                

Moment of Inertia calculations can be made much easier with double integrals.



References
1802SC - Multivariable Calculus - Sessions 51, 52

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Int.title: Double Integrals in Polar Coordinates
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Int.content:
Double Integrals in Polar Coordinates
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
When you convert from taking a Double Integrals in Cartesian Coordinates to an equivalent one in Polar Coordinates, you can’t just say that dA = drd\theta. This is because the equivalent small rectangle dA actually has an area of r dr d \theta. See Jacobian.


                  
                  Example of Double Integral in Polar Coordinates 
                  
                

Consider f(x,y) = 1 - x^{2} - y^{2}. What is the volume beneath this curve on the region 0 \leq x \leq 1 and 0 \leq y \leq 1?
Solution:
You could do this in xy, doing the “iterated” integral \int\limits_{0}^{1}\int\limits_{0}^{1}{1-x^{2}-y^{2}dydx}
However the result is quite difficulty involving a integration of \cos^{4}{}. Instead we can convert to polar coordinates.
V = \int\limits_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{2}}\int\limits_{0}^{1}{(1 - r^{2})r dr d \theta} = \int\limits_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{2}}{\left[\frac{r^{2}}{2} - \frac{r^{4}}{4}\right]_{0}^{1}d \theta} = \frac{\pi}{8}



References
1802SC - Multivariable Calculus - Session 50

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Int.title: Double Integrals
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Int.content:
Double Integrals
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
Double integrals, are, as the name suggests, repeated integrals. The give the volume beneath a surface, just as Integrals give the area under a curve. Conceptually, the process of taking double integrals is like taking slices along one axis, and then summing all of the slices to get the total volume.
V = \iint_{R} f(x,y)dA = \int\limits_{x_{min}}^{x_{max}}{\left(\int\limits_{y_{min}(x)}^{y_{max}(x)}{(f(x,y))dy}\right)dx}
Note that:

We can exchange the variables of integration; that is do dy before dx, or vice versa
The bounds of integration of the inner integral must be a function of the other variable

See:

Double Integrals in Polar Coordinates

Transclude of Double-Integral-Applications

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Int.title: Flux in Three Dimensions
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Int.content:
Flux in Three Dimensions
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
Much like Flux in Two Dimensions, we can describe how much a force goes through a surface. The two dimensional flux integral \int_{C} \vec{\textbf{F}} \cdot \hat{\textbf{n}} dsbecomes the surface integral \iint\limits_{S}^{}{\vec{\textbf{F}} \cdot d\vec{S}}
where dS stands for the surface area element with a direction decided by the orientation of the surface.
General Surface
For a generalized surface z = f(x, y), it can be shown that n \cdot dS = d\vec{S} = \pm \langle -z_{x}, -z_{y}, 1 \rangle dxdy
where the \pm is resolved by the orientation chosen.
If we have a vector field given by some potential function F(x, y, z) = c and a surface z = f(x, y), then it can be written as n \cdot dS = \pm \frac{\nabla F}{F_{x}}dxdy
Other Ways to find \hat{\textbf{n}}dS
Suppose S is a surface parametrized by two variables u and v, such that \langle x, y, z \rangle = \vec{r} = \vec{r}(u, v). Or, you could say,
S = \begin{cases} x = x(u,v)  \\ y = y(u,v) \\ z = z(u, v)\end{cases}
In this case, when we change u by a little bit, the surface changes by \frac{\partial \vec{r}}{\partial u}\Delta u, and the same for v. The integrating element is given by \boxed{\hat{\textbf{n}}dS = \pm \left(\frac{\partial \vec{r}}{\partial u} \times \frac{\partial \vec{r}}{\partial v}\right)\Delta u \Delta v}
If instead we know any normal vector \vec{N} to the surface (e.g. Equations of Planes or Proof of Gradient Vector Perpendicularity), then \boxed{\hat{\textbf{n}}dS = \frac{\vec{N}}{\vec{N} \cdot \hat{\textbf{k}}}dxdy}
To visualize that, think about a slanted plane S being projected down onto the xy-plane. The xy-plane has a normal vector of \hat{\textbf{k}}, and the slanted plane has a normal vector of \vec{N}. The area of S projected onto the xy-plane is A = S \cos{(\alpha)}, where \alpha is the angle between them. That is just given by \cos{(\alpha)} = \frac{\vec{N} \cdot \hat{\textbf{k}}}{|\vec{N}| |\hat{\textbf{k}}|} (see Vector Dot Products, Angle Between Two Vectors, Equations of Planes). Therefore, the surface element is \Delta S = \frac{|\vec{N}|}{\vec{N}\cdot \hat{\textbf{k}}}\Delta A
which, when taken in the limit and multiplied by \hat{\textbf{n}}, gives the equation above.
Examples


                  
                  Example 1: Sphere 
                  
                

Consider a sphere centered at the origin with radius a. What is the flux of a force \vec{\textbf{H}} = z \hat{\textbf{k}} through the sphere?
Solution:
First, our unit normal vector at any point is \hat{\textbf{n}} = \frac{\langle x, y, z\rangle}{a}. Therefore \vec{\textbf{H}} \cdot \hat{\textbf{n}} = \langle 0, 0, z\rangle \cdot \frac{\langle x, y, z\rangle}{a} = \frac{z^{2}}{a}
So the flux is \iint_{S} \vec{\textbf{H}} \cdot \hat{\textbf{n}}dS = \frac{1}{a} \iint_{S} z^{2} dS
We need to then determine dS in terms of two variables. Since a is constant, we could determine position as a function of \theta and \phi. From Spherical Coordinates, we know that the surface element is dS = \rho^{2} \sin{(\phi)} d\phi d\theta = a^{2} \sin{(\phi)} d\phi d\theta. Also, z = a \cos{(\phi)}. So then we integrate \text{Flux} = a^{3} \int\limits_{0}^{2 \pi} \int\limits_{0}^{ \pi}{\cos^{2}{(\phi)} \sin{(\phi)} d\phi d\theta} = \frac{4}{3} \pi a^{3}
Would you look at that? That is the Volume of a Sphere.



References
1802SC - Multivariable Calculus - Session 80

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Int.title: Flux in Two Dimensions
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Int.content:
Flux in Two Dimensions
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
Along a plane curve C and a Vector Field \vec{\textbf{F}}, the flux of \vec{\textbf{F}} across C is defined as the Line Integral
\int_{C} \vec{\textbf{F}} \cdot \hat{\textbf{n}} ds
where \hat{\textbf{n}} is the unit normal vector to any point on the curve C, always pointing clockwise from the tangent vector \hat{\textbf{T}}. We can write Work as the line integral
\int_{C} \vec{\textbf{F}} \cdot \hat{\textbf{T}}ds
which means the amount of force along the curve, while flux is how much the force is going across the curve.
The idea is clearly related to Electric Flux.
Interpretation
If you consider \vec{\textbf{F}} to be a velocity field, say water flowing, then flux is a measurement of how much fluid passes through the curve C per unit time.
This can be visualized as the paraellogram traced out by the fluid moving through a small straight section of the curve of base \Delta s and sides \vec{\textbf{F}}, such that the height is \vec{\textbf{F}} \cdot \hat{\textbf{n}}.
Calculation Using Components
It is known that d \vec{r} = \hat{\textbf{T}} ds = \langle dx, dy \rangle. \hat{\textbf{n}} is \hat{\textbf{T}} rotated by 90 degrees clockwise, so \hat{\textbf{n}}ds = \langle dy, -dx \rangle. So, if \vec{\textbf{F}} = \langle P, Q \rangle, then the Line Integral is \int_{C} \vec{\textbf{F}} \cdot \hat{\textbf{n}}ds = \int_{C} \langle P, Q \rangle \ cdot \langle dy, -dx \rangle = \int_{C} -Q dx  + Pdy
Then we parameterize Q, P, dx, and dy to bring everything into one integral.

References
1802SC - Multivariable Calculus - Session 69

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Int.title: Fundamental Theorem of Line Integrals
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Int.content:
Fundamental Theorem of Line Integrals
Topic: Multivariable Calculus


                  
                  Basic Idea 
                  
                

The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus tells us that if we integrate a derivative, you get back the original function. In Multivariable Calculus, there is an equivalent statement: if you take the line integral of a Gradient Field, you get back the function.


If the Vector Fields of a Line Integral is \vec{\textbf{F}} = \nabla f, it is called the Gradient field. In this case, we can simplify our line integral greatly: \int\limits_{C}^{}{\nabla f \cdot d\vec{r}} = f(P_{1}) - f(P_{0})
where the curve C brings us from P_{0} to P_{1}.


                  
                  Not always true! 
                  
                

This is only true if \vec{\textbf{F}} is a Gradient Field




                  
                  Example Problem 
                  
                

Let \vec{\textbf{F}} = \langle y, x \rangle. Is this a Gradient Field, and if so, what is the function? What is the work done by moving along the x-axis by 1 unit?
Solution:
We are looking for a function f which has \frac{\partial f}{\partial x} = y and \frac{\partial f}{\partial y} = x. There are probably more examples, but the one that comes to mind is f(x, y) = xy. So yes, this is a Gradient Field given by f(x,y) = xy. The work done by moving along the x-axis by a unit is then given by W = \int\limits_{C}^{}{F \cdot d\vec{r}} = f(1, 0) - f(0, 0) = 0


Properties

The Gradient Field is path independent
\vec{\textbf{F}} = \nabla f is a conservative force
\oint\limits_{C}{\nabla f \cdot d\vec{r}} = 0
The Work done by \vec{F} is the change in the Potential Energy from the field
\vec{F} = Mdx + Ndy is an Exact Differential Equations.


References
1802SC - Multivariable Calculus - Session 60

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Int.title: Green's Theorem
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Int.content:
Green’s Theorem
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
Line integrals can be difficult some times. Green’s Theorem provides an alternative way of computing them for closed curves. Specifically, it gives that
\oint_{C} \vec{\textbf{F}} \cdot d \vec{\textbf{r}} = \iint\limits_{R}^{}{\nabla \times \vec{\textbf{F}}dA}
where \nabla \times \vec{\textbf{F}} is the Curl of the Vector Field \vec{F}, and R is the region enclosed by the closed curve C.


                  
                  Green's Theorem 
                  
                

Consider a closed, non-intersecting curve C with an interior enclosed of R. Let C be piecewise smooth and be counterclockwise. Let the Vector Field \vec{\textbf{F}} = \langle M, N \rangle and let \vec{\textbf{F}} be continuous and differentiable. Then, \oint_{C} \vec{\textbf{F}} \cdot d \vec{\textbf{r}} = \iint_{R}{\text{curl}(\vec{\textbf{F}})dA}
or \oint_{C} M dx + N dy = \iint_{R} N_{x} - M_{y} dA


This proves the fact about Conservative Forces shown here [[Curl Operator#^60b is defined everywhere in the plane and \text{curl}(\vec{\textbf{F}}) = 0, then \vec{\textbf{F}} is a Conservative Forces.


                  
                  Decomposition 
                  
                

If we have a curve C enclosing a region R, the line integral along C can be decomposed into two simpler line integrals around arbitrary regions split along a line, giving separate curves C_{1} and C_{2}. This is because the line that splits the region is covered once in C_{1} and once in the opposite direction along C_{2}. You can continue splitting indefinitely to get infinitely small regions, which is how Green’s Theorem is proved.


Discontinuity
If you have a discontinuity — a point where the Vector Field is not defined or not differentiable — then you can make a second smaller curve going clockwise enclosing this “hole” and then connect it to the main one with an infinitely thin slice. The total Line Integral is then
\oint_{C} - \oint_{C'}
This leads to the idea of Simply Connected Regions.
Green’s Theorem for Flux (in Normal Form)
There is a closely related idea for Flux in Two Dimensions: if C encloses a region R counterclockwise, and we have a Vector Field \vec{\textbf{F}} = \langle P, Q \rangle defined and differentiable everywhere on C and R, then \oint_{C} \vec{\textbf{F}} \cdot \hat{\textbf{n}}ds = \iint_{R} \text{div} \vec{\textbf{F}} dA
where \text{div} is the Divergence Operator. This gives us the flux out of R through C.

References
1802SC - Multivariable Calculus - Session 65

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Int.title: Line Integral
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Int.content:
Line Integral
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
A line integral is, much like in single variable calculus, the area beneath a curve. In this case, however, it represents the area beneath an arbitrary trajectory C. Let the curve C be given by the parametric equations
x = h(t);\quad y = g(t);\quad a \leq t \leq b
which can be summarized as
\vec{r}(t) = h(t) \hat{\textbf{i}} + g(t) \hat{\textbf{j}}; \quad a \leq t \leq b
The parameterization of the curve C doesn’t matter, as long as it traces out the same trajectory.
The line integral is then \int\limits_{C}^{}{f(h(t), g(t))||\vec{r}'(t)||dt}
where ||\vec{r}'(t)|| is the magnitude of the velocity along the curve.
A different way of thinking about it is given in terms of Vector Fields. If you have \vec{\textbf{F}} = \langle M, N \rangle, then r(t) = x(t) \hat{\textbf{i}} + y(t) \hat{\textbf{j}}; \quad dr = \langle dx, dy \rangle so
\int\limits_{C}^{}{\vec{\textbf{F}} \cdot d\vec{\textbf{r}}} = \int\limits_{C}^{}{Mdx + Ndy}
This latter representation using \langle M, N \rangle is the method that Denis Auroux prefers.


                  
                  Line Integral Example 1 
                  
                

What is the Work done by the force vector field F = \langle y, x \rangle along the segment of the unit circle from 0 to \frac{\pi}{2} radians?
Solution:
W = \int\limits_{C}^{[](Vector%20Fields.md)c{r}} = \int\limits_{C}^{}{Mdx + Ndy}
We can parameterize our given curve as \begin{array}{lct} x = \cos{(\theta)} \\ y=\sin{(\theta)}\end{array}; \quad \begin{array}{lct} dx = -\sin{(\theta)}d \theta \\ dy=\cos{(\theta)} d \theta \end{array}; \quad 0 \leq \theta \leq \frac{\pi}{4}
So therefore W = \int\limits_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{4}}{ (\cos^{2}{(\theta)}- \sin^{2}{(\theta)}) d \theta} = \frac{1}{2} \sin{(2x)}|_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{4}} = \frac{1}{2}


Geometric Intepretation
You can think of velocity \frac{d \vec{\textbf{r}}}{dt} as being a vector in the direction of the tangent vector \hat{\textbf{T}} with magnitude of the speed \frac{ds}{dt}. Then, cancelling out the dt, we have d\vec{\textbf{r}} = \hat{\textbf{T}}ds. So, we have
\int\limits_{C}^{}{\vec{\textbf{F}} \cdot d \vec{\textbf{r}}} = \int\limits_{C}^{}{\vec{\textbf{F}}\cdot \hat{\textbf{T}}ds}
which is the component of the force along the curve integrated over the curve.
For example, consider a trajectory that is just a circle of radius a at the origin going counterclockwise, and a vector field that is just \vec{\textbf{F}} = x \hat{\textbf{i}} + y \hat{\textbf{j}} (i.e. the vector to each point, placed at the point). The tangent to a circle at any point is perpendicular to the radius, so \vec{\textbf{F}} \cdot \hat{\textbf{T}} = 0, so the line integral is 0.
Transclude of Fundamental-Theorem-of-Line-Integrals
Transclude of Line-Integrals-in-Space#line-integrals-in-space

1802SC - Multivariable Calculus - Session 57

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Int.title: Line Integrals in Space
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Int.content:
Line Integrals in Space
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
We can take Line Integrals along Curves in Space. Consider the Vector Field \vec{\textbf{F}} = M \hat{\textbf{i}} + N \hat{\textbf{j}} + P \hat{\textbf{k}}, assumed continuous. WE define the line integral of \vec{\textbf{F}} along a curve C in the same way as the plane: \int\limits_{C}^{}{\vec{\textbf{F}} \cdot d \vec{\textbf{r}}} = \int\limits_{C}^{}{Mdx + Ndy + Pdz}


                  
                  Example 
                  
                

Evaluate the vector field \vec{\textbf{F}} = \langle yz, xz, xy \rangle along the curve C: x = t^{3}, y = t^{2}, z = t from 0 \leq t \leq 1.
Solution:
We take dx = 3t^{2}dt, dy = 2t dt, and dz = dt. Then, we substitute: \begin{aligned}
\int\limits_{C}^{}{\vec{\textbf{F}} \cdot d \vec{\textbf{r}}} &=  \int\limits_{C}^{}{yzdx + xzdy + xydz}\\
 &=  \int\limits_{C}^{}{t^{3} \cdot 3t^{2}dt + t^{4} \cdot 2t dt + t^{5} \cdot dt}\\
 &=  \int\limits_{0}^{1}{6t^{5}dt}\\
 &=  t^{6}|_{0}^{1} = 1\end{aligned}



References
1802SC - Multivariable Calculus - Session 88

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Int.title: Potential Function from Line Integral
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Int.content:
Potential Function from Line Integral
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
Let \vec{F} = \nabla f = \langle M(x,y), N(x,y) \rangle (i.e. let F be a Vector Field that is a Gradient Field). The Potential Function described by this Gradient Field is equal to
f(x,y) = \int\limits_{C}^{}{\vec{\textbf{F}} \cdot d\vec{\textbf{r}}} + f(0, 0)
Where the integral there is a Line Integral. We can choose the easiest possible trajectory to get to some point (x_{1}, y_{1}), which is probably to split into two steps: first go from x = 0 to x = x_{1}, and then do y = 0 to y = y_{1}. For the first trajectory, y = 0 and is constant so dy = 0; for the second, x = x_{1} and dx = 0. Together, this gives us the integral
f(x, y) = \int\limits_{0}^{x_{1}}{M(x, 0)dx} + \int\limits_{0}^{y_{1} }{N(x_{1}, y)dy} + c
In Space
Consider \vec{\textbf{F}} = \langle P(x,y,z), Q(x,y,z), R(x,y,z)\rangle. To find f(x, y, z) = \int\limits_{C}^{}{\vec{\textbf{F}} \cdot d \vec{\textbf{r}}} + f(0, 0, 0), we typically choose the trajectory where we go along the x-axis, then y-axis, then z-axis to reach the point (x_{1}, y_{1}, z_{1}).

References
1802SC - Multivariable Calculus - Session 63

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Int.title: Stokes' Theorem
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Int.content:
Stokes’ Theorem
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
Stokes’ Theorem is the space equivalent of Greens Theorem. It relates a Line Integral to a Surface Integral. Mathematically, it states that:
\oint_{C} \vec{\textbf{F}} \cdot d \vec{\textbf{r}} = \iint_{S} (\nabla \times  \vec{\textbf{F}}) \cdot \hat{\textbf{n}} dS
where C is a closed curve and S is any surface bounded by C.
For example, if you need to take a line integral around a circle centered at the origin, you could instead take a cone or hemisphere or disk or any shape bounded by the circle.


                  
                  Orientation Matters! 
                  
                

You need the orientations of C and S to be compatible: if you travel along C in the positive direction with S to the left, then \hat{\textbf{n}} is pointing up.
In terms of the right hand: point your thumb along the curve, your index finger towards the center of the surface, and then your middle finger points in the direction of \hat{\textbf{n}}.


Green’s Theorem for Flux is just a special case of Stokes, in the xy-plane.

References
1802SC - Multivariable Calculus - Session 91

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Int.title: Surface Integrals
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Int.content:
Surface Integrals
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
Surface integrals are the space equivalent of line integrals. They are concerned with the integration of a force over a surface. Generally, the surface integral of the continuous function f(x,y,z) over the surface S is denoted by \iint_{S} f(x,y,z) dS
where dS is the area of an infinitesimal piece of the surface S. This is seen famously in Gauss’s Law.

References
1802SC - Multivariable Calculus - Session 80

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Int.title: Triple Integrals
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Int.content:
Triple Integrals
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
Much like Double Integrals, we can evaluate triple nested integrals. These represent the integral over a volume element; some solid. The basic form is
\iiint_{R} f dV
For rectangular coordinates, dV = dxdydz, or some order of integration therein.


                  
                  Triple Integral Example 1 
                  
                

The hardest part about a triple integral is setting it up. First, let’s consider the region between two paraboloids z = x^{2} + y^{2} and z = 4-x^{2}-y^{2}. What is the volume of this region?
Solution:
We must evaluate the volume integral \iiint_{R} dV
where R represents the region. The z = x^{2} + y^{2} is a very simple paraboloid, with its vertex at the origin. The other one is pointing down with a vertex at (0, 0, 4). The z bounds at a specific coordinate are given by the lower bound x^{2} + y^{2} and the upper bound 4 - x^{2} - y^{2}, so we have our first step of the iterated integral: \iiint\limits_{x^{2}+y^{2}}^{4-x^{2} - y^{2}}dzdydx
Now, to find the bounds of x and y, we consider the maximum values that they can obtain. We look at x^{2} + y^{2} < 4 - x^{2} - y^{2} \to x^{2} + y^{2} < 2, which is the disk with radius \sqrt{2}. Considering that circle, and using Pythagoras, we see that as x ranges from -\sqrt{2} to \sqrt{2}, y must range from \sqrt{2 - x^{2}} to - \sqrt{2-x^{2}} so our final integral is \int\limits_{-\sqrt{2}}^{\sqrt{2}}\int\limits_{-\sqrt{2-x^{2}}}^{\sqrt{2-x^{2}}}\int\limits_{x^{2}+y^{2}}^{4-x^{2}-y^{2}} dzdydx
Note: in this case, it would be better to use Cylindrical Coordinates.


Triple integrals are super useful. See Applications of Triple Integrals.

References
1802SC - Multivariable Calculus - Session 74

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Int.title: Vector Fields
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Int.content:
Vector Fields
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
A vector field is \vec{\textbf{F}} = M \hat{\textbf{i}} + N \hat{\textbf{j}}, where M and N are functions of (x, y). In other words, at every point in the plane, there is an associated vector.
Examples:

Wind graphs; you show the velocity of the wind at a number of points
Force fields
Velocity in a fluid \vec{v}



                  
                  Vector Field vs Vector Function 
                  
                

The terms vector field and vector function are generally effectively interchangeable. Saying “the vector field \textbf{F}” is equivalent to saying “the vector field corresponding to the vector function \textbf{F}“.


Continuity
The vector field F is continuous in some region of the plane if both M and N are continuous functions in that region.

Geometrically this means vectors change direction and magnitude mostly smoothly

Differentiability
Vector field F is differentiable in the region if M and N are differentiable, which occurs if all the Partial Derivatives
\frac{\partial M}{\partial x}, \quad \frac{\partial M}{\partial y}, \quad \frac{\partial N}{\partial x}, \quad \frac{\partial N}{\partial y}
exist. See also Vector Differentiation.
Transclude of Work-Done-by-Vector-Field#work-done-by-vector-field
In Space
Vector fields can be three-dimensional. For example, you could consider the force field generated by the gravitational attraction. Consider a mass M at the origin and a unit mass m at point (x, y, z). The vector field in this case would be \vec{\textbf{F}} = -c\frac{\langle x, y, z \rangle}{\rho^{3}}where \rho is the distance from the origin.
You could also consider the flow of wind across altitudes.

References
1802SC - Multivariable Calculus - Session 56

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Int.title: Work Done by Vector Field
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Int.content:
Work Done by Vector Field
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
The work done by a vector field along a trajectory C (for curve) is found by a Line Integral:
W = \int\limits_{C}^{}{\vec{F} \cdot d\vec{r}}
Conceptually, we can think of it as splitting our trajectory into a ton of tiny time intervals, \Delta t, and the summing the work done over the whole time period.
W = \lim_{\Delta t \to 0} \sum\limits_{i} \vec{F} \cdot \left( \frac{\Delta \vec{r}}{\Delta t} \Delta t\right) = \int\limits_{t_{1}}^{t_{2}}{\vec{F} \cdot \frac{d\vec{r}}{dt} dt}
then we integrate over dt.


                  
                  Work Done by a Force 
                  
                

Consider the Force vector field \vec{\textbf{F}} = -y \hat{\textbf{i}} + x \hat{\textbf{j}} where we move along the parametric trajectory C = \begin{array}{lct} x = t \\ y = t^{2} \end{array}; 0 \leq t \leq 1. What is the work done?
Solution:md), we can rewrite our force field in terms of t: \vec{\textbf{F}} = \langle-y, x\rangle = \langle- t^{2}, t\rangle. Our velocity vector is \frac{dx}{dt}= 1, \frac{dy}{dt} = 2t; \frac{d\vec{r}}{dt} = \langle1, 2t\rangle. The dot product is then \vec{\textbf{F}} \cdot \frac{d\vec{r}}{dt} = -t^{2} + 2t^{2} = t^{2}
so our work is
W = \int\limits_{0}^{1}{\vec{\textbf{F}} \cdot \frac{d\vec{r}}{dt} dt} = \int\limits_{0}^{1}{t^{2}dt} = \frac{1}{3}



References
1802SC - Multivariable Calculus - Session 57

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Lap.title: Laplace Operator
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Lap.content:
Laplace Operator
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
The Laplace Operator is a Differential Operator given by the divergence of the Gradient. Conceptually, it is the equivalent to the second derivative in three dimensions.
The Laplace operator is written as \boxed{\nabla \cdot \nabla = \nabla^{2}}. See Del Notation. It is also rarely written as \Delta.


                  
                  Definition 
                  
                

Explicitly, the Laplacian of f is the sum of all the unmixed Partial Derivatives:
\nabla^{2} f = \sum\limits_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x^{2}_{i}}
for example,
\nabla^{2}f(x, y, z) = \frac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x^{2}} + \frac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial y^{2}} + \frac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial z^{2}}


Physical Intuition
Take a function f in three dimensions. Look at all the values of f that fall some tiny distance d from a starting point \vec{p}. Call the average of these values \langle{f}\rangle_\text{around}. If you subtract the value of f(\vec{p}), you get a sense of how much the function changes around \vec{p}. This very same intuition can be used for the Laplacian:1 \nabla^{2} f(\vec{x_{0}}) = \lim_{d \vec{x} \to \vec{0}} 6 \frac{\langle f \rangle_\text{around} - f(\vec{x_{0}})}{d \vec{x}^{2}}

References
Footnotes


isis2.cc.oberlin.edu/physics/dstyer/Electrodynamics/Laplacian.pdf ↩

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Mul.content:
Multivariable Calculus

Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Pot.title: Potential Function
Concepts/Math/Multivariable-Calculus/Pot.content:
Potential Function
Topic: Multivariable Calculus
A potential function gives us the Potential Energy associated with a Conservative Forces as described by a Vector Field. Given a Gradient Field, it can be found via multiple methods:

Solving Exact Differential Equations
Potential Function from Line Integral


References

Concepts/Math/Number-Theory/Chinese-Rema.title: Chinese Remainder Theorem
Concepts/Math/Number-Theory/Chinese-Rema.content:
Chinese Remainder Theorem
Topic: Number Theory
The Chinese Remainder Theorem is a critical theorem in Modular Arithmetic. It is used when you have a system of modular congruences.


                  
                  Chinese Remainder Theorem 
                  
                

Q: Solve the system of congruences \begin{cases}x\equiv 1\ (\text{mod}\ 3)\\ x\equiv 4\ (\text{mod}\ 5) \\
x\equiv 6\ (\text{mod}\ 7)\end{cases}
A: We begin with the largest modulus. Based on the information from this, we can rewrite x as 7j + 6,\ \text{for some integer}\ j. Then, we substitute into the next largest modulus:
x\equiv 4\ (\text{mod}\ 5) \implies 7j+6\equiv 4\ (\text{mod}\ 5) \to 2j\equiv -2\ (\text{mod}\ 5) \to j\equiv 4\ (\text{mod}\ 5)
Therefore j = 5k + 4,\ \text{for some integer}\ k. We combine these two expressions to find that x = 7(5k + 4) + 6 = 35k + 34. Now we go into the smallest modulus.
35k + 34\equiv 1\ (\text{mod}\ 3) \implies k\equiv 0\ (\text{mod}\ 3)
Therefore k = 3\ell,\ \text{for some integer}\ \ell. Again, we substitute: x = 35(3\ell) + 34



References

brilliant.org/wiki/chinese-remainder-theorem/

Concepts/Math/Number-Theory/Divisibility.title: Divisibility Rule for 11
Concepts/Math/Number-Theory/Divisibility.content:
Divisibility Rule for 11
Topic: Number Theory
The divisibility rule for 11 states that if the sum of the even digits minus the sum of the odd-place digits is mod 11, then the whole number is. For example, the number \bar{abcabc} \text{ mod}\ 11 = 1000(abc) + abc = 1001(abc) so it will always be divisible by 11.

References

Concepts/Math/Number-Theory/Divisibility.title: Divisibility Rule for 3
Concepts/Math/Number-Theory/Divisibility.content:
Divisibility Rule for 3
Topic: Number Theory
A number is divisible by 3 if the sum of all the digits of that number are divisible by 3.


                  
                  Is 495 Divisible by 3? 
                  
                

The number 495 has digits that sum to 18. 18 is divisible by 3. Therefore, the number is divisible by 3 as well.



References

Concepts/Math/Number-Theory/Divisibility.title: Divisibility Rule for 4
Concepts/Math/Number-Theory/Divisibility.content:
Divisibility Rule for 4
Topic: Number Theory
If the last two digits of a number are divisible by 4, then the larger number will be as well.


                  
                  Is 384 divisible by 4? 
                  
                

The last two digits of 384 are 84. 84 = 40 + 40 + 4 = 21 \times 4, so therefore 384 is divisible by 4. Equivalently, 384 \equiv 0\ (\text{mod}\ 4). See Modular Arithmetic.



References

Concepts/Math/Number-Theory/Divisibility.title: Divisibility Rule for 5
Concepts/Math/Number-Theory/Divisibility.content:
Divisibility Rule for 5
Topic: Number Theory
The divisibility rule for 5 is quite trivial: if the last digit is 0 or 5, it is divisible by 5. Otherwise its not.


                  
                  Is 878 divisible by 5? 
                  
                

The last digit is 8\equiv 3\ (\text{mod}\ 5), so 878 is not divisible by 5. See Modular Arithmetic.



References

Concepts/Math/Number-Theory/Divisibility.title: Divisibility Rule for 6
Concepts/Math/Number-Theory/Divisibility.content:
Divisibility Rule for 6
Topic: Number Theory
A number is divisible by 6 when the sum of its digits is divisible by 3 AND it is even. See Divisibility Rule for 3.

Concepts/Math/Number-Theory/Divisibility.title: Divisibility Rule for 9
Concepts/Math/Number-Theory/Divisibility.content:
Divisibility Rule for 9
Topic: Number Theory
if the sum of the digits are divisible by 9, then the larger number will be as well.

References

Concepts/Math/Number-Theory/Divisibility.title: Divisibility Rules
Concepts/Math/Number-Theory/Divisibility.content:
Divisibility Rules
Topic: Number Theory
There are certain tricks we have for determining if a number is divisible by a certain factor. Here is a list of some of them.

Divisibility Rule for 3
Divisibility Rule for 4
Divisibility Rule for 5
Divisibility Rule for 6
