Concepts/Science/Physics/Angular-Motion/.title: Angular Acceleration
Concepts/Science/Physics/Angular-Motion/.content:
Angular Acceleration
Topic: Angular Motion
Angular acceleration is the angular equivalent of Acceleration. It can be defined as the change in Angular Velocity:
\bar\alpha = \frac{\Delta \omega}{\Delta t}
Instantaneous angular acceleration is:
\alpha = \frac{d\omega}{dt}
Angular acceleration is related to the tangential linear acceleration a_{\tan} of a point in the rotating object by:
a_{\tan{}} = \frac{dv}{dt} = R \frac{d \omega}{dt} = R\alpha
This also gives us another way to find the Centripetal Force acting on the object:
a_{R} = \frac{v^{2}}{R} = \omega^{2}R

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 10

Concepts/Science/Physics/Angular-Motion/.title: Angular Frequency
Concepts/Science/Physics/Angular-Motion/.content:
Angular Frequency
Topic: Oscillations and Vibrations
Angular frequency is 2\pi \times fwhere f is the Frequency.

References

Concepts/Science/Physics/Angular-Motion/.title: Angular Momentum
Concepts/Science/Physics/Angular-Motion/.content:
Angular Momentum
Topic: Angular Motion
Angular momentum is the angular analogue of Linear Momentum. It can most simply be stated as:
\vec{L} = I\vec{\omega}
However, this is only true when the rotation is about a fixed Principle Axis.
Second Law Equivalent
\sum\limits \vec{\tau} = \frac{d\vec{L}}{dt}
Conservation
If no net external Torque acts on a system, then the total angular momentum is conserved.
General Definition
\vec{L} = \vec{r} \times \vec{p}
Where \vec{r} is the position, and \vec{p} is the Linear Momentum. This is a Vector Cross Product.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 11

Concepts/Science/Physics/Angular-Motion/.title: Angular Motion
Concepts/Science/Physics/Angular-Motion/.content:
Angular Motion
The study of rotational motion.
Subtopics
table without id file.inlinks
where file.name = this.file.name

Concepts/Science/Physics/Angular-Motion/.title: Angular Position
Concepts/Science/Physics/Angular-Motion/.content:
Angular Position
Topic: Angular Motion
Each translatational property has a angular equivalent. Angular position is the equivalent of x, y, z position.
\theta = \frac{\ell}{R}
Where \ell is the Arc Length, and R is the distance from the axis of rotation.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 10

Concepts/Science/Physics/Angular-Motion/.title: Angular Velocity
Concepts/Science/Physics/Angular-Motion/.content:
Angular Velocity
Topic: Angular Motion
Angular velocity is the angular equivalent of Velocity, just as Angular Position is the equivalent of position. Average angular velocity is defined as:
\bar{\omega} = \frac{\Delta \theta}{\Delta t}
And instantaneous velocity is defined as:
\omega = \frac{d\theta}{dt}
It has units of radians per second.
\omega is the same for all points of a rotating object. Because of this, you can find the linear Velocity of any point on a rotating object using this formula:
v = \frac{d\ell}{dt} = \frac{Rd\theta}{dt} = R \omega
The derivative of \omega is Angular Acceleration.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 10

Concepts/Science/Physics/Angular-Motion/.title: Moment of Inertia
Concepts/Science/Physics/Angular-Motion/.content:
Moment of Inertia
Topic: Angular Motion
Moment of inertia (I) is the angular equivalent of Center of Mass. It is can be difficult to define and find, far more than CM. This is because I varies based on the axis of rotation, the shape of the object, the density distribution of the object, and the size.
Planar Object Calculations
The moment of inertia of a point mass is I = mr^{2}, where m is the mass and r^{2} is the distance from the rotational axis. The moment of inertia of a larger object can be found by approximating the object as a sum of point masses. Let \delta(x,y) be the density at point (x,y). The moment of inertia about the origin is the following double integral I_{0}= \iint_{R}r^{2} \delta dA
where r^{2} = x^{2} +y^{2}.


                  
                  Example: Rotating a Disk about the Origin 
                  
                

Consider a uniform disk of radius a and Density \delta = 1. What is the moment of inertia?
Solution:
This is easiest to do in polar coordinates.
I_{0} = \iint_{R}r^{2}dA = \int\limits_{0}^{2\pi} \int\limits_{0}^{a} r^{2} \cdot r dr d \theta
Evaluating that integral yields
I_{0} = \int\limits_{0}^{2\pi} \frac{a^{4}}{4} d \theta = 2\pi \frac{a^{4}}{4} = \frac{\pi}{2} a^{4}


Other Axes
The origin (or \hat{\textbf{k}}) isn’t the only axis we can rotate about. Instead, consider rotation about the x-axis. The distance to the x-axis is just |y|, so
I_{x} = \iint_{R} y^{2} \delta dA
Volumetric Objects
The moment of inertia about an axi\iiinty the Triple Integrals: \iiint_{R} (\text{distance to axis})^{2} \delta dV
where \delta is the density function and R is the region of the object.
The moment of inertia about the z-axis:
I_{z} = \iiint_{R} r^{2} \delta dV = \iiint_{R} (x^{2} + y ^{2}) \delta dV
The x-axis:
I_{x} = \iiint_{R} (y^{2} + z^{2}) \delta dV
The y-axis:
I_{y} = \iiint_{R} (x^{2} + z^{2}) \delta dV


                  
                  Find the Moment of Inertia 
                  
                

What is I_{z} of a solid cone between z = ar and z = b?
Solution:
We will use a triple integral in the Cylindrical Coordinates. Let \delta = 1. We can find the area of each disk, and then sum the disks vertically to find the moment of inertia.
I_{z} = \int\limits_{0}^{b}\int\limits_{0}^{2\pi}\int\limits_{0}^{\frac{z}{a}}r^{3} dr d \theta dz = \frac{\pi b^{5}}{10 a^{4}}



References

Concepts/Science/Physics/Angular-Motion/.title: Parallel Axis Theorem
Concepts/Science/Physics/Angular-Motion/.content:
Parallel Axis Theorem
The Moment of Inertia of an object around a parallel axis to its center of mass is equal to:
I = I_{cm} + Mh^{2}

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 10

Concepts/Science/Physics/Angular-Motion/.title: Torque
Concepts/Science/Physics/Angular-Motion/.content:
Torque
Topic: Angular Motion
Torque (\tau) is the angular equivalent of Force. The amount of torque you do for a given amount of energy depends on the position on the object which you apply a force, and the angle at which you apply the force.
The amount of torque can be found It can be found in many different ways, all involving vectors and trigonometry:

r \sin{(\theta)}F where r is the length from the axis of rotation and \theta is the angle at which the force is being applied
rF_{\perp}, where F_{\perp} is the magnitude of the force perpendicular to the radial from the axis of rotation
r_{\perp}F, where r_{\perp} is the moment arm — the length of the radial that is perpendicular to the axis through which the force is being applied
\vec{ \tau } = \vec{\textbf{r}} \times \vec{\textbf{F}}, Vector Cross Product

Angular Second Law of Motion
\sum \vec{\tau} = I_{cm}\vec{\alpha}_{cm}
Only true for:

axis fixed in Inertial Frames of Reference
axis accelerating in one dimension


References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 10

Concepts/Science/Physics/Angular-Motion/.title: Uniform Circular Motion

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Ampere's Law
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Topic: Electromagnetism
Ampere’s Law
Ampere’s Law states that the Line Integral of the Magnetic Field \vec{\textbf{B}} around any closed path is equal to \mu_{0} times the total net current I_{encl} enclosed by that path: \oint \vec{\textbf{B}} \cdot d \vec{\ell} = \mu_{0} I_{encl}
Where \mu_{0} is the magnetic constant.
Maxwell’s Addition
Maxwell found that a changing Electric Flux also influences the magnetic field. He added a term to Ampere’s Law to account for this, creating the finalized equation: \oint \vec{\textbf{B}} \cdot d \vec{\ell} = \mu_{0} I_{encl} + \mu_{0} \epsilon_{0} \frac{d\Phi_{e}}{dt}

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 28

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Biot-Savart Equation
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Biot-Savart Equation
Topic: Electromagnetism
The relationship between an electric Current I and the Magnetic Field \vec{B} can be expressed by the equation \vec{\textbf{B}} = \frac{\mu_{0} I}{4 \pi} \int\limits_{}^{}{\frac{d \vec{\ell} \times \hat{\textbf{r}}}{r^{2}}}
where d\vec{\ell} is the tiny change in arc length along the wire.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 28

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Charge
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Charge
Topic: Electromagnetism
Electric charge, denoted by the symbol Q or q, is the property of matter that causes it to experience a force when placed in an electromagnetic field.
There are five main ways to charge something:

Move electrons from one to another; i.e. create Ions
Transfer charge by friction (triboelectric charging)
Charge by conduction, i.e. physical contact
Polarization: one side of a neutral object appears positive, other side negative, e.g. water
Induction: start with polarization, then provide a path for some charge to escape

Transclude of Elementary-Charge#elementary-charge

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 21

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: AC Circuits
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
AC Circuits
Topic: Electromagnetism
In RC Circuits, LC Circuits. LR Circuits, and LRC Circuits, we assume direct current. However, circuits can alternatively be connected to Alternating Current of a sinusoidal voltage of frequency f. This complicates matters.
In an AC circuit, we assume a Current I(t) = I_{0} \cos{(2\pi f t)} = I_{0} \cos{(\omega t)}
and averages V_{rms} = V_{0}/\sqrt{2}, I_{rms} = I_{0}/\sqrt{2}.
Resistor
When an AC source is connected to a Resistor, the current increases and decreases with the alternating voltage according to Ohms Law:
V = V_{0} \cos{(\omega t)} = IR = I_{0}R \cos{(\omega t)}
where V_{0} = I_{0}R is the peak voltage. Energy is lost at an average rate \bar{P} = I_{rms}^{2}R = \frac{V_{rms}^{2}}{R}
Inductor
In an inductor of Self-Inductance L, it can be shown that V = V_{0} \cos{(\omega t + \frac{\pi}{2})}; \quad V_{0} = I_{0} \omega L
Therefore, the current lags behind the voltage by \frac{\pi}{2} radians.
The inductive reactance of the inductor is given by X_{L} = \omega L = w \pi f L
and has units of \ohm.
Inductive Reactance
Capacitor
When a Capacitors of capacitance C is connected to an alternating current source, V = V_{0} \cos{( \omega t - \frac{\pi}{2})}; \quad V_{0} = I_{0} \left(\frac{1}{\omega C} \right)
Therefore, the current leads the voltage by \frac{\pi}{2} radians.
Just as with inductors, there is a capacitive reactance: V_{0} = I_{0}X_{C}; \quad X_{C} =  \frac{1}{\omega C} = \frac{1}{2 \pi f C}
Capacitive Reactance
Acronym
Remembering the phases: ELI the ICE man:

E(mf) before I(current) in L(inductors)
I(current) before E(mf) in C(apacitors)


References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 30-7

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Alternating Current
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Alternating Current
Topic: Electromagnetism
When a Electric Battery is connected to a Circuit, the Current moves steadily in one direction. This is called direct current. However, we can instead use Alternating Current, AC, which reverses direction many times per second in a sinusoidal pattern. Almost our entire power system relies on AC systems, because AC can be transmitted across longer distances with less energy loss.
The Voltage as a function of time in a AC circuit can be written as
V(t) = V_{0}\sin{(\omega t)} = V_{0} \sin{(2 \pi f t)}
where V_{0} is the peak voltage and f is the number of complete oscillations per second (Frequency). In the US, f = 60 \text{ Hz}.
In the same manner, from Ohms Law, we find that I = \frac{V}{R} = I_{0} \sin{(\omega t)}
where I_{0} is the peak current.
The root-mean-square voltage and current are
I_{rms} = \frac{I_{0}}{\sqrt{2}}; \quad V_{rms} = \frac{V_{0}}{\sqrt{2}}
and the average Power is
\bar{P} = I_{rms}V_{rms} = I^{2}_{rms} R = \frac{V_{rms}^{2}}{R}

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 25-7

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Capacitive Reactance
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Capacitive Reactance
Topic: Electromagnetism
In an alternating current circuit with a capacitor, the capacitor impedes the flow of Current. The capacitive reactance represents this impedance, and is given by X_{C} = \frac{1}{\omega C} = \frac{1}{2\pi f C}
Together with the Inductive Reactance and the Resistance, this becomes the Impedance.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 30

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Capacitors in Parallel
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Capacitors in Parallel
Topic: Electromagnetism

Capacitors in parallel are all directly connected to the same source.
The same Potential Difference V exists across each of the capacitors.
Each capacitor plate acquires a charge given by Q_{1} = C_{1}V, Q_{2} = C_{2}V, \dots Q_{n} = C_{n}V
The total charge that leaves the battery is Q = Q_{1} + Q_{2} +  \dots + Q_{n} = C_{eq}V
The equivalent capacitance C_{eq} is given by C_{eq} = C_{1} + C_{2} + \dots + C_{n}
Capacitors in parallel increase the total capacitance


References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 24-3

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Capacitors in Series
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Capacitors in Series
Topic: Electromagnetism

Capacitors in series all have the same charge Q
The total Voltage V across all capacitors in series must equal the sum of the voltages across each: V = V_{1} + V_{2} + \dots + V_{n}
The equivalent capacitance is \frac{1}{C_{eq}} = \frac{1}{C_{1}} + \frac{1}{C_{2}} + \dots + \frac{1}{C_{n}}
The equivalent capacitance is smaller than the smallest contributing capacitance


References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 24-3

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Capacitors
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Capacitors
Two layers of conducting materials separated by a layer of insulator form a capacitor.

An electrical device used for storing electric charge.
Modeled by two parallel conducting plates holding equal charge Q
The movement of charge between the plates is prevented by the insulating layer.
The unit of measurement for capacitance is the Farad (F)

Electrical Properties

The Electric Field inside a capacitor is uniform: E = \frac{\sigma}{\epsilon_{0}}
The schematic symbol is two parallel lines
When connected to a battery, the voltage difference becomes equal to that of the battery
Charge on plates is proportional to voltage: Q = CV
Capacitor is the electrical equivalent to a spring



                  
                  Electric Potential Difference for Parallel Plate Capacitor 
                  
                

The Potential Difference between the parallel plates of a capacitor is V_{ba} = Ed
when you move from the positive plate at point a to the negative plate at point b. It makes conceptual sense that this is negative because holding a positive charge near the positive plate is difficult, thus increasing Potential Energy, but as it moves to the negative charge it lowers.



Capacitance
The capacitance of a parallel plate capacitor is given by
C = \frac{A \epsilon_{0} K}{d}
where A is the area of each plate, \epsilon_{0} is the Permittivity of Free Space, K is the Dielectric Constant of the separation material (1 for air!) and d is the distance between the two plates.
Stored Energy
Energy Stored in a Capacitor
Circuits
See Capacitors in Series and Capacitors in Parallel.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Circuit
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Circuit
A circuit is a connection of electrical components.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Impedance
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Impedance
Topic: Electromagnetism
The impedance of a circuit represents the reactances and resistances. In a LRC Series AC Circuit, it is given as Z = \sqrt{R^{2} + (X_{L} - X_{C})^{2}}

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 30

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Inductive Reactance
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Inductive Reactance
Topic: Electromagnetism
In an AC Circuits containing an inductor, there is an inductive reactance; this is how the inductor impedes the flow of charge.
X_{L} = \omega L = \omega \pi f L
where L is the Self-Inductance, \omega is the Angular Frequency of the current.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 30

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Inductors
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Inductors
Topic: Electromagnetism
Inductors are components used in circuits. When Current passes through an inductor, the tightly wrapped coils produce a Magnetic Flux which in turns induces a EMF by Faraday’s Law of Induction. This EMF opposes the current, as seen by Lenz’s Law. The result is that if current is increasing, then the induced EMF tends to counter it; and vice versa if decreasing. They can be thought of as adding inertia to the system.
If a coil of N turns of wire has a Magnetic Flux of \Phi_{B} flowing through it due to a Current I, then the self-inductance L is given by L = \frac{N\Phi_{B}}{I}
and the EMF induced in a coil of self-inductance L is \mathscr{E} = - L \frac{dI}{dt}
Self-inductance is measured in Henrys.
When calculating self-inductance, it is often useful to use the Solenoid magnetic field of B = \frac{\mu_{0}NI}{\ell} \to \Phi_{B} = BA = \frac{\mu_{0}NIA}{\ell}.
Inductors allow us to store energy.
See also:

LR Circuits
LRC Circuits


References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 30-2

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: LC Circuits
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
LC Circuits
Topic: Electromagnetism
A circuit with a capacitor and an inductor is charged so that one plate of the capacitor has Charge Q_{0} and the other -Q_{0} and the Potential Difference is V = \frac{Q}{C}. Suppose that at t = 0 a switch is closed allowing the plates to connect. Current flows. By Kirchhoffs Rules, \frac{Q}{C} - L \frac{dI}{dt} = 0
which, using that I = - \frac{dQ}{dt}, becomes \frac{d^{2}Q}{dt^{2}} + \frac{Q}{LC} = 0
This can be solved using the techniques in Solutions of Homogeneous Linear Equations with Constant Coefficients to find that Q(t) = Q_{0} \cos{(\omega t + \phi)}
where \omega = \sqrt{\frac{1}{LC}}.
We can find, again using that I = - \frac{dQ}{dt}, the current: I(t) = \omega Q_{0} \sin{(\omega t + \phi)}
Both the current and charge oscillate, so this circuit is called an LC oscillator.
The next step is combining LR Circuits, LC Circuits, and RC Circuits to describe LRC Circuits.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 30-5

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: LR Circuits
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
LR Circuits
Topic: Electromagnetism
Connected
Consider a circuit with a resistor R and Self-Inductance L connected to a battery of Voltage V_0. At the instant the circuit is closed, current starts to flow, although opposed by inductor. Eventually, it reaches an asymptote when the current stops changing and the inductor stops mattering; at this point, I_{0} = \frac{V_{0}}{R}
We can find the Current at any time I(t) using Kirchhoffs Rules:
V_{0} - IR - L \frac{dI}{dt} \Longrightarrow L \frac{dI}{dt} + RI = V_{0}
This Linear Ordinary Differential Equations can be solved using an integrating factor and the initial conditions that I = 0 when t = 0 to find that I = \frac{V_{0}}{R}(1 - e^{\frac{-t}{\tau}})
where \tau = \frac{L}{R}
is called the time constant of the LR circuit, much like \tau in RC Circuits.
Disconnect
When this circuit is disconnected from a battery, the current decays as I = I_{0}e^{\frac{-t}{\tau}}
V = IR

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 30-4

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: LRC Circuits
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
LRC Circuits
Topic: Electromagnetism
The LRC circuit contains a Resistor R, capacitor C charged to Q, and inductor L. An LRC circuit is much like Damped Harmonic Motion.
By applying Kirchhoffs Rules, we find that -L \frac{dI}{dt} - IR + \frac{Q}{C} = 0
using that the Current I = - \frac{dQ}{dt}, this becomes L \frac{d^{2}Q}{dt^{2}} + R \frac{dQ}{dt} + \frac{1}{C}Q = 0
This is a pretty tricky Differential Equation to solve, but it can be done using Solutions of Homogeneous Linear Equations with Constant Coefficients. The trick is that we don’t know if it has complex roots to the associated equation. If R^{2} < \frac{4L}{C}
the system is said to be underdamped, and will oscillate; it is overdamped for R^{2} > 4L/C, and critically damped if equal.
Underdamped
If it is underdamped, the associated equation has complex roots and applying Eulers Formula results in the charge Q as a function of time:
Q(t) = Q_{0}e^{- \frac{R}{2L} t } \cos{(\omega' t + \phi)}
where \omega' = \sqrt{\frac{1}{LC} - \frac{R^{2}}{4L^{2}}}
and \phi is a phase constant which depends on the initial conditions.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 30-6

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: LRC Series AC Circuit
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
LRC Series AC Circuit
Topic: Electromagnetism
An LRC series AC circuit contains a Resistor of R, a inductor L, and a capacitor C. (or some subset therein). We let V_{R}, V_{L}, \text{ and } V_{C} represent the voltage across each component at a given instant in time, and V_{R0}, V_{L0}, \text{ and } V_{C0} represent the peak voltages. The total voltage at any instant is given by V = V_{R} + V_{L} + V_{C}. Note that the sum of the maximums can be greater than the peak voltage of the source.
Let current be I = I_{0} \cos{( \omega t)}
We use a Phasor Diagram to make this easier. The magnitude of each arrow is given by V_{R0} = I_{0}R; \quad V_{L0} = I_{0} X_{L}; \quad V_{C0} = I_{0} X_{C}
where X_{L} is the Inductive Reactance and X_{C} is the Capacitive Reactance.
The total Impedance Z of the circuit is related to voltage by V_{0} = I_{0} Z (or RMS). The phase angle is \tan{(\phi)} = \frac{X_{L}-X_{C}}{R} or \cos{(\phi)} = \frac{R}{Z}.
The average power is I_{rms}V_{rms} \cos{(\phi)}.
The Resonance frequency is \omega_{0} = \sqrt{\frac{1}{LC}}

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 30

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Mutual Inductance
RC Circuits
Resistors in Parallel
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Resistors in Parallel
Topic: Electromagnetism
To find the equivalent resistance to a group of resistors in parallel, we use the relation:
\frac{1}{R_{eq}} = \frac{1}{R_{1}} + \frac{1}{R_{2}} + \cdots + \frac{1}{R_{n}}
This is similar to Capacitors in Series.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 26

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Resistors in Series
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Resistors in Series
Topic: Electromagnetism
To find the equivalent resistance to a number of resistors in series of one another, simply sum them:
R_{eq} = R_{1} + R_{2} + \cdots + R_{n}
This is reminiscent of Capacitors in Parallel.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 26

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Coulomb
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Coulomb
1 Coulomb is associated with 6.25 billion billion electrons. This is about the amount of charge that passes through a common 100-watt light bulb in a little over a second.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Coulombs Law of Electrical Forces
Current Density
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Current Density
Topic: Electromagnetism
Current can be defined in terms of a microscopic quantity \vec{\textbf{j}}, called the current density. It is defined as the Current per unit cross-sectional area at any point in space. Current can then be defined as the Line Integral
I = \int\limits_{}^{}{\vec{\textbf{j}} \cdot d \vec{\textbf{A}}}
This allows for current to be calculated in situations where the current is not uniform or the area of the wire is not uniform.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 25

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Current
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Current
Topic: Electromagnetism
Current refers to the rate of flow of electricity. It is measured in Amperes, which is charge/second = Coulomb/second (1 \text{ A} = 1 \text{ C/s}).
The instantaneous current is defined by the derivative in the limit of I = \lim_{\Delta t\to0} \frac{\Delta Q}{\Delta t} = \frac{dQ}{dt}
Current can only flow in a Circuit that is complete; there is no break.
Current flows in the conventional direction, which assumes that positive Charge flows. In reality, it is Electrons that flow - our model is inverted.
Current is related to Voltage and Resistance by Ohms Law.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 25

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Dielectric Constant
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Dielectric Constant
Topic: Electromagnetism
A dielectric is an Insulator between the two plates of a capacitor. It has an associated dielectric constant which determines how effective it is at increasing the capacitance. It is given the symbol K, can scales the capacitance by C = K C_{0}. The full equation is seen in Capacitance.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 24-5

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Dipoles
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Dipoles
Topic: Electromagnetism
A dipole is an electrical system with two point charges of equal and opposite charge separated by a distance \ell.
An electric dipole is represented mathematically by \vec{\textbf{p}} = Q\ell, where \vec{\textbf{p}} points from the negative to the positive charge.
An electric dipole placed in an Electric Field may have some Torque. Specifically, it will have torque given by
\vec{\tau} = \vec{\textbf{p}} \times \vec{\textbf{E}}
When \theta = 0 or 180, this will be 0. However, the system is only stable when \theta = 0. See Vector Cross Product.


                  
                  Potential Energy of a Dipole 
                  
                

A dipole will have potential energy equal to U = -\vec{\textbf{p}} \cdot \vec{\textbf{E}}




                  
                  Electric Field on a Charge From a Dipole 
                  
                

A dipole will create an Electric Field of form \vec{\textbf{E}} = - \frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}} \frac{p}{(r^{2} + \frac{\ell^{2}}{4})^\frac{3}{2}} \hat{\textbf{p}}
Which, for sufficiently large values of r \gg \ell, simply becomes \vec{\textbf{E}} = - \frac{1}{4\pi \epsilon_{0}} \frac{p}{r^{3}} \hat{\textbf{p}}



References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 21

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: EMF
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
EMF
Topic: Electromagnetism
The term EMF originally referred to electromotive force. Now, the Potential Difference between the terminals of a source, when no current flows to an external circuit, is called the emf of the source. The symbol \mathscr{E} (script E) is used to denote this value.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 26

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Electric Battery
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Electric Battery
Topic: Electromagnetism
A battery stores Energy. It has to somehow convert that stored Potential Energy into Electric Potential Energy to produce a voltage and current. The way that modern batteries work, typically, is by having some chemical reaction that releases electrons as a byproduct. The electrons are then attracted to a metal, typically zinc, which creates a negative charge in relation to a positive electrode, typically carbon. The resulting Potential Difference is the Voltage of the battery.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 25-1

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Electric Field Determined from Voltage
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Electric Field Determined from Voltage
Topic: Electromagnetism
If we take the derivative of the equation \Delta V = \int\limits_{}^{}{\vec{\textbf{E}} \cdot d\vec{\ell}} (^3e149e), we find that
dV = -E_{\ell}d\ell
where dV is the infinitesimal Potential Difference between two points a distance d\ell apart with a component of the electric field E_{\ell} in the direction of the displacement. Rearranging, we find that
E_{\ell} = - \frac{dV}{d\ell}
or \vec{\textbf{E}} = - \vec{\nabla} V
where \nabla represents the Gradient Vector.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 23-7

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Electric Field Lines
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Electric Field Lines
Topic: Electromagnetism
A common way of thinking about Electrical Fields is in terms of a simple diagram of charged particles or bodies with lines flowing into or out of them. These are called electric field lines or simply field lines.
There are many rules for how field lines should be drawn:

Electric field lines indicate the direction of the electric field; the field points in the direction tangent to the field line at any point
The lines are drawn so that the magnitude of the electric field, E, is proportional to the number of lines crossing unit area perpendicular to the lines. The closer together the lines, the stronger the field.
Electric field lines start on positive charges and end on negative charges (or infinity!); and the number starting or ending is proportional to the magnitude of the charge.
Electric field lines never cross. You can’t have two directions at the same point.
Lines are always perpendicular to lines of constant Voltage


References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 21

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Electric Flux
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Electric Flux
Topic: Electromagnetism


                  
                  Electric Flux 
                  
                

The electric flux refers to the Electrical Fields passing through a given area, and is denoted by \Phi_{E} = \vec{\textbf{E}} \cdot \vec{\textbf{A}}
where \vec{\textbf{E}} is the electric field vector and \vec{\textbf{A}} is the area vector; that is, the vector with magnitude corresponding to area and direction normal to it.


Electric flux is often though about in terms of Electric Field Lines, such that if you have N field lines passing through an area then N \propto \Phi. Typically, flux is found using Gauss’s Law.
For ways of evaluating flux, see Flux in Two Dimensions and Flux in Three Dimensions.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 22

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Electric Potential Due To A Point Charge
Electric Potential Energy
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Electric Potential Energy
Topic: Electromagnetism
Electric Potential Energy is due to the conservative force due to Electrical Fields.


                  
                  Derivation of EPE 
                  
                

From the Conservation of Energy for conservative forces, we know that \Delta U = -W. We can then define the change in electric potential energy to be \Delta U = U_{b} - U_{a} when a Charge q moves from some point a to another point b. If we assume the field \vec{\textbf{E}} is uniform, then the Work done W by the electric field to move the distance a charge d (to go from a to b) is W = Fd = qEd
The change in electric potential energy is the negative of this, so \text{EPE} = \Delta U = U_{b} - U_{a} = -W = -qEd
Typically, we then define U_{a} to be 0 or U_{b} to be 0. The latter is often convenient because it leaves us with positive values.


The electric potential energy per charge is defines Electric Potential.
Using Voltage, we can also write the change in potential energy of a charge q when it moves from point a to point b as
\Delta U = U_{b} - U_{a} = q(V_{b} - V_{a}) = qV_{ba}


                  
                  Potential Energy Example 
                  
                

If the potential difference between two parallel plates is 6 volts, and a charge of 1 Coulomb is moved across them, what is the change in potential energy?
Solution:
\Delta U = qV_{ba} = (1 \text{ C})(6 \text{ V}) = 6 \text{ J}



References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 23

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Electrical Conductors
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Electrical Conductors
Topic: Electromagnetism
Materials have an associated property called their electrical conductivity. It refers to how easily electricity flows through them. Materials that are good conductors, like copper, typically have free Electrons, which allow them to transfer charge easily. These are thus good conductors.
A material which is good at conducting is called a conductor, and one which isn’t is called a insulator or dielectric.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 24-5

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Electrical Fields
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Electrical Fields
Topic: Electromagnetism
A Charge produces an electric field in all of space, with a force dictated by Coulombs Law. Every “thing” in the field experiences a force due to it. A field is denoted by \vec{E}.
The magnitude of \vec{E} on a “test charge” q is \vec{\textbf{E}} = \frac{\vec{\textbf{F}}}{q}
where the charge is assumed to be small enough that it does not impact \vec{E}.
The electric field, \vec{E} = \frac{K}{r^{2} q}\hat{\textbf{r}}, can be measured \text{ in V/m or N/C}. (volts per meter or Newtons per Coulomb). Note that K = 8.99 \cdot 10^{9} \cdot \frac{N*m^{2}}{c^{2}} or K is the electrical constant, and is equal to \frac{1}{4\pi \epsilon_{0}}
Where \epsilon_{0} is the constant for the Permittivity of Free Space, 8.85 \text{ pF/m}.
Field Lines
Transclude of Electric-Field-Lines#electric-field-lines
Electric Fields and Electrical Conductors

Electric field inside a conductor is 0 (electrons move inside)
Net charge on a conductor is on the outside
Electric field of a conductor is always perpendicular to the surface for an electrostatic
Sharp or round ends have larger charge density which equals large electric fields. More mathematically, areas of greater curvature have greater electric fields


References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 21

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Electromagnetic Velocity Selector
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Electromagnetic Velocity Selector
Topic: Electromagnetism
If you release Ions of Charge q through a slit into a region where there are perpendicular Electrical Fields and Magnetic Fields, the ions will follow a straight-line path if the electric force is balanced by the magnetic force, which occurs only when v = \frac{E}{B}

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 27

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Electromagnetic Waves
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Electromagnetic Waves
Waves of the Electric Field and Magnetic Field that propagate through space. Light is an example.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Electron Drift Speed
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Electron Drift Speed
Topic: Electromagnetism
One occasionally useful way to define Current Density is in terms of the number of moving Electrons and their drift speed v_{d}. Drift speed refers to the average speed of electrons inside a wire. Collisions within the wire keep them from accelerating further, so the drift speed is much smaller than the electron’s average random speed.
The relation is:
j = -ne v_{d}
where the - sign denotes that the electrons move opposite of conventional Current.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 25

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Electron Volt
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Electron Volt
Topic: Electromagnetism
When dealing with Electrons, Joules are a very large unit of energy. Accordingly, we sometimes use the electron volt (eV) which is defined as the energy acquired by a particle carrying the Elementary Charge through a Potential Difference of 1 Volt. Thus, 1 \text{ eV} = 1.6022 \times 10^{-19} \text{ J}

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 23-8

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Elementary Charge
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Elementary Charge
Topic: Electromagnetism
The magnitude of the charge of a proton or an electron is equal to e = 1.60 \times 10^{-19} \text{ C}, where \text{C} is a Coulomb. An electron has a charge of -e, and a proton has e. It has been found that all other charges are exact multiples of e. That is, all charges Q = \alpha e, \alpha \in \mathbb{Z}.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 23-8

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Energy Stored in a Capacitor
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Energy Stored in a Capacitor
Topic: Electromagnetism
The energy stored in a capacitor is found by
U = \frac{1}{2} \frac{Q^{2}}{C} = \frac{1}{2}CV^{2}= \frac{1}{2}QV

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 23-4

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Energy Stored in a Magnetic Field
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Energy Stored in a Magnetic Field
Topic: Electromagnetism
An Inductors of inductance L is carrying a Current I. The energy stored in the inductor is given by U = \frac{1}{2} LI^{2}
when we take U = 0 when I = 0.
This formula is comparable to the Energy Stored in a Capacitor.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 30-3

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Equipotential Lines and Surfaces
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Equipotential Lines and Surfaces
Topic: Electromagnetism
The Electric Potential over space can be represented by drawing equipotential lines or, in three dimensions, equipotential surfaces.

Surfaces where the potential difference between any two points is zero, i.e. Level Curves
Surfaces must be perpendicular to the Electric Field at any point
No Work is required to move a charge from one point on the surface to another


References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 23-5

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Farad
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Farad
The unit of Capacitors.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Faraday's Law of Induction
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Faraday’s Law of Induction
Topic: Electromagnetism
Michael Faraday discovered that a changing Magnetic Field induces a EMF: \mathscr{E} = - \frac{d\Phi_{B}}{dt}
where \Phi_{B} is the Magnetic Flux.
The induced EMF produces a current whose magnetic field opposes the original change in flux. This is called Lenz’s Law.
See also Maxwell-Faraday Equation. This is one of Maxwell’s Equations.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 29

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Ferromagnets
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Ferromagnets
Topic: Electromagnetism
All magnetic fields are said to be produced due to moving Electrical Charges. How, then, do fridge magnets work? Well it is due to the Electrons moving inside the material. For example, the electrons in the orbit of a copper atom produce some tiny magnetic field, as described by the Biot-Savart Equation. In most materials, these electron-induced fields cancel out. In certain ferromagnets, however, they can be reinforce to become permanent magnets.
Ferromagnets are made up of many tiny domains, each a tiny sub-magnet. In a permanent magnet, they become aligned. When they become fixed in place, they become “hard.” In other materials, these aligned domains instead return to random, in which case they are considered “soft.”

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 28

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Force on an Electric Current in a Magnetic Field
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Force on an Electric Current in a Magnetic Field
Topic: Electromagnetism
When a wire carrying an electric Current is placed in a Magnetic Field, it experiences a force. The direction of the force is given by a right-hand-rule: put your fingers in the direction of the conventional Current I, curl them in the direction of the magnetic field \vec{\textbf{B}}, then your thumb points in the direction of \vec{\textbf{F}}. Mathematically, it is found that:
\vec{\textbf{F}} = I \vec{\ell} \times \vec{\textbf{B}}
where \vec{\ell} is the length and direction of a straight wire. More generally, though, it can be written that d \vec{\textbf{F}} = I d\vec{\ell} \times \vec{\textbf{B}} \to \vec{\textbf{F}} = I \int\limits_{}^{}{d\vec{\ell} \times \vec{\textbf{B}}} = \int\limits_{}^{}{\vec{j} \cdot d\vec{A}} \int\limits_{}^{}{d\vec{\ell} \times \vec{\textbf{B}}}

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 27

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Gauss's Law
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Topic: Electromagnetism
Gauss’s Law
Gauss’s Law is a method for finding/analyzing the net charge in an enclosed space and the related Electric Flux through a surface.


                  
                  Gaussian Surface 
                  
                

We deem an imaginary closed surface surrounding some section of space to be a Gaussian Surface.




                  
                  Gauss's Law 
                  
                

The relation between the electric flux through a closed surface (Gaussian Surface) and the net charge Q_\text{encl} enclosed within that surface is given by
\oint \vec{\textbf{E}} \cdot d\vec{\textbf{A}} = \frac{Q_\text{encl}}{\epsilon_{0}}
which is a surface integral.


The law is found by dividing a surface into many small areas of size d \vec{\textbf{A}} and summing over the surface to find the total electric flux through a closed surface.
Differential Form
It follows from the Divergence Theorem that Gauss’s Law can be alternatively written in the differential form \nabla \cdot \vec{\textbf{E}} = \frac{\rho}{\epsilon_{0}}
where \nabla \cdot \vec{\textbf{E}} is the Divergence Operator of the Electric Field \vec{\textbf{E}}, \rho is the volume charge Density, and \epsilon_{0} is the Permittivity of Free Space.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 22

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Henrys
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Henrys
Topic: Electromagnetism
The Henry is a unit of inductance (used for Mutual Inductance and L in circuits): 1 \text{ H} = \frac{1 \text{ V} \cdot \text{s}}{1 \text{ A}} = 1 \Omega \cdot \text{s}
where V is Volt, A is Ampere, and \ohm is Resistance.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 30

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Kirchhoffs Rules
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Kirchhoffs Rules
Kirchhoff’s First Law
The total current flowing towards a junction is equal to the total current flowing away from that junction. i.e the algebraic sum of the currents flowing in a junction is zero.
Kirchhoff’s Second Law
In a closed circuit the algebraic sum of the products of the current and the resistance of each part of the circuit is equal to the resultant EMF, or voltage, in the circuit.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 26-3

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Lorentz Force
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Lorentz Force
Topic: Electromagnetism
The Lorentz Force is the combination of the Electric Field and the Magnetic Field on a point charge. It states that a particle of Charge q moving with a velocity \vec{\textbf{v}} in an electric field \vec{\textbf{E}} and a magnetic field \vec{\textbf{B}} experiences a force of
F = q(\vec{\textbf{E}} + v \times \vec{\textbf{B}})
where (\vec{\textbf{v}} \times \vec{\textbf{B}}) is a Vector Cross Product.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 27

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Magnet
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Magnet
Topic: Electromagnetism
A magnet is an object with a Magnetic Field. It has a north and south pole.
If a magnet is divided, it creates two smaller magnets both with north and south poles.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 27

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Magnetic Dipole Moment
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Magnetic Dipole Moment
Topic: Electromagnetism
The magnetic dipole moment (\vec{\mu}) of an object determines the magnitude of the Torque that the object experiences in a given Magnetic Field. It emerges from the idea of Current flowing in a closed loop of wire.
\vec{\mu} = NI \vec{A}
where \vec{A} is the area vector - it has direction normal to the plane of the coil and magnitude equal to the area - and N is the number of loops of wire.
See also Torque on a Current Loop in a Magnetic Field.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 27

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Magnetic Field Due To A Long Straight Wire
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Magnetic Field Due To A Long Straight Wire
Topic: Electromagnetism
The Magnetic Field due to a long straight wire holding a Current I is proportional to the distance r from the wire: B = \frac{\mu_{0}}{2\pi} \frac{I}{r}
where \mu_{0} is the magnetic constant. The direction of the magnetic field lines is given by a right-hand-rule: point your thumb in the direction, and your fingers curl in the direction of the Magnetic Field.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 28

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Magnetic Field of a Moving Point Charge
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Magnetic Field of a Moving Point Charge
Topic: Electromagnetism
When a Charge q moves through space with a Velocity \vec{v}, it creates a Magnetic Field at a distance r in the direction of the unit vector \hat{\textbf{r}} given by \vec{\textbf{B}} = \frac{\mu_{0}}{4\pi} \frac{q \vec{v} \times \hat{\textbf{r}}}{r^{2}}
where \mu_{0} is the Vacuum Magnetic Permeability. This becomes generalized for more charges in the Biot-Savart Equation for a Current.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 28

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Magnetic Field
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Magnetic Field
Topic: Electromagnetism
The magnetic field, denoted by \vec{\textbf{B}}, is the Vector Field surrounding a Magnet. It can be thought of much as the Electric Field. The direction of the magnetic field at a given location is the direction that the north pole of a compass needle would point if placed at that location.
The SI unit for the magnetic field is the Tesla (t). It is often measured in the gauss (G): 1 \text{ G} = 10^{-4} \text{ T}.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 27

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Magnetic Flux
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Magnetic Flux
Topic: Electromagnetism
The magnetic flux passing through a certain area is given by the Surface Integral \Phi_{B} = \iint \vec{\textbf{B}} \cdot d \vec{\textbf{A}}
also see Flux in Three Dimensions. By Faraday’s Law of Induction, a changing magnetic flux induces a Voltage.
It is measured in Webers.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 29

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Magnetic Gauss's Law
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Magnetic Gauss’s Law
Topic: Electromagnetism
Much like Gauss’s Law, there is a relationship between the Flux in Three Dimensions due to a Magnetic Field. Specifically, it states that the Surface Integral evaluates to 0:
\oint\oint_{S} \vec{\textbf{B}} \cdot d\vec{\textbf{A}} = 0
Differential Form
In differential form, using the Divergence Operator as written in Del Notation, \nabla \cdot \vec{\textbf{B}} = 0

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 29

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Mass Spectrometer
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Mass Spectrometer
Topic: Electromagnetism
A mass spectrometer uses Magnetic Field and Electric Field effects to measure the mass of Ions, which in turn allows for you to determine the material makeup of a sample.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 27

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Maxwell's Equations
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Maxwell’s Equations
James Clark Maxwell outlined a series of four equations which form the basis of the study of Electromagnetism. The equations are:

Gauss’s Law
Magnetic Gauss’s Law
Faraday’s Law of Induction (a.k.a) Maxwell-Faraday Equation
Ampere’s Law


References

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Maxwell-Faraday Equation
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Maxwell-Faraday Equation
Topic: Electromagnetism
Faraday’s Law of Induction can be extended into the Maxwell-Faraday Equation, which states that a changing Magnetic Flux produces an Electric Field. The mathematical relation is \oint \vec{\textbf{E}} \cdot d \vec{\ell} = - \frac{d\Phi_{B}}{dt}
where \vec{\textbf{E}} is the Electric Field and \Phi_{B} is the Magnetic Flux. For evaluating this, see Line Integrals.
Differential Interpretation
This can also be written as \nabla \times \vec{\textbf{E}} = - \frac{\partial \vec{\textbf{B}}}{\partial t}
where \nabla \times \vec{\textbf{E}} represents the Curl of the Electrical Fields and those are Partial Derivatives of the Magnetic Field. You can go from one form to the other by Stokes’ Theorem.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 29

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Ohms Law
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Ohms Law


                  
                  Ohm's Law 
                  
                

Current, or amperage (I), in a circuit is equal to the voltage (V) in the circuit divided by the resistance (R) of the circuit. I = \frac{V}{R} \to V = IR \to R = \frac{V}{I}
Resistance is measured in ohms (\ohm) Current in Amps (A) and Voltage in volts (V).




                  
                  Equivalence in Water 
                  
                

Consider a pipe with water flowing through it. Think of current as the water flow rate, the voltage as the potential energy due to height, and the resistance as the width of a pipe. It makes sense that for more water to flow (I_{f} > I_{0}) either the resistance must decrease (R_{f} < R_{0}) or the energy must increase to push it harder (V_{f} > V_{0}).

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Potential Due to Any Charge Distribution
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Potential Due to Any Charge Distribution
Topic: Electromagnetism
The Electric Potential Due To A Point Charge is given by
V = \frac{1}{4\pi \epsilon_{0}} \frac{Q}{r}
A Charge distribution is then given by summing over all the charges. Using a limiting approach, this yields, for a continuous distribution,
V = \frac{1}{4\pi \epsilon_{0}} \int\limits_{}^{}{\frac{dq}{r}} 
Examples


                  
                  Potential Difference Due to a Ring of Charge 
                  
                

A thin circular ring of radius R has a uniformly distributed charge Q. Determine the electrical potential at a point P along the axis of the ring at a distance x from its center.
Solution:
We simply integrate over the ring using the above equation. Each point on the ring is equidistant from P, and that distance is r = (x^{2} + R^{2})^{\frac{1}{2}}:
V = \frac{1}{4\pi \epsilon_{0}} \int\limits_{}^{}{\frac{dq}{r}} = \frac{1}{4\pi \epsilon_{0}} \frac{Q}{(x^{2} + R^{2})^{\frac{1}{2}}}


”

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 23-4

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Resistance
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Resistance
Any Circuit component that hinders the flow of charge is called a resistor.
The ability to hinder the flow of charge is called resistance, and is measured in Ohms (\ohm) (see Ohms Law).
When electricity is flowing through a wire, the length of the wire is proportional to the resistance. The thickness of the wire also impacts the amount of resistance. The thinner wire will offer more resistance than a thicker wire due to the decreased numbers of Electrons in the thinner wire. The relationship between resistance and the area of the cross section or a wire is inversely proportional. Mathematically, this becomes
R = \rho \frac{\ell}{A}
where \ell is the thickness of the wire, A is the cross-sectional area, and \rho is the Resistivity.
A resistor can be compared to a coffee filter hindering the flow of coffee water.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 25

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Resistivity
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Resistivity
Topic: Electromagnetism
The resistivity (\rho) is a material property that determines how much Resistance (\Omega) it generates per unit distance (\text{m}). It makes sense, then, that the units are [\rho] = [\Omega \cdot \text{m}].
What this means is that a wire of a high resistivity material impedes the flow of electricity a lot, whereas one with a low value allows electricity to flow easily. Generally, the values depend on Temperature, heat treatment, and other factors.
Copper has a value of \rho = 1.68 \times 10^{-8} \text{ }\Omega\cdot\text{m}.
Each material also has a resistivity temperature coefficient \alpha. The resistance of metals increases with temperature by \rho_{T} = \rho_{0}[1 + \alpha(T - T_{0})]


                  
                  Relationship between Resistivity and Conductivity 
                  
                

The reciprocal of the resistivity gives the conductivity of the material: \sigma = \frac{1}{\rho}



References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 25-4

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Solenoid
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Solenoid
Topic: Electromagnetism
A solenoid is an electrical component consisting of many tightly wound wires. The Magnetic Field inside a solenoid is constant, and given by: B = \mu_{0} n I
where n is the number of loops per unit length, I is the Current, and \mu_{0} is the magnetic constant.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 28

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Terminal Voltage
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Terminal Voltage
Topic: Electromagnetism
The terminal voltage is the Voltage measured across the two terminals of a Electric Battery, V_{ab} = V_{a} - V_{b}. When no Current is drawn from the battery, V_{ab} = \mathscr{E}, where \mathscr{E} is the EMF. When a Current I flows from the battery, there is a drop given by:
V_{ab} = \mathscr{E} - Ir


                  
                  Battery with Internal Resistance 
                  
                

A 65.0\text{-}\ohm resistor is connected to the terminals of a battery whose EMF is 12.0 \text{ V} and whose internal Resistance is 0.5 \text{ }\ohm. Calculate (a) the current in the circuit, (b) the terminal voltage V_{ab}, and (c) the power dissipated in the resistor R and in the battery’s internal resistance r.
Solution:
(a) These are Resistors in Series, so the total resistance is R + r. The current is then I = \frac{\mathscr{E}}{R+r} = \frac{12.0 \text{ V}}{65.5 \text{ } \ohm} = 0.183 \text{ A}.
(b) The terminal voltage is V_{ab} = \mathscr{E} - Ir = 12.0 \text{ V} - (0.183 \text{ A})(0.5 \text{ }\ohm) = 11.9 \text{ V}
(c) The Power dissipated in R is I^{2}R = 2.18 \text{ W} and in r is I^{2}r = 0.02 \text{ W}.



References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 26

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Tesla
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Tesla
Topic: Electromagnetism
The Tesla is the unit of the Magnetic Field, and is defined as 1 \text{ T} = 1 \text{ N/A} \cdot \text{m}
(1 Newton per Ampere meter)

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 27

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Torque on a Current Loop in a Magnetic Field
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Torque on a Current Loop in a Magnetic Field
Topic: Electromagnetism
The torque on a Current loop (in a uniform magnetic field) is then \vec{\tau} = \vec{\mu} \times \vec{\textbf{B}}
This is reminiscent of electric Dipoles. We can, just like electric dipoles, define a type of potential energy for a magnetic dipole in a magnetic field, which is: U = - \vec{\mu} \times \vec{\textbf{B}}; \quad U\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right) = 0

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 27

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Transformers
Vacuum Magnetic Permeability
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Vacuum Magnetic Permeability
Topic: Electromagnetism
The vacuum magnetic permeability is a physical constant that is used in the Magnetic Field of a Moving Point Charge. It is given by \mu_{0} = 4 \pi \times 10^{-7} \text{(T m)/A}
where T is Tesla, m is meters, and A is Ampere.
It is related to the Permittivity of Free Space.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 28

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Volt
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Volt
Topic: Electromagnetism
Named in honor of Alessandro Volta, the Volt is the unit for Potential Difference. It is defined as
1 \text{ V} = 1 \text{ J/C}
where J is Joules and C is Coulomb.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 23-1

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Voltage
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Voltage
Topic: Electromagnetism

The Electric Potential Energy per unit Charge.

If we put a tiny positive test charge q in a uniform Electric Field, it have some amount of electric potential energy U_{a} at some arbitrary point a relative to some zero. Then, the electric potential V_{a} at this point is defined as
V_{a} = \frac{U_{a}}{q} 
This gives us the potential difference between point a and the zero, b.
The unit is the Volt.


                  
                  Comparison to Mechanics 
                  
                

In Electromagnetism, many of our concepts have equivalents to Newtons Laws of Motion. Voltage has a mechanical analog of force, F. It can be thought of as voltage representing the amount of force required to hold a charge, much like a normal force holds a mass.


Electric Potential and the Electric Field
The potential difference can be derived from the Conservation of Energy as
\Delta V = V_{ba} = V_{b} - V_{a} = - \int\limits_{a}^{b}{\vec{\textbf{E}}\cdot d\vec{\ell}}
Notice that is the Vector Dot Products between the electric field and some infinitesimal displacement d \vec{\ell}. That makes this a Line Integral. 
We can go the opposite direction, as well: Electric Field Determined from Voltage.
Specific Cases
Transclude of Capacitors#^8bdbf4
Transclude of Electric-Potential-Due-To-A-Point-Charge#^79d358
Building on this point charge example, we can find the Potential Due to Any Charge Distribution.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 23-1

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Weber Unit
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Weber Unit
Topic: Electromagnetism
Weber Unit
The weber unit is the unit of Magnetic Flux. It is given by 1 \text{ Wb} = 1 \text{ V} \cdot \text{s}

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 29

Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Ampere.title: Ampere
Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Ampere.content:
Ampere
Topic: Energy
The Ampere is the unit of Electrical Charge.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics: Chapter null

Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Conserva.title: Conservation of Energy
Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Conserva.content:
Conservation of Energy
Topic: Energy


                  
                  Law of Conservation of Energy 
                  
                

Energy can neither be created nor destroyed, only converted from one form of energy to another.


E_{total}=K_{E} + P_{E} + Q
The total energy within a closed system is equal to the sum of the kinetic energy, potential energy, and internal/thermal energy. Alternatively, it could be stated that:
W_{net} = W_{conservative} + W_{non-conservative}
Conservation of Mechanical Energy


                  
                  Conservation of Mechanical Energy 
                  
                

If only Conservative Forces act, then the total mechanical energy of a system is conserved.


Proof
k = \frac{1}{2}mv^{2} => W_{net}=\Delta K
\text{Potential Energy }  U => \Delta U = -W_{conservative}
Thus, if only conservative forces act:
\begin{aligned}
\Delta K &= -\Delta U \\
K_{f} - K_{i} &= U_{i} - U_{f}\\
U_{i} + K_{i} &= U_{f} + K_{f} \\
E_{i} &= E_{f} 
\end{aligned}


                  
                  Sample Problem 
                  
                

A roller coast includes a vertical drop of 59.4 meters. If the speed at the crest is 0 and no friction is present, what would be the speed of the roller coaster at the bottom of the drop?
E_{total} = (PE+KE)_{top} = (PE + KE)_{bottom}
Since there is no kinetic energy at the top and no potential energy at the ground, we conclude that:
PE_{top} = KE_{bottom}
Therefore:
(mgh)_{top} = (\frac{1}{2}mv^{2})_{bottom}
gh = \frac{1}{2}v^2 \to v = \sqrt{2gh} = \sqrt{(2)(-9.81 m/s^2)(-59.4)} = 34.138 m/s
The speed at the bottom is 34.1 meters per second.



References

Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Conserva.title: Conservative Forces
Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Conserva.content:
Conservative Forces
Topic: Energy
A force is conservative if:

The work done by moving an object from an initial to final position is independent of the path taken
The work done by the force is 0 in a round trip

In other words, a conservative force can only be written as a function of position.
The three most common conservative forces in elementary physics are:

Newtons Law of Gravity
Hookes Law (Elastic Potential Energy)
Electric Potential Energy

How To Tell if a Force is Conservative
If a force is given by a Vector Field \vec{\textbf{F}}, and if curl(\vec{\textbf{F}}) = 0 and the domain where \vec{\textbf{F}} is defined is simply connected, then \vec{\textbf{F}} is conservative and is a Gradient Field and you can apply Greens Theorem.

References

Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Elastic-.title: Elastic Potential Energy
Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Elastic-.content:
Elastic Potential Energy
The work done on a spring is the area under the Force versus Elongation curve. This also equals the change in elastic potential of the system (EPE). Since a Force versus Elongation curve is linear, the area under it is a triangle, and the area of a triangle is \frac{1}{2}(base)(height), so  the elastic potential energy is:
EPE = \frac{1}{2}(F \Delta x) = \frac{1}{2}(k\Delta x^2)

Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Energy.title: Energy
Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Energy.content:
Energy
Energy is the ability to cause change or the ability to do work and is measured in the SI unit Joules. All forms of energy can be measured in a unit called Joule.
1 \text{ J} = \frac{\text{ kg} \cdot \text{m}}{^2}{\text{ s}^{2}}
1 calorie = 4.186 Joules
1 Kilocalorie = 4186 Joules
Work is the process of causing matter to move against an opposing force. When matter moves, it is changing position, and that requires energy.
All forms of energy can be classified as either potential or kinetic energy.
Potential Energy
Transclude of Potential-Energy
Kinetic Energy
Transclude of Kinetic-Energy#kinetic-energy

Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Heating-.title: Heating and Cooling Curves
Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Heating-.content:
Heating and Cooling Curves
Temperature changes and phase transistions over time are modeled by heating curves and cooling curves. They both show the relationship between the temperature of the substance (plotted on the vertical axis), and the time that has passed (plotted on the horizontal axis).
A heating curve shows constant heating, with particles gaining energy and phase transitions from solid to liquid or liquid to gas.
A cooling curve shows constant cooling, with particles losing energy and phase transitions from gas down to solid.
The curves often have horizontal lines to show the phase transition over time.
Sample Heating Curve

Sample Cooling Curve

Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Joules.title: Joules
Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Joules.content:
Joules
Topic: Energy
The Joule is the SI unit for energy and Work, named after James Prescott Joule. A Joule is defined as 1 Newton Meter. That means that a Joule is the work done when a force of 1 Newton displaces a mass through a distance of 1 meter in the direction of the force. It can alternatively be described as:

1 Watt/second
\frac{\text{kg} \times \text{m}^{2}}{\text{s}^{2}}


References

Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Kinetic-.title: Kinetic Energy
Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Kinetic-.content:
Kinetic Energy
Topic: Energy
Kinetic energy is the energy which a particle has a result of its movement. Kinetic energy is generally defined by the formula
k = \frac{1}{2}mv^{2}
where m is the Mass of the object, v is the Velocity, and k is the kinetic energy, measured in Joules.
Angular Motion
When angular motion is involved as well as translational, you must account for the energy that is spent rotating the object. As such, the formula becomes
K = \frac{1}{2}mv^{2} + \frac{1}{2}I_{cm} \omega^{2}
k is the kinetic energy, measured in Joules, m is the Mass of the object, v is the Velocity, I_{cm} is the Moment of Inertia, and \omega is the Angular Velocity.

References

Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Potentia.title: Potential Energy
Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Potentia.content:
Potential Energy
Topic: Energy
Potential energy (U) is:

stored energy
can only be defined for Conservative Forces
Defined for a system of two objects

e.g. holding up a pen increases the potential energy of the earth-pen system; this is normally omitted for brevity



The two most common examples of potential energy in Calculus-Based Physics are:

Gravitational Potential Energy: U_{grav} = mgy where m is the Mass, y is the height from some specific reference point, and g is the acceleration due to gravity.
Elastic Potential Energy: U_{s}=\frac{1}{2}kx^{2}, where k is a Spring Constant and x is the distance which the spring is compressed.

Change in Potential Energy
Conservation of Energy
Gravitational Potential Energy
Potential energy due to the elevated position of an object is called gravitational potential energy (GPE). It is the focus of Physics 04.03.
The GPE of an object depends on the mass and height of the object, as well as the gravitational acceleration.
GPE = mgh

References

Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Power.title: Power
Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Power.content:
Power
Topic: Energy
Power is defined as the energy over time, and is measured in Watts or Horsepower.
1 \text{ W} = 1 \text{ J/s}
Power in a Circuit is given by P = \frac{dq}{dt}V = IV = I^{2}R = \frac{V^{2}}{R}
where V is Voltage and I is Current. This resembles Ohms Law and the Energy Stored in a Capacitor but is different.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 25-5

Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Work-Ene.title: Work Energy Theorem
Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Work-Ene.content:
Work Energy Theorem
Topic: Energy
The work energy theorem relates Work to Kinetic Energy. Specifically, it states that the work done by the sum of all forces acting on an object is equal to the change in the kinetic energy of that object:
W = \Delta K.

References

Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Work.title: Work
Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Work.content:
Work
Work is the application of energy. The standard equation for work is:
W = Fd
where W = the work done, measured in J, F = the applied constant force, measured in newtons, and d = the displacement the object moves in the direction of the force, measured in meters.
Work is the area under a Force versus Displacement Graph.
Work is equal to the change in kinetic energy: Work Energy Theorem
Integral
Work is much better expressed as an integral.
W = \int\limits_{a}^{b}{(F(x))dx}
Where F(x) is the force at a distance. This is important when the force varies over distance. In physics, this might be written as:
W = \int\limits_{a}^{b}{\vec{\textbf{F}} \cdot d\vec{l}}
Power
The rate at which work is done is called Power.
Other Units

Foot pound: The work accomplished when a one pound force pushes something through a distance of one foot.
Horsepower: a unit of measurement for power, 1 hp = 550 ft * lb/s = 746 Watts. 4

Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.title: Absolute Pressure
Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.content:
Absolute Pressure
Topic: Fluids
What is absolute pressure? :?: Absolute pressure is the total net pressure, P = P_{0} + P_{g} \to \text{Pressure} = \text{External Pressure + Gauge Pressure}

Absolute pressure is what is typically used in equations, such as the Hydrostatic Equation, so you’ll have to convert.

References

Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.title: Bernoulli's Equation
Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.content:
Bernoulli’s Equation
Topic: Fluid Dynamics
P_{1} + \frac{1}{2} \rho v_{1}^{2} + \rho g h_{1} = P_{2} + \frac{1}{2} \rho v_{2}^{2} + \rho g h
Where P is Absolute Pressure, \rho is Density, v is Velocity, and h is the height of the fluid at each point.
This equation comes from the Conservation of Energy. If you add up all the forms of energy that the liquid at any point has, it has to be constant.

The first term comes from pressure and volume being able to do Work
The second term comes from the Kinetic Energy of the liquid. This is called the kinetic energy density
The third term comes from the Potential Energy due to Newtons Law of Gravity

Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.title: Bernoulli's Principle
Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.content:
Topic: Fluids
Bernoulli’s Principle
Fluid velocity and pressure are inverse. Therefore if a liquid is moving faster, it exhibits less pressure on the walls of the pipe. This, along with the Application, gives an interesting idea: narrower, faster flowing pipes put less pressure on the pipe.
See also Bernoulli’s Equation.
References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 13

Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.title: Buoyancy
Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.content:
Buoyancy

the buoyant force on a submerged object is equal to the Weight of the displaced fluid

When an object is placed into the water, it displaces water equal to its volume. The weight of that water is called the buoyancy.
F_{b}= \rho g V
An object is neutrally buoyant when the force of gravity = the force of buoyancy. This occurs when the Density of the object is equal to the Density of the water.
A object is negatively buoyant when gravity is stronger than buoyant force. The opposite is true for positive buoyancy.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.title: Computational Fluid Dynamics
Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.content:
Computational Fluid Dynamics
Topic: Fluid Dynamics
The study of Fluid Dynamics using computers.

References

Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.title: Critical Temperature
Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.content:
Critical Temperature
Topic: Fluids
At different pressures, volumes, and temperatures, a substance may or may not undergo Phase Changes. There exists a combination of pressure and temperature for each substance such that it a Gas barely transforms into a liquid, called the critical point. The temperature of this value is called the critical temperature.
In the following diagram, point c represents the critical point.



References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 18

Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.title: Equation of Continuity
Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.content:
Equation of Continuity
Topic: Fluids
The equation of continuity for fluids relates the rate of flow at one point to another, stating that they must be equal across the fluid. This is applied in narrowing or widening pipes, for example.
\rho_{1}v_{1}A_{1} = \rho_{2}v_{2}A_{2}
\rho is density, v is velocity, and A is cross-sectional area.
Conceptual
If you have a certain amount of liquid flowing through a cross-section of a pipe in a certain period of time you can imagine that liquid is pushing on all the other water further down the pipe. Therefore the rate at which the liquid is passing through must be equal everywhere.
Application
In areas where the area is narrower, it will have to move faster.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 13

Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.title: Fluids
Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.content:
Fluids
What is a fluid? :?: Something that flows, including gases, liquids, and plasmas.

What causes Pressure in a fluid? :?: The weight of the fluid and the collisions of the molecules.
